Reviews.Title: Rocky start, but MUCH better now
Reviews.Author: Brad McClintock
Reviews.Content: THE BAD NEWSI bought my Kindle Fire HD 16gb on Sept. 22nd and today is Sept. 24th.My first Kindle Fire HD 16gb came out of the box full of issues.  The speakers were real crackly at first and for some reason after about 10 minutes of using them they cleared up "a bit".  They was still a little crackling, but not as bad.The 2nd issue (still to be determined if it was an issue or just something is the norm) was the battery life.  I charged it fully and within 10 minutes of playing FlowFree, the Kindle was showing it had only 3/4ths battery life.  This could be the norm, but if it dies so fast with a simple game then it would never have kept a charge for a full length movie.The 3rd issue was the biggest for me.  I was playing a different game today and the Kindle completely shut down EVERY 5 minutes or so of playing.  I had to reboot and restart the game.  I let this happen for 5 times within a half hour time frame and decided I had enough.  I took that Kindle back to Bestbuy and exchanged it for a new one.******************************************************************************************************************THE GOOD NEWSMy NEWEST Kindle Fire HD 16gb is as far as I can tell, perfectly fine.The sound is AMAZING!!  No crackling at all and the surround sound while watching the Super 8 trailer blew me away!I still don't know about battery life.  I am assuming it is better, but I haven't hooked it to a charger yet.  I did play 30 minutes of my game that was giving me issues this morning and the battery life did not dwindle!  That is a good sign.And yes!  I played 30 minutes of that same game straight through.  The replacement Kindle did NOT shut down one time.I am SO happy that all of my issues appear to be isolated incidents!!******************************************************************************************************************THE FINAL WORDSound - AMAZING!!Picture - Outstanding!  There is still a bit of glare, but NOTHING like my other devices have.  (and no, I do not own an IPAD or Iphone.  I know those rank best in this department.Camera - This is an annoyance of mine and one reason I only gave 4 stars instead of 5.  There is no back camera and besides Skype, I have yet to locate anything to let me use the front camera!  Yet, there are a ton of photo editing apps on the market.  This is a major downside in my opinion.  If you have a Front facing camera, at least have a tab or icon to let us use it!Market - Not the biggest at all.  For what I do though, it works.  For others.. it might be a flaw.Other annoying bits to keep in mind - It would have been REALLY helpful if they made the Power and Volume buttons silver or any other color than black!  I'm sure I will get use to it, but I don't know how many times I have turned the Kindle all around trying to find the dang buttons.  They are flush with the base and blend in.. not a smart call on Amazons part.Only other complaint is the keyboard.  I wish it would turn sideways when you are typing.  It might for some programs, but haven't seen it personally.  Also would be nice to be able to read the books horizontal instead of being made to read them just vertical.  Petty complaint, but figured I'd put it in the review.  :)

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD vs Nexus 7 vs iPad
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Update (9.21.12)After a week with the Kindle Fire HD, I am still very impressed.  There are several features that I uncovered in that time that add to the already sweet hardware:1. Flash works!  If you don't mind a couple of extra steps, you can easily get flash to work on this device.  In the interest of full disclosure, I could never get flash to work properly on the Nexus 7 although some people apparently can.  Check out the comments for this review for instructions!2. Text to speech has been added to Kindle Books.  This is a great feature that I really enjoyed with the e-ink Kindle, and it's a wonderful addition to the fire.  It's great for reading while doing other tasks!3. Micro HDMI works as advertised.  You get exact mirroring of what is being displayed on the device, unlike many phones with HDMI that only allow certain video apps.  It's like having Apple's Air Play without buying Apple TV (if you don't mind running a cable across the floor).To sum up, the Fire is probably the most enjoyable tablet I've owned.  The video and audio quality is just outstanding and makes me want to use the device.  Everything about amazon's content works beautifully, and just inspires you to seek out more media.  If you're someone who wants complete control over your experience and likes to tinker, the Nexus 7 is certainly the best choice.  If you want to try replacing your laptop, the iPad or a full size android tablet (such as the Asus Transformer line) are your best choices.  However, if you'd rather spend your time enjoying movies, games, books, and music, the Kindle is far superior (in my opinion).  It's a nearly ideal combination of a convenient form factor, quality hardware and software, an extremely rich content libraries, and overall value!Original Review (9.14.12)I currently own all three of these devices, so I thought it might helpful to do a short comparison.  First, however, I want to address the ill-informed one star reviews: there is no more Flash on any new mobile devices.  It's not Amazon's or Google's fault, as Adobe decided to completely block it, so stop whining! Also, you can remove the lock screen and home screen ads at any time for a $15 one time charge.Moving on, the Kindle Fire HD is a superb product and outclasses the Nexus 7  in several ways:1. Double the storage for the same price: I ran out of space almost immediately on my Nexus 7 8GB!2. Vastly superior sound from the dual stereo speakers: the Kindle has easily the best sounding speakers on any tablet, while the Nexus is barely audible.3. Much better screen even though the resolution is the same: the Nexus 7 screen is washed out and too dim in almost every situation.  The Kindle screen has gorgeous colors and contrast, plus the anti-glare filter works quite well.4. HDMI out vs. Nothing: There is no way to get video out of the Nexus 7.5. Reduced access to Amazon content: Although you can get Kindle books, apps, and mp3's on the Nexus, there's no way to get Amazon Video or use the Kindle Lending Library on the Nexus 7.6. Build quality: the Nexus 7 feels a bit cheap compared to the Kindle and lacks the Fire's super strong Gorilla Glass.However, the Nexus has some strong advantages as well:1. Many more apps and games: the Google Play store has around 600,000 apps compared to about 60,000 on the Amazon App Store.  No malware on the Kindle though!2. Excellent processor for gaming and general performance: the Nexus is extremely snappy and high end games look amazing.  Maybe the 8.9" model will be different, but for now, the Nexus 7 is just a bit faster than the 7" Kindle Fire HD.3. Stock android software: the latest version of Android (Jelly Bean) is superb and probably the best mobile operating system currently available.When compared to my wife's iPad, it's hard to not think about price.  Besides that, I would still buy a Kindle even if they cost the same.  The 7" form factor is just more useful and comfortable than the larger tablets.  Amazon has addressed pretty much all of the hardware complaints about the original Fire including the power and volume controls, blocky/brick-like design, and poor off-angle viewing.  Basically, you're getting the premium experience of the iPad without the cost, and also in a more convenient package.I do have a few complaints about the device, as it's not quite perfect:1. Why can't I change the keyboard? I love SwiftKey on my Android phone, but I can't use it on the Kindle Fire.2. The Silk browser still needs work.  I sideloaded the Dolphin Browser, which is much faster and smoother.3. A few basic Google apps would be nice like YouTube and Maps.  Of course, you can sideload these if you want, but native support would be nice.4. We Need More Apps!  Amazon has to improve the App Store if they want to remain relevant.All in all, though, it's a fantastic device and an improvement in every way on the original.  I'll probably be selling my Nexus 7, but want to live with the Kindle for a few days to be sure.  Hopefully, we'll be able to install stock Jelly Bean soon, and have the best of both worlds.

Reviews.Title: Amazing product, great price!
Reviews.Author: Amanda A. Thompson "A thompson"
Reviews.Content: Although I loved my 2nd Edition Kindle, I was torn between purchasing an iPad, Android tablet and Kindle Fire. I somehow thought the Kindle Fire would just be for reading like my old Kindle. Well, I was wrong.My husband bought me the Kindle Fire and I use it for EVERYTHING! I not only love reading my books on my Kindle Fire, but I am addicted to the apps (in particlar Pandora and TuneIn Radio for listening to music, Pinterest, Ultimate Checklist, Travel Planner, iSpy Cameras,Facebook and Flipboard), the games (solitaire, sudoku, mahjong, wordsearch, Scrabble, movies, videos, newspapers, magazines and storing documents and photos.Unlike my old Kindle, the graphics are AMAZING! The sound is clear, even without headphones and there are hundreds of apps for anything and everything you could ever think of. At half the price of an iPad, with everything I could every want or need? I would highly recommend this product.

Reviews.Title: A great upgrade to an already-great consumer tablet!
Reviews.Author: Brian Hartman
Reviews.Content: I just received my Kindle Fire HD yesterday, so I may update this review if I discover anything else.First of all, the screen is beautiful.  I was completely blown away.  If you compare the old Kindle Fire's screen to this one, it's no contest.  It's gorgeous.  I actually find myself using my reading glasses less on this Kindle Fire than the old model.  Second, Amazon did a great job on the audio.  Professional reviews have called this the best audio on a tablet, and I have to agree.  You won't need to use headphones just to hear the tablet, that's for sure.  If you're considering upgrading from a Kindle Fire, those two improvements alone would be worth it.Physically, the Kindle Fire HD is much thinner than the original Kindle Fire. With the rounded edges, it's got a much less boxy feel than the original.  The bezel around the screen is larger than the original Kindle Fire, so the overall device is a little bit larger.  I don't find it too large to hold with one hand, but if you have a case or cover for your old Kindle Fire, it won't work on this one.As you would expect, when I opened my Kindle Fire HD and turned it on, all of my content from my old Kindle Fire was there waiting for me.  The carousel is very fluid on this version, and the overall speed of the device is much improved.  There's a camera for use with Skype (which is included on the tablet), and of course, a microphone.The camera is positioned on one of the long sides of the device, rather than the short side, so it's meant to be held in landscape mode when you're videoconferencing.  I find this an odd design decision, since every other tablet with a webcam that I've seen has it positioned in portrait mode, but it's not that big a deal.  Amazon doesn't include a camera app with the tablet, but you can easily download an app like Gallery+ that will serve that purpose fine.  The camera is most certainly *not* HD, so don't expect too much out of it, but for videoconferencing, Facebook, and such, it works fine.Movies, as you'd expect, play very well on the Kindle Fire HD.  I was impressed by both the sound and how fluid the playback was.  The device seemed to do a lot less buffering than the old Kindle Fire.  X-Ray for movies also performed admirably, showing information on actors in the movies (when supported).  It's not a feature I think I'd use very much, but it's nice to have.Books are much the same story. Everything is very fluid.  There are still no page turn animations in books, but I don't like that kind of thing, anyway.  The crisp display makes reading a pleasure.  You certainly won't mistake it for e-Ink, but it's  a nice screen to read off of. X-Ray for Books was a little disappointing, though.  I'm reading "Lord of the Flies", and X-Ray only had information on one character.  I hope authors and publishers take better advantage of the technology in the future.Happily, Bluetooth is included in the Kindle Fire HD.  To test it, I paired it with my printer, and it worked fine.  I look forward to getting a Bluetooth keyboard for it.So with all of that going for it, why didn't I give it five stars?  Well, there are some baffling design decisions.  They're not enough to really drag the Kindle Fire HD down, but they're big enough to leave me scratching my head.First, there's no charging indicator.  You have to go to the Device screen under Settings to find out if the device is charging, and how far along it is.  (I say "if" it's charging, because there are some situations, like when it's turned on and plugged into your computer, rather than an outlet, where it won't charge.)Then, there are the buttons.  Amazon seems to have trouble getting the ergonomics of their buttons right on the Kindle Fire.  In the last version, people complained because the power button stuck out too much, and could be depressed when the tablet was put on a lap, table, etc.  In this version, the buttons are all flush with the device.  Unfortunately, this makes it harder to operate the buttons by feel.  It's not hard to get used to, but it's a little disconcerting at first.And although I don't consider it a big deal, I do have to ding Amazon a little for not including a camera app.  A tablet with a camera should always include one.Overall, I would enthusiastically recommend this device to anyone thinking of upgrading from the older version of the Kindle Fire.  If you have an iPad 3, you probably won't be jealous.  And if you're a devotee of Android, you might want to go with the Nexus 7 (just because it's "pure" Android, rather than Amazon's forked version).  But I can definitely recommend this tablet without reservation to anyone looking for a great tablet experience without spending a lot of money. :)10/7/2012:Because the battery indicator problem has an easy fix (the free Battery HD app) I've decided to give the tablet 5 stars.  The buttons aren't a big deal to get used to, and the camera problem also has an app fix.  I might give the device 4 1/2 stars if I could, but since I have to use whole numbers, it's 5. :)

Reviews.Title: KFHD: Original Fire's Fumbles Fixed! (US-centric features)
Reviews.Author: Mers
Reviews.Content: tl;dr - The Kindle Fire HD is exactly what I was looking for: a thin-&-light Android tablet that lets me access digital content and surf the web/check email/entertain myself while NOT sitting at my desk. I had some initial  concerns based on some of the reviews, but between a little googling, software patches, using the right apps, and some creativity, all of them were resolved. (Scroll to **** for my list of fumbles fixed.)Overall, I think the KFHD is a brilliant little device. I like how it looks and feels. I like what you get for the price you pay. It does what I want it to do. Is it perfect? Of course not. I fully expect the one next year to make this one look like last year's Fire. OH WAIT. =DWhat I like:1. OMG the speakers are a million times better than the original Fire's. For the size and distance between speaker grilles, you can actually hear the stereo-ness of it.2. The screen! so clear and bright and pretty!3. Video out port. I cannot tell you how much I LOVE THAT HDMI OUT.4. The WiFi really is able to pick up signals from a wider area. Side-by-side compare with my OF shows me about 8 more networks in my area, and two that are 1-bar on the OF are full bar on the KFHD.5. Integration with my Amazon content is seamless.6. If you have Prime and use Prime Video (some only use it for shipping, go figure ;) you'd be crazy not to pair it with a KFHD. If you do NOT have Prime and expect to get a free month of Prime, be aware that you are not eligible for the trial month if you signed up for the free trial in the last 12-13 months (dates approximate).7. The larger size is a bit of a stretch (hah! literally for smaller hands!) but it turns out I like the wider border because it gives my hands/fingers something to hold on to and lessen the need to stretch at all.NEW! 8. Gamecircle - normally, I hate 'socializing' my games, leaderboards, achievements, all that nonsense, BUT! Gamecircle makes a Steam-like experience for game progress between OF and KFHD. If, for example, you have tri-ducked a lot of Where's My Water, and don't want to do it over again on your new tablet, Gamecircle is for you! If you can't (or won't) root/copy game files/transfer manually, Gamecircle allowed me to continue playing on the KFHD where I was last on the OF with no effort (other than enabling Gamecircle to begin with).What I DISlike (but not a dealbreaker):1. Orientation - flips at the slightest shift. Thankfully, I can lock the screen to my preferred landscape.FIXED IN 7.2.2! - Keyboard - WHY is there no CAPSLOCK? And give us more longpress options; it seems stupid to have to switch to SYM or +> "keyboards" when a longpress on the alpha keys should have the basic special characters. I'm not even asking for Swype, so what gives? And why so much space between keys? When typing on webforms, autocapitalize and autocomplete suggestions do not appear, even when I made sure the settings were correct. Very weird.3. Silk Reading View - if it is supposed to feel like a book, why are we scrolling like it is a website instead of getting tap/swipe to next page/screen?NEW!! 4. Silk crashing - on long websurfing sessions, Silk will occasionally freeze and crash, no idea why. Thankfully, it manages to restore the tabs with no problems, but it is irksome that it crashes at all.FIXED IN 7.2.2 (at least for me) - "Zombie" carousel (where stuff removed from carousel keep coming back) - I actually have not experienced this yet, but I remember how irritating it was when we weren't able to remove anything from the original Fire's carousel. Amazon patched it then, so hopefully I won't get hit before it gets patched now.Special note:Considering the events of hurricane Sandy, I was SHOCKED that my KFHD arrived exactly on time. It sat in delivery depot starting Oct 27, and I was resigned to getting it late due to flooding in NJ--then Nov 2 it turns up in my mailbox, exactly as estimated on the order page. Color me impressed, Amazon/FedEx!**** **** ****Reminder: I have the Original Fire (OF) and the Fire HD (KFHD), so any comparisons I make will be to the OF. I'm going to list the problems I've been hearing about in user reviews while waiting for my KFHD and giving my 5 cents now that I have my own for testing.**** **** ****Major Complaints (**items are my own):1. Prime Video only works in USA - unfortunately (though understandably) a vast majority of the video offerings of Amazon are only available if you are located in the USA. Due to the mess that is international intellectual property protections, Amazon actually DOES NOT HAVE PERMISSION to sell or stream a lot of media outside the US. Blame the studios/countries. It sucks for non-US buyers, honestly, but until international law is settled, we are going to have to live with regional/locality barriers. WORKAROUND: get yourself a VPN with a US IP address.2. KFHD does not ship with a charger, just a USB cord - Considering that:(a) most users *already have* USB chargers - the OF charger works on the KFHD, as does my cellphone's, and heck, if you have an iDevice, the plug head for those should work with your USB cord! How much e-waste do you really want anyway?(b) if you read the complete product description (which you should ALWAYS do when spending money!) it was clear in the 'what's in the box' section near the bottom that it was only a USB cord, no charger.(c) on the order page, under the 'add to cart' button, Amazon recommends a powerfast charger for $10 and spells out that this is not included with the KFHD--I'm shocked that people were shocked that there was no charger in the box. NON-ISSUE (but YMMV if you didn't notice, don't have any other USB-powered devices, and can't spare the cash)3. Special Offers - this sucks, but it is also easily ignored. How long do you stare at the lockscreen anyway? And they didn't spring it on buyers as a surprise... it's on the product description, and based on the trend with the e-ink Kindles, it was inevitable. I actually consider it to be typical corporate money-gouging behavior to charge to get rid of them. ALL businesses will find a way to get more money out of you, I promise; its kind of the whole point of being a business. Do I like being charged for it? No, but at least it is a nominal $15, which is certainly affordable to most buyers. The $30 for e-ink Kindles is a lot harder to swallow, IMHO. NON-ISSUE (but YMMV)**4. Customers Also Bought - I nearly cancelled my preorder because of this. I really didn't want to concede the screen space for that crap, but then Amazon promised a software update so I decided to wait, and return the KFHD if it wasn't fixed. Lo and behold! Version 7.2.1 is out, and the CAB is now user-controlled. NON-ISSUE (after update)5. My kid can see XYZ! - um, if you didn't install Kids Place or lock WiFi or password your Fire (or create *and control* one Amazon account specifically for the kid with their own Fire), you're not even TRYING to manage things. You can't hold a corporation responsible for what your kid does when the tools exist for YOU to take control. And hey, look! FreeTime has rolled out on KFHD so: NON-ISSUE, particularly after update.6. Flash not supported - OK, this one is seriously not Amazon's fault. When the owner of Flash (Adobe) announces end-of-life for mobile OS with Flash as of 08/15/2012, it is actually recommended business best practice to NOT offer technology that is on the way out. As for not seeing the content you are used to, Amazon has no control over non-Amazon sites! YES it is inconvenient, but you should be giving the dinosaur websites you are visiting the stinkeye for not having mobile-friendly versions... Or maybe they do--have you tried using "m.whatever" instead of "[...]"? You might be surprised. Besides, there are several googleable workarounds (sideloading browsers, apps) so: NON-ISSUEMinor Griping (based on reviews (**items are my own):1. Power button is invisible/impossible to find - I *really* don't get this one. I bought one of the wake/sleep covers  to make it easier, but I didn't actually need it for that. If you run your finger along the side of the KFHD you can feel a gap/edge with 2 short extrusions in a row (volume rocker) then a smooth section, another gap/edge (power), another smooth section and then the speaker grille. You don't need to see the buttons to press them, and no matter how difficult you personally find it, there is a trivial amount of time needed to make it feel normal. Beyond all that, it is approximately in the middle of the short edge of the KFHD, so just feeling in the area you will find the invisible button. NON-ISSUE**2. Battery indicator gone - I get that a LED on the button (OF) just won't work anymore for engineering/aesthetic reasons, but it was a really convenient way to see if the OF was in fact charging. WORKAROUND: install Battery HD.3. No official access to GooglePlay - Of *course* a content provider will make it easier for you to buy the competition's content. After all, they are only selling products out of the goodness of their hearts right? There's no profit motive at all! YEAH NO. And note that there is no *official* access--the KFHD (and the OF) is completely able to access 3rd party sites and allow sideloading if you feel very strongly about the app you need being not available in the Amazon appstore. NON-ISSUE3a. which leads to: Fewer apps in Amazon Appstore than GooglePlay - really? this is a thing now? How many cut-the-rope clones do you really need? The major apps are available on both stores. If you can't find your app, and sideloading doesn't work, and no decent alternative can be found, and you *absolutely MUST* have it, why not ask the developers to create a KFHD version? Surprisingly, Amazon does not control which apps have KFHD versions. Shocking, I know. NON-ISSUE3b. which leads to: WhateverApp looks ugly/does not work right on the Fire - yes, OF COURSE Amazon is responsible for how a developer designs their apps. ::eye-rolling:: NON-ISSUE (unless it is an Amazon app because that ain't right ;)4. Amazon cases overpriced - I sort of agree with this one. The official cases aren't THAT much higher on the quality scale than others available, but then again, I'm sure this is all part of their marketing/brand position. Whatever the reason, there ARE other brands available that are just as functional, so NON-ISSUE5. No SD memory slot - until the Nook Tablet HD (or whatever they're calling it) came out, there was NO major brand 7" Android tablet with a memory slot. To be honest, everyone is trying to get you married to their cloud so I doubt the major producers (Amazon, Google, Samsung, Apple) will ever offer an SD slot. Considering I haven't actually filled up my 8GB OF yet, I suspect my 32GB KFHD is going to last a while. NON-ISSUE (and if you care for rooting purposes, you're more techie than the target audience for this device anyway. The Nexus 7 seems more your speed ;)6. "only" front-facing camera - I'm betting most users would rather have their cellphone or actual cameras for pictures as they are easier to hold, are always on hand AND have decent cameras. The one on the KFHD is meant for use with Skype, and it does that job very well. Besides, you'd look pretty nutso holding up a (relatively) gigantic tablet in a sea of cellphones. The ability to switch Skype video calling from front to rear view is a nice to have but not mission critical. NON-ISSUE **plus Amazon added a camera app in 7.2.2 so no more complaints, yeah?7. No 3G/4G/LTE on the KFHD7 - I don't get this one. I suppose it is nice to have connectivity wherever you go, but to be honest the only time I am out of a WiFi zone is if I am driving around. When I'm sitting down with my tablet at home, in a cafe, in a park, in a friend's house, I will either use the available WiFi or tether to my phone. I don't want to pay for a second data plan, after all. Furthermore, I believe the price of the data plan for the KFHD8.9 is more than $50 in your second year. NON-ISSUE (but YMMV if WiFi not available in areas you frequent)8. No turn-by-turn navigation/GPS - I don't get this one at all. The car/cellphone GPS is better for that purpose. I'm not paying for a second data plan, when all I get out of it is a super-sized GPS I have to leave in my lap or the seat beside because mounting a 7-inch tablet on the dash would kill visibility. NON-ISSUE

Reviews.Title: Mildly disappointing.
Reviews.Author: S. Carroll
Reviews.Content: I did quite a bit of research before I purchased this item, and I decided that I would give it a shot. It came out of the box decently charged, and once I got everything set up I was eager to look around and discover some goodies. I downloaded the Twitter and Facebook apps, which look AMAZING on the display, but my favorite social networking app (Tumblr) was nowhere to be found. I decided to just log on using Silk and found that I couldn't type anything into the login fields. After some quick Googling, I found out that I simply needed to restart the Kindle. That took care of THAT problem easily enough...Apps: Before I bought this, I was well aware that the app store was lacking, but I didn't really realize by how much. It was virtually impossible for me to find anything useful, and in some cases I would try to download something only to find it was incompatible with the HD. This became incredibly frustrating after about an hour of use.Carousel: This is a neat feature, but constantly removing icons from it was bothersome. It frequently added icons back after I removed them even if I hadn't used the app or read the book.Browser: I found that the browser didn't work very well for me unless I loaded everything in mobile view. This wasn't terrible, but it wasn't my favorite either.I had a problem with the page orientation changing and the slightest movement, but that was fixed by locking the orientation. I also had an issue with the physical glass screen pressing inward when I used a stylus. It just made the product seem poorly made and kind of fragile. I'm accustomed to using touchscreen devices, so I wasn't pressing particularly hard. The screen just appears to have some give.I found that the touchscreen was sometimes really sensitive, while at other times it barely registered a tap or swipe. This made playing games iffy, and sometimes I'd accidentally press links in the browser that I didn't intend to press.Oh, and the ads... There were some good offers, but I found the constant advertising a bit annoying. It wasn't intrusive, but it wasn't exactly subtle either.Overall, I was disappointed with the Kindle Fire HD. It isn't a bad device, but it isn't the device for me. I won't be shunning Amazon's Kindle line, but I would only purchase again after major improvements.

Reviews.Title: The KFHD is fabulous, but it's a tool so be patient
Reviews.Author: A. Dightam
Reviews.Content: I'm very pleased with my KFHD. I've really enjoyed getting to know its capabilities. It's a tool so be patient and allow some serious playtime to unleash all your KFHD can do for you.A couple of basic tips:* Download the software update 7.2.1 as soon as you get connected to wi-fi - the update solves a lot of problems people complain about on this board. Press Sync and the update will download in the background while you play with your new KFHD and install when it next goes to sleep.* Facebook app works fine for me after the above update.* TubeMate (in the App store) is great so don't start about not being able to view YouTube.* Dolphin HD browser is really fast and it accommodates FLASH (may open a separate player window). I sideloaded that from GetJar (easy-peasey). Lots of 'sideloading' tips in the comments section of the reviews here or look in the forum or search YouTube from your new TubeMate app. I like SILK but I think Dolphin is faster.* Imho, INOMAIL Lite is better than the pre installed Amazon e-mail app (INOMAIL LITE is free in the App store)* MapQuest is a good map app* TweetCaster for Twitter is a fab Twitter app.* Movies from Amazon look magnificent, from Netflix (using the app) slightly less but still really good quality. Hulu Plus looks great.* You'll need a case - this is cheap & good (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0098F5WJC/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00). It stand the KFHD upright for watching movies at a table, etc.* Order your power supply with the KFHD and you'll get an immediate discount. Amazon sell the KFHD almost at cost so don't whine about the power supply.Issues:I've noticed the yellow hue on SILK and I can see it on HULU PLUS too. I don't mind but some might not like it.On/off button & volume - watch the camera; the buttons are to the right of the camera when the camera is upright so the buttons are easy to find if you locate where the camera is when feeling for them. Fiddly but better than protruding buttons methinks.Disclaimer: I would like to get a Nexus 7 one day (it has great reviews and I like Google products). I have no problem with Apple devices - they're excellent. Having said that, I'm thrilled with my KFHD. Enjoy yours :)

Reviews.Title: March 31 2013 update  (old title: Better value / different experience than iPad Mini)
Reviews.Author: M. Zolikoff
Reviews.Content: March 31 2013 update -A few days ago my son accidentally dropped and shattered the glass on our iPad 2, but it still worked normally otherwise.  My wife and I debated the various options:  get it fixed by a 3rd party or by Apple, buy a new iPad 2/3/Mini or a Kindle or other Android tablet, or do nothing.  I asked what apps she and my son used the most on the iPad and then loaded them on my Kindle Fire HD so they could "test" the experience.  In short, it was a slightly "painful"/stressful experience for all of us, as I couldn't just drop the Kindle in their laps and let them run free.  "See this hidden button on the side?  Wait, where is that bugger?  Ah, here it is. This is how you wake it up.  Ok, this is the carousel, and you have to swipe through this thing until you find the app you want, or you can touch the App link at the top.  Oh, wait, it's a bit laggy today, sorry.  Hmmm, that app froze.  Hmmm, super laggy today.  Oh, how do you adjust the volume?  Well, there are these hidden buttons on the side, or you can tap on the screen and wait for the onscreen controls to come up.  What, you want to get to the Internet?  Um, let me remember how to do that; oh, the Favorites star.  Or you can (again) swipe through the carousel" etc etc etc.  5 minutes later the experiment was concluded and the results were, um, not positive.So we went to the Apple store to see what it would cost to fix the iPad, and while we waited we played with the iPad Mini.  O.M.G. that thing was fast and light (308g vs 395g - trust me, there's a difference).  Granted, you don't get the full Amazon ecosystem experience in terms of content (but you can load the Amazon Video app), but wow.  Did I mention it was fast?  And easy to find the wake up/home button?  And a familiar experience.  After we found out how much it would cost to get it fixed/replaced by Apple, I did a quick Google search to find a local ok-Yelp-rated iPad repair shop, and then we compared our options.Options:$249 - New replacement via Apple with 90 day warranty$330 - New iPad Mini$175 - New Kindle Fire HD from Best Buy with a $25 Rewards certificate (normally $200)$110 - get the iPad fixed by a 3rd partyNot only was getting the iPad fixed our best option monetarily, but in terms of the OS/interface experience and speed and reliability, it made more sense (for us) to stick with the iPad for now.Now, if the Kindle experience would have been on par with the Apple experience I would have pushed for a new Kindle Fire HD for another $65.  But I couldn't make that argument, I simply couldn't.  Since he was 2, my son has been able to use iOS with almost no guidance from me, but with the Kindle it's "Daddy, how do I?" and "Daddy, how do I?" every 3 minutes.  And the speed difference between the two is just night and day.So, there you go.  Personally, I'm "ok" with my Kindle and the way it works as compared to iOS.  But when it comes to "just working" for my wife and son, I have to go with the iPad every day and twice on Sundays.================Previous ReviewPrior to my purchase, I had been thinking about a 7" tablet for about six months, as my iPad 2 had become the family's central digital device and my digital reading appetite had been increasing at a logarithmic rate.  The next logical step was a device for myself, right?Once the iPad Mini's pricing became available (and immediately priced me out of the market - tsk tsk, Apple, as my family has two iPhones, an iPod Touch, an iPad 2 and a Macbook Pro), I spent about two weeks making extensive pro/con lists and reading every reputable review I could find about the Kindle Fire HD and the Nexus 7.  In the end it really boiled down to one thing:  Amazon Prime.Sure, a faster tablet with a better screen, a more-extensive app store, a flat/open operating system, and a more-aggressive operating system upgrade schedule is nice, but in the end I had to ask myself one simple question:  "what am I going to use this tablet for?"  And the answers were:  browsing, email, Facebook, reading, and *maybe* the occasional video.  It was the last two answers that really helped me make my decision.See, we have Amazon Prime.  And while we stream quite a bit from Amazon using our Prime account and our LG TV, having a Kindle would give me access to an additional (and significant) chunk of content.  Plus there's the (albeit limited on a monthly basis) Kindle Lending Library.So, I tromped on down to Best Buy with a few Reward Zone certificates in hand and woke up a week later having consumed a massive amount of Star Trek, Star Wars and Fringe episodes and a plethora of cheesy B sci-fi movies.  Seriously, that additional chunk of content I was talking about?  Um, it's a LOT, and there's a LOT of good stuff there.  And, I've been ripping DVDs and whatnot to MP4s and sideloading them like crazy (hint: do a search for the Personal Videos app on the Kindle and make it a favorite - this is the cleanest and easiest way to find your sideloaded videos).  Not to mention downloading a bunch of free classics from the Gutenberg Project (hint: and dropping them in the Documents folder using ES Explorer).  Have you ever read beyond the first sentence of Moby Dick?  It's a HOOT!  The narrator is a sarcastic, slap-you-in-the-face, very Louis C.K. kind of guy.  I actually think that Moby Dick is a comedy.In the short week I've had my Kindle, I can't even begin to calculate what it would take to get the content I've consumed on Google Play or the iTunes Store.  This tablet may not be the fastest, sleekest device or have the wicked-easy OS of an Apple iOS device, but man it has content.My main gripes thus far center around physical design.  Frankly, the volume and on/off buttons are useless JUNK and every port is in the wrong place.  When I pick up my iPad and need to wake it up, it's one big button on the face that I can find in the dark while half inebriated; easy easy easy, so easy in fact that my 3 year old son can do it.  With the Kindle Fire HD it's a "which way am I holding this damn thing and where is that button again?!?!?" experience.  Hey Jeff B, here's a design hint:  give your prototypes to a 3 year old and tell them to turn it on.  If they can't, YOU HAVE THE WRONG DESIGN.  Regarding the ports... normally, I wouldn't care where the ports are, but you will when you try to find a case for your Kindle that ISN'T the $40 version from Amazon.  Read the reviews and the 2/3/4-star reviews all sound the same: "the designer didn't get this right"/"it opens the wrong way"/"opposite"/etc, but what this really means is that the *Kindle* is improperly designed and the designers put the buttons and ports on adjacent sides of the device, not opposing sides.Other than the physical issues, everything else is amazing... sure, the carousel interface is a bit limiting and dumbed down, but this is a content consumption device, not an end-all/be-all device (although the Amazon Appstore has everything you need and more to make it a be-all device; don't buy into the hype that you need 300K+ apps at your disposal, because you don't, and whatever you do need is in the Amazon Appstore).Thus far, I'm a VERY happy and proud owner of a Kindle Fire HD, and I look forward to future iterations.PS - Unless you plan on sideloading a bunch of movies or have purchased a bunch of MP3s from Amazon that you absolutely NEED to have on your Kindle that you don't have on your phone, you don't need the 32GB version.  Rip, sideload, watch, delete, repeat = 16GB.  (Sure, 32GB is only $50 more, but that's 50 MP3s or 12 rentals)

Reviews.Title: First eReader
Reviews.Author: Kitch
Reviews.Content: As the title suggests, this is my first eReader. I've had some time to play around with the original Kindle Fire and the Samsung Galaxy 7" Tab, and so far I'm loving the Kindle Fire HD. For a while I did a side by side comparison with the Samsung tablet that I bought earlier this year. They both have their strong points, but I'm reviewing the Fire HD so that's where the focus will be, even if I use the Samsung as a reference point. So lets get started with what an eReader is all about! Reading books...Books - The Kindle Fire HD gives you three different backdrop colors to choose from when reading books. White, black, and sepia. I started off using white but then moved to sepia because it's just more comfortable. One of the biggest reasons I waited so long to jump on the eReader train was because I like paper books. I still do. However, I'm shocked at how quickly I've 'adjusted', if you can even call it that. Switching to the Fire HD was seamless because of the screen clarity and ease of use. The sepia choice makes it seem more like a book I suppose. You can also change font styles and sizes, but I haven't touched much of that. One thing I would like to mention here is that reading on this vs the Samsung only differs really in the margins. The Kindle gives you a larger area for text where as the Samsung cuts off a sentence or two. Minor difference, not much of a setback. Changing pages is easy, you tap the screen. Adding bookmarks to save your place is easy as well and I've only used it a few times when the book would close on it's own and start from the beginning. Not sure why it's done that, but it has happened. One fantastic feature that comes in handy is being able to highlight and then search keywords throughout the entire book. I'm currently reading a detective novel and it's extremely convenient to be able to highlight a name and see every time it's been used previously so I can refresh on a character's background from earlier in the story.Movies - The HD screen really shines here. Of course everything I use as far as movies is streamed through Amazon, so internet connection is a big player here as far as clarity. Whenever I have a good connection though, it's fantastic to see these movies and TV shows with such clarity. The color quality on the Fire is amazing as well. No complaints here. It's worth noting that the Fire HD has fantastic speakers as well. I was able to hear everything without having to blast the volume and it even has surround sound.Magazines - One of the main reasons I gave this item 5 stars was the convenience factor. I can't explain how great it is to carry a magazine, book, and movie with me all in one device. I honestly didn't think this would matter, since carrying a book or magazine with me or throwing it in the car isn't necessarily hard, it's just beyond convenient to have it on one device. I've seen reviews on magazines saying they prefer the paper to take in certain pictures and read the articles in larger print, but I can honestly say I prefer the Fire HD. I read Bike Magazine and they put out some phenomenal pictures and the HD screen does them justice. I'd even argue it's a better look than the paper version. It also gives you the option to read the articles in full page view, just like you're reading the magazine, or by double-clicking an article to read it in eReader mode where you can adjust font size, etc, etc.Apps - you're locked into Amazons app store, but they give you the majority of any app you'd need. This wasn't a big selling point for me. I've only really put Sudoku on mine. I have a smart phone for apps. Amazon does have a great selection and a majority of the top games and applications can be found on their market.Browser - It's nice that it comes with a browser, and can handle the desktop sized websites, but it seems like the Samsung I was using loaded websites faster than the HD. However -- the general interface of the Fire HD itself (scrolling through material & shopping in the market) went faster than the Samsung did because of how Amazon has kept everything very simple and you don't have the option to have a main screen to put apps and links on. I realize these are two different devices entirely, but just figured I'd mention it. Another thing I'll add to this small section is the added wifi system they put in the HD. I'm not the most technical person, but I can pick up on wifi networks from much farther distances than most other wireless devices I own. It's great for range, but speed stays the same.Screen Quality - As I've stated before, it's stunning! I've been able to watch tv and movies and enjoy the fantastic pictures in my magazines. It's also a perk to not strain your eyes as much as other back-lit eReaders caused me to do while testing them out in the store. I'd also like to mention that when they say they've added anti-glare technology to it, that's true to a certain extent. The black siding to the screen definitely shows a reflection, but it doesn't matter so much. The screen itself with your media on it has a slight glare that I had to look for to see. I haven't used it outside, and really have never seen the need to yet, but inside with lamps around it doesn't pick up any extra light to create a glare, which is another plus. I also like that this is a little wider. The original Fire's screen sort of bugged me for it's shape.Weight - Super light & thin. I hardly notice any weight at all when carrying it. It's also comfortable to hold when reading.Accessories - I bought the leather case that Amazon sells for it and it's very nice. I like the stand when watching movies and it gives me a warm fuzzy feeling to have something cover it, even if it doesn't protect from drops.Ports / Storage - So far I haven't filled up really any of the space on it. For what this device is used for, you really don't need a lot of space unless you're downloading movies to it, in which case you need to upgrade to the larger size as there are no SD card slots or any of that jazz. As far as I know it's still the same principal of only using the usb to charge and not transfer data as well, but I could be wrong on that so don't take my word for it. That's just something I heard about the older Fire.Battery - So far I've gotten a solid days use out of it no matter what I'm doing. Whether I'm watching video or just reading it usually gives me the same charge of roughly a day.All in all I'm really enjoying this product. I've had it for about two weeks now and am really getting into it. Amazon Prime is a nice perk at first, they give you a free 30 day trial with your purchase. I've taken advantage of the free 2 day shipping already, but I'm not sure I'll renew this service. I feel like buying the product should give you more time to use it or at least a discount on purchasing it. Streaming videos and movies has been great though. Compared with the Samsung, I'd say go with whatever fits your needs more. I would have chosen the Samsung if I wasn't JUST looking for an eReader. At first the HD screen and added speaker quality of the Fire were just a plus but now I can see how they'd be a definite selling point. The Samsung is great too because of it's expandable storage and access to anything and everything android. The biggest downside to the Fire is being locked into Amazon's market, which isn't a big enough issue to cause me to down-rate it at all. After all, it is Amazon's product. I hope this helps and if there are any questions please feel free to ask them and I'll try to respond quickly.EDIT : I forgot to mention it doesn't come with a wall charger, they've only included a usb cord. Pretty cheap, but not enough to make me hate the product seeing as I already had a wall to usb port on hand from my smart phone. So don't be surprised when you open the box and it's not there. Charging from a computer takes forever.

Reviews.Title: DEEPLY disappointed loyal Amazon customer!!!
Reviews.Author: Leona Hamrick
Reviews.Content: I pre-ordered the 32GB HD on September 24.  As promised it was delivered on October 25!  I was thrilled to get this shiny new toy on the day of release!  I had the previous Kindle Fire and was looking for the extra storage space for content.  The timing was perfect because I am going out of the country at the end of October for a month and looked forward to hours of entertainment from my 32 gigs of storage.  THEN things went bad.  I set it up and things seemed okay.  I downloaded all of my travel docs, many movies, and hours of Amazon prime purchased television.  IT WOULDN'T WORK!  I got continuous error messages that the screen was not responding and it needed to close. About half of my purchased books would not show up.  The internet was dreadfully slow.  It was a mess!  At 7am EST October 26 I called customer service for help.  After 3 phone calls and no real tech-support I said, "Send me a new one tomorrow.  I'm leaving to go out of the country and this purchase was specifically for my trip".  She ask me to try re-registering my device (as a last ditch effort).  I did, and as soon as it turned back on the screen froze up - again!Historically Amazon has kick-a*$ customer service so I didn't think this would be a problem.  Boy, was I wrong!  First, they had NO RECORD of my order - which was in my order history (per-ordered September 24).  Despite this, the lady on the phone assured me things would be okay and told me she would request overnight shipping so I would have a new unit on October 27 - given my circumstances of leaving the country.* Let me also add that I'm a prime member that spends WAY TO MUCH on Amazon.com weekly *I will also - in fairness - add that I was frustrated and not the nicest on the phone - I did just spend $250 on a device that wouldn't work!!!So, she said I would receive an email in a few hours about my new device shipment.  At 4:30pm EST, I received an email stating "We're sorry about your device, we will be shipping out your replacement, estimated delivery is October 30th"  SERIOUSLY?? 3-day shipping to a prime customer who can't get a BRAND NEW device to work the FIRST DAY it is released AND who is leaving to go out the country for a month?  UNACCEPTABLE!I obviously called and cancelled the new device.  I told customer service I would try one more time to "de-register" and re-register the device and hoped that worked but I was more disappointed in the customer service than ever! Let me say, I know this is a strongly negative review; you can check my history as a reviewer and see that normally this is not the case.  This review is intended about 40% for the quality of the new Kindle Fire HD 32G and about 60% for the pitiful customer service!  I am SHOCKED and deeply saddened by this customer service.  I have returned products in the past from Amazon and had outstanding customer service.I plan to work with the device tonight and hope that it works.  If not, I'm sad to say I'm done!  I'm the owner of an Ipad 3 and if my final efforts can't get the new HD Fire to work, it will be returned and I will be the owner of a new Ipad mini.To the Amazon CEO and BOD - you are potentially losing a very loyal customer that spends thousands on your website every year!  Shame on you!!  You should do better!

Reviews.Title: My first experiences with e-readers and Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: wooster
Reviews.Content: When I purchased my Kindle Fire HD in December 2012, it was my first experience with e-readers.....so this review might help other folks who are not familiar with e-reading and who might be hesitant about purchasing their first reader tablet.  Here's my e-reader experience so far:1.  Why did I purchase Kindle Fire HD in the first place?There are numerous e-readers out there to choose from. The ipad is supposed to be the best of the lot.  It sells for $600/$700/$800 or more, and is basically a mini personal computer that you can carry around with you.  Way too expensive for me, especially when all I really want to do is read books.The rest of the e-readers sell for anywhere from $50-$400.  The ones sold by Amazon (Kindle) and Barnes and Noble (Nook) are touted to be the best tablets for reading books because they are designed around the huge libraries of e-books that are available for download from those companies.  I suspect that Nook and all the others are very good products (judging from all the good reviews that I have read on them), but I chose Kindle because I'm already an Amazon.com customer, having ordered numerous items from them in the past.  Their prices are about as cheap as anyone around and they seem to stand behind what they sell....and they also deliver relatively fast.My first choice was Kindle Paperwhite.  Fairly inexpensive and it seemed to have all the features that I was looking for in good e-book reader.  When I told my wife about it, she asked if we'd be able to use it to listen to audio books during our drive to Florida this winter. Audiobooks are available for e-readers, but Paperwhite is not set up for them. So, from there I went looking for an e-reader with speakers.I settled on Kindle Fire HD because it's still relatively cheap (but more expensive than Paperwhite) and it's supposed to have the best tablet speakers around.  I ended up with Kindle Fire HD 7" (16GB).  I bought it from Amazon.com and paid $214 for it (without special offers).2.  With Special Offers or Without Special Offers:"Special Offers" is a way to get your Kindle product a little cheaper, but there are advertisements that are imbedded in the software when you purchase it.  Evidently, you can't get rid of these ads and they show-up on your reader somewhere.  There are a lot of complaints about them in some of the other reviews. Personally, I paid the extra $20 and had mine configured "Without Special Offers", so I don't get the ads and really can't say anything about them, one way or another.3.  Kindle Fire Leather Case:I ordered the leather case that is designed for Kindle Fire HD 7" ($45).  I figured that, sooner or later I am going to drop this thing...so I need a case.It fits like a glove, looks good and seems like it would absorb the shock if I dropped the device.  It does not interfere with the speaker sound or any of the Kindle's control buttons.There's a couple of other benefits to the leather case:The on/off button for this device is a little indent switch that is located on one edge of the Kindle.  It's one of those switches that you need to use your fingernail to operate.  It's not that easy to find and it's close to the speaker volume controls, so it's easy to get the buttons mixed up.  The leather case solves that problem.  It automatically turns the kindle on whenever you open the case (and the Kindle goes right back to the last book and page that you had been previously reading).  This is a great feature.  When you're done reading, just close the case and the Kindle automatically turns off.When I was checking out e-readers, in all the photos and videos of people using these devices, they all looked awkward.....like they weren't comfortable to hold...like your thumb and finger would get tired holding them by the edge.  The leather case solves that problem too.  When you open the flap, it's just like opening a book...so you hold the device just like you would a book.  It's very `comfortable'.3.  The PowerFast charging device:This is another accessory that I ordered with my Kindle.  The Kindle itself comes with a charging cord.  One end connects to the Kindle and the other end connects to a usb port on your computer.  This is supposed to give you a `slow' charge.  I've never charged my device that way, so I don't know the charge time.The PowerFast charger ($10) is a little `electric plug looking' device.  Plug your Kindle charging cord into your Kindle, plug the usb end of the cord into the PowerFast and then plug the PowerFast into an electrical outlet.  It charges the Kindle very fast.  I used my Kindle all day, plugged it into the charger and it recharged in less than an hour.4.  Setting-up the Kindle Fire HD:This device is very easy to set-up after delivery.First of all, you need to have access to wifi, which is some sort of wireless internet.  Don't ask me how it works....it's FM to me (f-ing magic).  I recently had high speed internet installed by my phone company and (going out the door) the tech told me that my new high speed modem was wifi enabled.  If the modem is turned on, wifi service is available throughout the house.  OK, if you say so......Out of the box, the easy to follow Kindle instructions tell you to fully charge your device (mine already was) and then go through a short series of steps to get you operational.  Things like naming your device and so on.  One of the steps has you check for wifi availability, and when I did, my phone company wifi came right up for me to select.  From there it sent me (via the wifi) to Amazon.com to sync my Kindle Fire HD to my Amazon.com page.  Once that was done, the set up was complete and I was ready to go.5.  Ordering and downloading books from Amazon.com:When you turn on a Kindle Fire HD, a series of icons appear across the face of the device.  The first icon is "shop".  Tap on it and you go directly to your Amazon.com page.  From there you can search for books through the Amazon search engine or select your wish lists and download books that you've previously placed there using your computer.Once you find a book you want to download, select it and the Kindle version (and price) will be displayed on your Kindle Fire HD.  Tap on "buy now" and you get the option to purchase the book right away or just download a free sample (a chapter or two) of the book to make sure you're going to like it before buying it.  This is a great feature of Amazon e-books.  I suspect that Barnes and Noble has the same feature. Anyway, once you decide that you want to buy the book, tap "purchase" and your book will be downloaded to your kindle in less than a minute and your credit card will be charged for the purchase.  If you make a mistake during the purchase procedure, you have the option to cancel your purchase if you desire.One final thing on downloading books:  you don't have to purchase books exclusively from Amazon.  You can get your e-books from a host of different on-line venders.  But, like I said, Amazon is very easy to deal with and they have a huge selection of books.  I doubt if I'll ever need to go somewhere else.6.  Setting up Kindle for reading a book:All of the e-readers that I reviewed stated that their product's reading parameters were easy to adjust (letter size, font and backlighting).  Kindle Fire HD's adjustments are definitely easy. They are available from a drop-down menu on the Kindle's `desktop'.  Just tap on the menu, then tap on the function that you want to adjust...and adjust it.  Very simple.7.  The Kindle Fire HD reading experience:Man, I really like this thing.  It has renewed my love of reading books.Once you get your reading parameters adjusted, tap on a downloaded book from the Kindle's desktop and the book comes right up.  You can turn pages by tapping or by swiping your finger.  There are functions available for bookmarking and for highlighting specific parts of a page.Don't be concerned about eye fatigue.  I have 65 year old eyes and have to use reading glasses.  I have read for hours and hours and have never had headaches or any kind of eye strain.I enjoy reading at night in bed most of all.  Turn off all the lights and it's pitch black (except for you and the Kindle).  I usually fall asleep reading, holding the Kindle on my chest.  The Kindle saves the page and turns itself off during inactivity, so it's not a problem.8.  Memory storage space:I asked a clerk at an electronics store (who actually owned a Kindle Paperwhite) how many books you could store on one of these devices.  He said over 1000 with his 2 GB Paperwhite.  The Kindle Fire HD come with 16 GB or 32 GB, so there's plenty of storage.The clerk said that books don't take up much memory at all.  What eats the memory is music and video downloads.9.  Cloud storage:Cloud storage is another one of those FM things.  You're allotted a certain amount of free storage space (outside your Kindle in cyberspace somewhere).  I believe that if you store a lot of high memory stuff there, you will reach your limit and get charged a fee.Every time you purchase a download from Amazon, a copy goes to the Kindle and a duplicate copy goes to Cloud.  If you delete your Kindle copy after you're done with it, the copy in Cloud storage remains.  This is a good feature, especially if you lose or damage your Kindle.  Just purchase a new Kindle and download your stuff from Cloud.  Nothing gets lost.They say that Cloud is good for storing high memory stuff (like music and videos) to free-up space on your Kindle.  There's even supposed to be an app that you can buy that makes it possible to copy your itunes music library to your Kindle (via Cloud).  Haven't tried any of these things (yet).10.  The Kindle Fire HD "desktop" icons:There is a row of icons across the desktop of the Kindle (books, apps, music, videos, audiobooks, games) that you can select by tapping.  Select one of them and you get a list of everything (in that category) that you have stored on your Kindle. You can also select Cloud for that category and see what's stored there.11.  APPSThere are numerous downloadable apps that are compatible with Kindle Fire HD. I bought an e-book that listed the most popular 150 of them.  They deal with a host of interesting topics.  So far, the only ones that I have purchased (cheap) are a battery meter and a volume controller.  Both of them downloaded seamlessly and work as advertised.12.  Problem Areas:I couldn't get the audiobook page to come up on the Kindle.  I tapped and tapped on the icon, but all I could get was a grey blank page.  Finally I called the Kindle help number from the Amazon web page and got a live technician in about a minute.  He walked me through the problem and it was fixed in about 30 seconds (had to reset something in the Kindle's settings).Another time I ordered an audiobook from Amazon using my computer.  The book was supposed to be sent directly to the Kindle, but it never showed up.  Again I called the tech and the problem was quickly fixed.  You have to tap on the Kindle's sync icon in order to download stuff ordered from your computer.  I tapped on sync and the audiobook immediately started downloading.Bottom line:  if you run into trouble with anything, you can quickly contact a live technician to resolve your problem.13.  Audiobooks:My wife and I tried to listen to an audiobook in our car but it wasn't the  good experience that we had hoped for.  Kindle Fire HD's speakers are excellent in the quiet of your home,  but there's not enough to them....to overcome road noise when driving (unless you have a super quiet car).  So, for road trips we're going back to audio cds.Like I said, the speakers are great for audiobooks at home or on the patio (or whatever).  Amazon offers an audiobook feature (at additional expense) that allows you to read your e-book while it's being read to you.  You kinda follow along with the audiobook.  My wife said `that's stupid .... either you read the book or you listen to it'.  I tried it anyway, and it turned out to be a pretty neat feature after all.  Really enhances the reading experience.  It's something you have to try for yourself to understand.14.  Bottom Line:If I lost (or broke) my Kindle Fire HD, would I replace it?  Answer: YES (immediately).  Like I said earlier, I really love this device.  I used to read a book every now and then.  Now, I'm reading every chance I get.  And I'm taking the Kindle with me, everyplace I go (so I probably WILL lose it...lol).I give 5 ½  stars to the e-reading experience (in general) and 5 ½ stars to Kindle Fire HD for taking me there.Hope this long winded review helps some other `e-novice' make up their mind about  Kindle Fire HD.

Reviews.Title: No Plug?
Reviews.Author: Peter Bradley
Reviews.Content: I like this product and using it with Amazon Prime.However there are a few fatal flaws that should be shared upfront:1. No Plug - Who would sell a rechargeable electronic product that doesn't include a power cord?  You have to buy the wall plug separately for another $10 to $20 bucks!  Shame on them.2. Ads?- What? I paid full price for this product, why am I being inundated with Ads and Paid Suggestions for other products?I feel deceived; Amazon should have called this Product Kindle Fire HD with Ads like they do with their other readers! My toddler is frustrated with pressing icons which look like apps but are actually ads to purchase other products.Since this is my device and not Amazon's I should have a way of turning off ads and "Suggestions" without having to pay for the privilege.They should spell out upfront that this is an Ad supported product.3. No YouTube or YouTube App?  - Why can't I install the YouTube App?  It's only the most popular video service on the web.

Reviews.Title: I love this way more than I thought I would.
Reviews.Author: SchnauzerFace
Reviews.Content: I have never owned a tablet, and I long questioned their place in my technology family tree. With a smartphone, a laptop, a desktop, and big-screen TV that can stream YouTube, Netflix, and Amazon Prime, I questioned whether the gap between iPhone and laptop really needed to be filled. That was until a tabletop miniature game I play (Warmachine & Hordes) announced an app that would make the game mechanics more efficient, so that piqued my interest a bit. I started researching the Kindle and, unexpectedly, I found myself really wanting the 7-inch tablet.I am the luckiest guy around -- my wife got this for me for my birthday. And I am so glad she did, as this is an absolutely awesome entertainment device. After using it for a long weekend, I've come to one conclusion: the Kindle HD isn't perfect for everyone, but it's absolutely perfect for me.SCREEN: The HD display is incredible. The screen is sharp, bright, saturated and beautiful. Glare is definitely at a minimum, and I've been able to enjoy it in reasonably bright rooms. The touch-screen is fairly responsive, and it's made gaming (Temple Run, Angry Birds, etc) even more fun than on a smartphone.INTERFACE: At first glance, the OS will seem minimalist at best and completely lacking at worst. There's no desktop to speak of. No folders, no menus, no icons (aside from the "carousel," which is basically a list of recently opened media). There's a toolbar at the top that will point you toward your books, music, movies, etc. But that's it. This was a little jarring to me at first. I'm used to a traditional operating system. But I soon realized that this interface makes sense. The Kindle is all about delivering and consuming media content. And, as such, the Kindle's OS is designed to do one thing and one thing only -- direct the user to the Amazon marketplace. And I'm OK with that.I know some people have complained that the Kindle is constantly trying to sell you something. But I don't get the problem. This was never designed to be an all-comers workhorse device. You're not going to use the Fire HD to tap out a report or prepare a PowerPoint. You're not going to do intensive video editing or debug a website. That's why, after all, we have our laptops and desktops, right? The Kindle HD is designed for entertainment. And Amazon has the best selection of movies, TV, books, magazines, music, games, etc. If I was using an iPad, I'd probably always point it toward the Amazon store, anyway, so this just cuts out the middleman. I haven't found myself lamenting the lack of X or Y or Z. I love what the Kindle comes with, and, more importantly, I love with what the Kindle DOESN'T come with. Again, this is an entertainment device. I have no plans to sync my work contacts with my Kindle. I will never set up my work e-mail on my Kindle. I will never create a presentation on my Kindle. This tablet is for fun, and that's it.SPEAKERS: I did not expect this. The speakers are way better than they have any right to be on a $200 tablet. They drive well through my nice headphones, too. The screen is awesome, so watching content is great. But these speakers make listening to content great, too. It's too big to replace an iPod, but it's really not meant to.STORAGE: I got the 16GB version, and that will be plenty for me. I don't plan to store HD movies on my device, as the Amazon Cloud, iTunes Cloud, Netflix Cloud, Whatever Cloud is all I need. If you do a lot of traveling (and perhaps would like to store a movie on the device for plane rides and stuff like that), a bigger hard drive might make sense. But, in 2012, we're all very rarely outside of WiFi access. Whether it's at home or Starbucks or work or wherever, you're going to be able to stream things most of the time. And, if not, you can still fit a few HD movies on here, or tons and tons and tons of books that will certainly tide you over until you're back to a WiFi area.BATTERY: Much better battery life than I expected. Amazon said, I believe, 11 hours of video, web, reading, etc. I was initially skeptical, but I think they're pretty much right on the money with that. When my Kindle arrived, it was maybe 1/3 charged. I still managed to get about 3-4 hours of use in before I had to charge it. That's amazing.Please note, the Kindle doesn't come with an outlet adapter (just the USB cable). However, there are a million adapters out there that will turn a USB cable into a wall charger. You can use the outlet portion of an old Kindle charger, or perhaps your cell phone charger will fit. My Samsung Galaxy SIII wall charger works great. If you don't have an outlet adapter, you can still charge it through a computer. It's a little slower, but it still works.SPEED: Here's my first qualm. Some apps are a little sluggish. I've found Netflix isn't as responsive as my phone, for example. Sometimes it takes 3-5 seconds for an app to open. It's annoying, but it's truly a 2012/ADD/impatient/technogluttony annoyance. I have to remind myself that waiting, literally, 5 seconds for Netflix to load -- where I have access to thousands upon thousands of movies and TV shows that will stream immediately -- is really petty, and any frustration is a bit narcissistic. Honestly, my time isn't so valuable that I can't wait a couple seconds for an app to load. I can be patient, sit back and wait a few seconds for a world of media to be delivered to my fingertips.PRIME: I believe Jeff Bezos described Amazon Prime as the greatest deal in the history of shopping. I have to say, he's right. My free month of Prime will soon turn into a full year of Prime, and it'll be the best $79 I spend in the next 12 months. In addition to free 2-day shipping, access to Amazon Prime's streaming videos is a steal at that price. However, I don't think it's as comprehensive or broad as Netflix's library, though it's still decent (and growing). In all honesty, neither Prime nor Netflix have nearly enough content to satisfy the vast majority of customers, but I trust it's only going to get better from here. But that free 2-day shipping ... now that's awesome.WIRELESS: It's fast. Really fast. I streamed HD movies and TV shows all weekend and didn't need any buffering. I know there are two antennae on the Fire, and I don't know all the technology behind it. But, whatever they did worked. I was streaming better on my Kindle than I usually do on my laptop. So I'm happy.READING: I have my first-gen Kindle for reading, and I love it. The e-ink cannot hold a candle to the LCD screen in (and on) my eyes. I like to read for long stretches, and the e-ink is just so much gentler. I'll keep my e-ink for books, but magazines and (finally!!) graphic novels/comic books are where the Fire HD wins out. I am extremely excited for the graphic novel selection to grow, though it does have a fair share of favorites (Watchmen, Batman: Year One, The Dark Knight Returns, etc). As an added bonus, I'll be doing the environment a favor by switching magazine subscriptions to a digital delivery. It seems some magazines (though not all) will be a good deal cheaper on the Fire than through the mail. Again, an added bonus.A FEW OTHER THINGS: My last few notes are really minor quibbles. The volume and power buttons are kind of hard to find just by touch --  raised buttons that aren't so flush with the body might make things easier. The Fire is a little bit heavier than I expected, though it's not uncomfortably heavy. The app store is limited compared to the Android and Apple marketplaces, but I know everything on there will work properly on the Fire. I guess Amazon doesn't support Flash anymore, so add this to the list of basically every major portable device (iPhone, iPad, Android 4.1 and later phones) that can't utilize Flash.In the end, I love my Fire. If you're looking for a media-delivery device, I have to recommend this tablet. I didn't realize it, but there is a gap that needs filling between the phone and the laptop. And a 7-inch Amazon tablet fills that void perfectly.

Reviews.Title: Take if from an Apple fan, the KINDLE FIRE HD ROCKS!
Reviews.Author: MM "Multimedia Minded"
Reviews.Content: As a long-time Apple fan and former employee, I must tell you that I was pleasantly surprised by how sophisticated the KINDLE Fire HD is in terms of intuitive features and SUPERIOR WEB BROWSING AND VIDEO LOADING!  -- SILK is definitely SMOOTH, my friends.Since I purchased the KINDLE to keep up with constantly evolving multimedia techniques, I was initially disappointed to learn that Silk does not support FLASH (in these newer units at least). - But not to worry, there's an app for that!Being a creative writer and researcher as well, I have to say how impressed I am with Silk's user interface and organizational system. Frankly it blows Safari away. Now it may take a minute to get used to, since it is so unique, but once you do you will be amazed by the efficiency of its set up.  And you'll wonder why no one thought of it sooner.  Of course, the fact that TubeMate can download YouTube clips at a blazing speed helps tremendously for someone like moi, because it allows me to save videos for future viewing, even when there's no WiFi connection in sight.Oh, and while on the topic of WiFi - OMG!  Take it from someone who doesn't say OMG, it is awesome.By that I mean video streaming is consistently much quicker and much MUCH more stable than any Apple smart product I've every owned. - Including the newly released ones that I've played with.So KUDOS to Amazon, they knocked it out of the park with the KINDLE Fire HD, particularly when you consider the price and crystal clear no glare HD screen resolution.  Very cool.Although I've been an avid Amazon customer for many years, I have rarely taken the time out of my busy life to write a review, but I was inspired by the innovation, elegance, and overall quality of this product.  And I think you will be too.

Reviews.Title: First impression: disapointment, 3 months later: acceptance
Reviews.Author: L. B.
Reviews.Content: First of all, I apologize for any typos in this review. My new kindle fire HD does not have a functioning autocorrect feature in the silk browser.  It works in other parts of the device, but not with silk.  I am hoping that this will be fixed with an update.One of the main reasons I upgraded from the regular kindle fire (which I love, love, love) is that this came with a camera.  Does it have any apps to use the camera? Nope. Just Skype. I thought I could use it like a webcam and take some still shots or video, but apparently not.Amazon decided to can the favorites shelf at the bottom of the screen (in portrait mode, even though it is shown in the above product photos) and replace it with ads and other recommended items.  I can call up my favorites by pressing an icon, but what's the point? I might as well search through the carousel.Maybe this isn't a big deal, but I'm very disapointed that the facebook app is gone.  I know I can open it in my browser, but I liked having it accessible at the touch of a button.  They also did away with youtube.The email app is a disappointment, too. On the original fire, my emails were optimized to be viewed on one screen.  Now I have to zoom out and scroll around to read an email.  They also move the delete button and you can't finger swipe to move to the next message. When I use my fire primarily for reading, facebook, and email and Amazon has only nailed one of these features; what am I supposed to think?Another thing: I like to touch the power button to check the time on the lock screen.  Now, it only shows advertisements.  Whatever. I hate the ads. But could they at least put something helpful on that screen like a clock??Also, there is no indicator light to tell me when this is finished charging.  I don't want to leave it plugged in longer than necessary, but I now have to power it on, open the device settings and see if it is done charging.  Fail!My husband was gracious enough to let me take the upgraded kindle fire HD and he has my original fire.  I really,truly hope that Amazon can fix some of the glaring problems with this new model, or I will have to return this and downgrade.Update 9/15:I just spent 45 minutes on the phone with Amazon.  While their customer service representative was very kind and helpful, only one of my problems was resolved.  There is a facebook app in the app store, you just have to scroll WAY down to find it.Autocorrect has been disabled in the silk browser.  This is absolutely ludicrous! The autocorrect feature actually works very well: everywhere except THE INTERNET!If you pay $15 to disable the ads, then you get to see time on your home/locked screen.  Would it be too much trouble to add that on there?  Even for those of us stuck looking at ads?As of right now, they will not be giving us the option to fix the favorites at the bottom of the screen.The customer service rep did say that he would forward my feedback to Amazon.  I hope they take note of these things.  I really want to love this thing as much as/more than my original fire.Update 9/18:The camera actually works with the facebook app. This is a nice bonus but I'm disappointed that Amazon isn't promoting.I am still annoyed to the point of being angry that autocorrect won't work in Silk. I have contacted Amazon for assistance with this matter, but they haven't received enough feedback that this is a problem for others.  Please let them know if this bothers you.I purchased the Poetic hardback case for the Fire HD and the cover powers my device on when I open it and off when I close it.  This makes the button placement less of a problem.Come on, already, Amazon! Start making some changes so I can like this thing!Update 12/7:This week's update finally fixed autocorrect in Silk!I have been given the option to turn off recommendations at the bottom of the screen, but this doesn't bring my favorites up. I still wish I could have them fixed at the bottom.There's.still no clock on the home screen, but I have taken advantage of at least $15 worth of special offers since I bought this, so I consider that a win.Many of my gripes have not been resolved, but I have  gotten used to the way this fire works and I'm less bothered  by it .

Reviews.Title: A good choice IF you are a part of Amazon's ecosystem
Reviews.Author: Alexi Rain
Reviews.Content: About me:I have a Macbook pro running Mac os and win 7A first gen  Xoom tablet which I still sorta love due to the internal and sd card storage space.An Iphone 4.First Gen. NookWhy I chose the Kindle Fire HD:1.  Storage, storage! I wanted a small tablet I could travel with that would keep a big chunk of my movies and books stored, so I wouldn't need to worry about wifi.  This shouldn't be as big of a problem as it is, but between flights and family without wifi, it's turned into an issue for me.2.  Amazon ecosystem.
