I buy lots of video from Amazon that I stream on a rokyu.  I love that I can download those to keep on my FireHD for offline viewing when I travel.  I love how easy it is to access my wishlist and to buy books and videos.  I love that I can easily stream Prime videos. The automatic cloud storage and streaming of Amazon content is a nice extra, too.3.  Books.  I have a Prime Membership, and all those free books listed with Prime were taunting me.  There's no getting them unless they're downloaded with an actual Kindle.  There is also a lending program which is a nice bonus.4.  The new whispersync.  I'm an Audible addict, and I thought that was a pretty cool concept.  I haven't tried it out yet, but hey, it's there and waiting for me.5.  It has all the necessary video apps/abilities:  Hulu, Netflix, HBOgo, and of course, Amazon.So far I'm glad I got the FireHD.  It turns out that Amazon Instant Videos take up less space than I'd anticipated.  So far, I've been able to fit 57 episodes of various TV shows, one movie, and 8 books onto 14 gigs of storage.  Not bad at all.What IS bad is that the video portion of my downloads can't be backed up.  There doesn't seem to be a way to access where they're stored on the Kindle so that I can move them onto my storage drive. This means that I'll have to delete, download other videos, delete, and redownload if I want to switch my stored videos around. This is wasting my bandwidth and time and was almost a deal breaker.There is a bit of lag online, but nothing too annoying.  Websites come up quickly, and the wifi is quick and stable during downloads.I'm  sick to bloody death of the Ad.  Not ads, *AD*.  I honestly wouldn't mind seeing deals and bargains when I come out of sleep mode,  but for the love of commerce, show me something besides that bleepin' Discover ad!The screen is very nice, but not as beautiful as people are saying.  Or maybe I was just expecting too much.  Detail in dark scenes can be difficult to see, and the glare is pretty awful, though better than on my Xoom.The battery life is horrifically bad.  Seriously.  In the last 20 minutes, 5% has been sucked away just sitting and having the device storage space checked.  One hour of video uses about 30%. Using pretty much any function will kill it fast.  However, the battery doesn't drain if left alone over night.So, to sum it up, if you are part of Amazon's ecosystem, I see the FireHD as the best choice available. It's a nice little tablet with decent storage and good video capability.  However, if I wasn't a Prime member and if I didn't purchase Amazon's instant videos, I would choose something else.**Update 11-6-12**After using the Kindle Fire HD for awhile, I would give it 3.5 stars if I could. The things I love about it have remained great, but some problems have come up.1.  Odor.  When the device heats up, there is a strong outgassing odor.  This is a separate issue from Amazon's "leather" case, which I had to remove due to fumes. The device is much, much worse than my Xoom and its case ever were.  I'm wondering if it's a byproduct of the antiglare lamination on the screen?  Granted, I'm sensitive to odors, but many people are, and this is something to consider.  13 days of use, and the smell is still very bad.2.  Silk browser.  I finally see what people are complaining about on the lag.  Some websites are fine, but some aren't.  It seems to depend on the types of ads used on the site.  For instance, the Dead Island wiki is completely unbrowsable on Silk.  I went over to XDA Developers and got Dolphin and Flash links that work wonderfully on the Kindle Fire HD. There is still a bit of lag on heavily monetized sites, but they can definitely be browsed without too much trouble.  However, I shouldn't have to waste my time hunting down a link to make my device work online. Amazon should give us a browser that works and/or provide Dolphin for download in their app store.  They have chosen to do neither.3. Device lag. Occasionally the device will freeze up for a second or two when browsing libraries, favorites, apps, etc.4.  The sound stops working after being disconnected from HDMI output to T.V.  Turning it off and on again gets the sound working.  This is a minor annoyance, but it's adding to a growing list.5. Extreme heat.  The Kindle Fire HD gets very hot during video applications.  Since 70% of the reason I bought it was so I could conveniently take my Amazon video library with me, this is a concern.At this point, I'm still glad I purchased the Fire HD, but just barely.  I buy so many instant videos through Amazon that it really is the best option for me.  I just wish the odor, heating, and lag hadn't become such an issue.****Update 12-5-12...Downgraded my review to 3 stars. It should probably be more like 2.5.****I seem to be in a cycle of returns on my Kindle Fire HD.  Mine has the backlight bleed issue which somehow only became obvious when I downloaded the Dark Knight app. The issue was camouflaged partly because Amazon highlights the top edge of the screen and put our kindle info across where the problem usually is.The bleed became glaring when I got my first game app, and it had lots of full screen black.Amazon CS was great as usual, and they sent me a new Kindle.  The new one also has a backlight bleed issue and additionally drops wifi. In testing the new Fire HD, it dropped a streaming movie constantly.  So, I put both units on my lap, and streamed with my old Fire HD with no issues.  I watched the wifi icon on my new device (not streaming it, just watching the wifi connection), and it dropped wifi about 6xs within 5 mins or so. I'll be contacting Amazon for yet another return, but I'm feeling dubious.On another note, Dolphin has proven unstable over time.  I've switched to Opera mobile which is generally more stable but not perfect or my first choice for a browser, if all were working equally well.  The quest to find a reliable browser has become hugely annoying.So.  I hate the glitches. I hate not having a stable browser. I hate the light bleed. I hate the heat.  I hate the odor issue which by now is much better, but still slightly present when the unit heats up.I also hate that I've become so attached to this darn thing. The size, weight, and storage space are awesome.  Still, if I didn't have such an extensive Amazon video library, I would have returned it and good riddance.

Reviews.Title: Device 5 OS 1
Reviews.Author: Sus
Reviews.Content: I couldnt wait to upgrade to the fire HD. The device was impressive: quality screen, fast wifi, HMDI port...The main problem is the lack of customization. The navigation bar cannot be edited and it now spans two screens instead of the one on the kindle fire.When you turn the device on you get movie ads. super annoying.When you are in your carousel and hover over a book, you see ads (customers also bought) and when you hover over a website you get (trending now). I thought these would be ok but they are very intrusive. they move and seriously clutter the screen in portrait mode. The kindle fire OS was so clean and organzied now it is cluttered and ugly. Tech support says there is no way to turn these off so reluctantly I am returning this which is sad because the hardware is amazing!Why cant they let us pay to turn these off? I dont mind ads when i am shopping but not when I am just browsing my own device.The fire was supposed to be a multimedia device not a cluttered ad. Worse than watching tv with commercials. Booo amazon. I have been a kindle fan for years but I am guessing I will never buy one again with this new focus.

Reviews.Title: fire is great...ads not so much!!!
Reviews.Author: dogralph
Reviews.Content: Let me just say that I love my new kindle fire hd.  The reason I am only going to give it 1 star is because (unless there is a way to turn it off WITHOUT having to spend extra money) the ads are VERY ANNOYING!!!! I will be reading my book and the screen will lock so that it can show me a new ad!  Not cool.  I don't mind the ads being my lock screen that is okay but when I am in the middle of working an app or reading my book....NO WAY.  Seriously, I don't want to have to pay an extra $15 to turn off ads when I could spend that money on a new book.  They don't tell you are having to pay EXTRA to turn off the ads or that you will be LOCKED out so it can show you a new ad!I have a kindle fire and loved it, so thought the HD would be better and for the most part it is.  But being locked out in the middle of reading my book to view a new ad almost makes me want to take it back to the store.  So just know that ADS are out there and annoying.

Reviews.Title: Entertainment GOLD!
Reviews.Author: Tanner
Reviews.Content: I bought the original Kindle Fire and was honestly disappointed.  I was expected an iPad type experience and I was left wanting more.  With all the new features and buzz surrounding the new Kindle Fire HD, I decided to give it one more try and I am so glad that I did.  If you're looking for an entertainment device this is it, period.  At $200 the price can't be beat and the media available for PRIME users is unreal.  The sound is great, the HD screen is great, the interface is great.  I love my KF HD, and now use it more than my iPad 3.

Reviews.Title: Great product - BEATS competition in many areas
Reviews.Author: Roop
Reviews.Content: This is a great great product. Reasons why this is better than the competition out there:1. Screen: The screen is absolutely mind blowing. You don't realize how good it is till you actually end up using it. If you look around, the 'HD' screen is pretty much the best there is in the 7 inch market.2. Content: People talk about the App Store not having enough applications - but 99% of the apps you use on your iPad or any other device are actually available in the App store. And I don't think Google (and even Apple) can match the digital content (videos, tv shows) that Amazon has for the price.3. Prime content and Amazon Instant Video: This is a killer feature. Amazon's ecosystem is brillianty supported by this device, and if you are a prime member, there is absolutely no other place you want to look at. The Kindle Fire HD is exactly what you want.4. Speakers: I almost forgot about probably the best feature in this device. The speakers are GREAT. I have a friend with a Nexus 7 and I have also owned an iPad, and trust me, its ridiculous how good these speakers are. I was watching a TV show in HD lying down, and the surround sound was so great, I felt like the sound was coming from different areas in the room. Awesome feature, makes for a great experience.The only thing that needs improving is the web browser, it is a little buggy, but you mostly do not notice it.If you are in the market for an affordable 7 inch tablet, you need to seriously think about getting this. The nexus is decent too, but especially with Prime membership and Amazon's digital content, this is the best tablet in the market.

Reviews.Title: Ipad killer
Reviews.Author: George Davis
Reviews.Content: Was kind of unsure on whether to get this or the larger version for my 10 yr old for Christmas. I got this in and wanted to set it up and test before wrapping it. It is great! everything i had hoped for , great little tablet at a great price.

Reviews.Title: Love Love Love
Reviews.Author: Kimberly Luchini
Reviews.Content: My first E-Reader was the Barnes and Noble Nook.  I found shopping for new titles on the Barnes and Noble website laborious so I ended up browsing on Amazon and then buying my e-books from Barnes and Noble.  After a year and half or so the Nook stopped working and I was told I had to buy the new one, because my old one couldn't be repaired.  So I abandoned my Nook and went with the entry level Kindle.  I was sold from the start.  Since then I have bought several of the first generation as gifts because once you can carry all of your books with you in one small device, a heavy book is a nuisance.  And even sceptics have loved the Kindle and found the benefit once they started using it.I share my Kindle with a friend because we read some of the same books so there are 2 Kindles on the one account.  What many of the reviewers of the E-Readers don't consider is that shopping for books and book recommendations are a big part of the E-Reader experience.  Barnes and Noble kept recommending romance novels to me and I never bought a romance novel for my Nook.  Amazon's recommendations are targeted based on my earlier purchases.I upgraded to the Kindle Fire HD, because it is reasonably priced, has beautiful color, a great screen resolution, and replaces my Ipad generation 1.  The Ipad was just too slow for browsing the internet and the new Ipad was more than I wanted to spend.  I carry my new Kindle in my purse and use the apps, the reader, and the internet easily.I am showing friends and family the benefit of the upgraded Kindle and think they will want one for Christmas. This device does everything easily and is simple to use.  Thank you Amazon!

Reviews.Title: Now this is a Mini Tablet !
Reviews.Author: RC
Reviews.Content: Wow! As good as the original Fire was for the money, this is an absolute steal! My favorite features are it's HD Screen and audio. Can't beat it for the price. highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: First Kindle
Reviews.Author: Albert D. Campbell
Reviews.Content: I've been on my first Kindle device for 8 hrs. now, when I ordered it I was afraid of the ads people were mentioning in the one star reviews, but you know what? The ads are not a problem, and the Kindle is responsive and smooth. I don't know how any one is giving a review lower than a 3 star. So it does what it's adverised to do it does it well, It does it even better than I expected, my 23 yr. old son was impressed, I gave it a 5 star.

Reviews.Title: Loving my Kindle Fire!
Reviews.Author: Kathryn Magendie
Reviews.Content: I already owned the "regular Kindle" that I used to read books, and to upload my own novel drafts onto to read for editing, which by the way, for you authors/writers out there, is a wonderful way to edit your draft works. I didn't want to spend the money on an iPad, and really, thought the iPad would be more than I needed. The Kindle Fire HD 7" seemed the perfect choice for me and I haven't been disappointed.The graphics are beautiful, more than I thought they'd be, and I can't wait to upload photos to it. I've yet to explore all the things my Kindle Fire can do, so I'm excited to see what else I'll discover.The sound quality is also better than I would have imagined, nice and clear and enough volume.It's way faster than I imagined, and in fact, I haven't had any delays or dragging at all. Maybe as I upload things it'll slow up, but for now, it's quite fast.I uploaded my first and only game (I'm not a gamer), Solitaire, and of course it was lighting fast to order and upload -- and the game worked perfectly.As with my former "regular kindle" I am able to comfortably read books - I didn't think I'd like the "glossy" screen when reading as much as I LOVE the "regular screen on the regular kindle" but I still am able to get into the novels/short story collections I read, though, in some ways I still like the "book look" of the "regular kindle;" yet, still, an enjoyable read.Also with the Kindle Fire HD, I am able to upload my draft novels and read them for edits, but! even better, I was able to listen to my book! The computer voice was obviously a computer voice; however, I was quite surprised at how "normal" she sounded, enough that I could listen to my entire novel while taking notes on rough patches and mistakes -- just one more layer of editing for my drafts. I even came to be fond of that voice, laughing! As well, I am going to record myself reading and upload that to my kindle (or maybe I can record right on the Kindle - I'll explore that capability).I like how the KF alerts me when I have a notification.This device will be perfect for traveling, which I do fairly often. I can use Kindle Fire to check email, social networking, play some solitaire, I could watch a movie, read books, and, I can listen or read my novel drafts--so there is no reason to take a computer when I travel, especially by airplane, as I can easily slip my Kindle Fire into my purse or bag and away I go!It was super easy to set up.As an author and a reader, the idea of ebooks was scary at first, but now I can't imagine my reading or my "author world" without them! I can upload books in mere seconds onto my Kindle and Kindle Fire, and my own books can be enjoyed by people from just about anywhere! How cool is that? Amazon has saved many an author from oblivion as we try to be noticed in a big ole sea of authors wanting space in bookstores. When I do upload a book, I can retrieve it on either Kindle I own, which is a plus, as well.For the price, I am very pleased and would recommend this product to anyone, and I have.There is one wrinkle I am having and that is with Facebook -- I can't figure out if it's something I'm doing or something with the Kindle Fire, but Facebook doesn't always work properly -- I'll click on an update and it takes me to a completely different screen--the same incorrect screen over and over. The screen will jump to somewhere completely different from where I clicked. So my Facebook experience is a little frustrating - though the graphics are so beautiful, I love looking at photos there. If I figure out it is something I'm doing, I'll report back (I will look at reviews and see if anyone else is having this problem).This is a wonderful little device and a great alternative to someone who does not want to own an iPad, for whatever reason, but still wants the experience of a tablet.

Reviews.Title: Small but awesome
Reviews.Author: Alexander the Weak
Reviews.Content: I love this product, it is kind of small but still it is a great tablet that is very versatile. If you like books, games, music, easy amazon shopping, and email/calendar than I would recommend this product to you.FYI I have used the ipad and actually like the kindle fire better except it is smaller, so if size is the most important attribute I would recommend the ipad but if you just want a solid, versatile tablet than I would recommend the kindle fire hd.

Reviews.Title: This Kindle's on Fire!
Reviews.Author: Briana Myricks "Book nerd for life!"
Reviews.Content: I've now had my Kindle Fire HD for a few weeks and feel it's now time to write a review. I won't write a novel because I'm sure you've read enough of those on here already, and to leave you time to read real novels on your Kindle!I bought the 1st generation iPad a few months after it came out, and just sold it in September. It was collecting dust after I got a new laptop. I enjoyed it moderately while we had it, but my husband enjoyed it a lot more. It was really about consumption, which is great, but it came at a heavy price tag of $499.I bought my Kindle Fire HD at my local Best Buy. I've been a long time Amazon user, and would've ordered it online, but I have a problem with "I want something and I want it now". So even with Amazon's lightening fast shipping, I couldn't wait.APPS: I was impressed by he amount of apps available, which was one of the things I was afraid of. But all the apps I used on my iPad are available on my Kindle. The apps I use are Kindle (of course), Amazon (duh), Evernote, Spotify, Songza, Dropbox, Twitter, Facebook, HBO Go. So the fact that all of these were available: score!SCREEN: So clear, so crisp, and just the right size! Watching movies on the iPad is great...if you have a stand. Watching movies or TV shows on the Kindle is even better.SOUND: Dolby? Yes! Beautiful, crisp, no distortion, the right amount of volume.AMAZON IN MY HAND: I love the fact that Amazon is right there in my hands. I read a lot so having the store right there is perfect, especially when I can buy with 1 click, and borrow books. Getting the Kindle Fire HD also encouraged me to get an Audible account. I use WhisperSync and read along while listening to the audio book. Love it! (Forgot to mention I had the Kindle Keyboard, but my mom loved it so much, she sort of, took it, which is why I was looking at the Fire HD in the first place).BATTERY LIFE: :( Disappointed! Coming from the iPad and the Kindle Keyboard, I'm disappointed that I have to charge my Kindle basically every night. Standby = dead battery at work when you want to listen to an audio book. Amazon says it lasts 11 hours. No way no how. I read somewhere else between 7-9 hours. That's a better average. Wish it lasted longer, ESPECIALLY since you can't simultaneously charge and do things on your Kindle. That's where I docked the star.I also hate that it just came with a USB cord, and needs it's own "special charger" if you want to plug it in to the wall. Plugging it in to your computer = charging for half a day. Seriously. Hate that. So I grabbed one of my old Android charger bases and plug the USB cord in there to charge. It gets the job done, but again, hate that you can't simultaneously charge & read.WEB: The web experience rocks for a tablet, and is pretty similar to iPad browsing (at least to me).GAMES: Don't play them so I'm no help in the arena.MOVIES/TV SHOWS: See SCREEN.PRICE: Lots of bang for your buck. iPad mini for $329? Yeah right. Treat yourself to this baby and you'll love it and won't want to put it down. But you'll have to in order to charge it.Hopefully this was a Cliff Notes version, or at least a novella as opposed to a novel. Treat yourself, or someone else, to it for Christmas! For the book lover (or movie lover) in your life.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 7": a nearly perfect companion, anytime and anywhere!
Reviews.Author: Mike Powers "mkp51"
Reviews.Content: Two years ago, when I purchased my Kindle Keyboard 3G, Free 3G + Wi-Fi, 6" E Ink Display ebook reader, I had no idea what a positive impact that device would have on my reading habits. (I am, by all accounts, a voracious reader, averaging nearly 20,000 pages a year for the past five years.)  In addition to reading, however, I spend a great deal of time watching movies, browsing the web, and playing computer games. Unfortunately,I can't take my ancient and venerable laptop everywhere, and my Kindle Keyboard isn't capable of playing the latest games or fully browsing the web.I discovered that I needed a new electronic companion that would completely meet my growing needs.The solution to my dilemma: my brand new Kindle Fire HD 7", Dolby Audio, Dual-Band Wi-Fi, 16 GB (Fire HD7)  tablet/ebook reader. It's about as perfect an electronic companion as I could ask for.  It's an ebook reader, a hi-definition video player, superb web browser, and game player. All with stunningly brilliant 1200-by-800 video resolution, superb Dolby Surround audio, the quickest Wi-fi I have ever seen in any device, and a list of features so long it's impossible to name `em all here...In this review, I'll focus on the three qualities of the Fire HD7 that I find most important: ease of use, ability to meet my high expectations,  and versatility and convenience.EASE OF USE:  Like all devices in the Kindle family, the Fire HD7 of a very convenient size (7.6" tall x 5.4" wide x 0.4" thick) and weight (13.9 ounces). This makes it easy for me to take along nearly everywhere. Also like the Fire HD7's older cousins, this device's design is simple and sleek. The front has a 7" display screen made with Gorilla glass and a bezel wide enough to allow me to hold the device comfortably without getting my fingers on the display area. The back is made of a black, fingerprint resistant, high-impact plastic that feels good in my the hands. On the back are located a pair of stereo speakers that bring the Fire HD7's Dolby Surround audio to life. Along the top edge are the on/off switch and volume rocker, which do feel a bit too small for comfort.Amazon prides itself on providing its customers with devices that are ready to go right out of the box. My Fire HD7  was no exception. After charging the internal lithium-ion battery for an hour or so, I turned the device on. I was immediately stunned by what I saw: the clearest, sharpest, most vibrant video display I've ever seen in a computer device. (More about that later...)My first test of the Fire HD7 was, of course, reading my ebooks. All 104 of my Kindle ebooks came pre-loaded.  I found reading on my Fire HD7 to be even more simple and straightforward  than reading on my Kindle Keyboard. The Fire HD7 uses touch-screen controls instead of buttons. Touch the right side of the screen to advance a page, and the left side to go back. You can also "swipe" left or right with your finger to achieve the same result. You can add a bookmark by touching the upper right corner; bring up the menu of options by touching the center of the screen. It's all designed to make reading as comfortable as... well, reading a book. And it succeeds admirably.Like its older cousins, the Fire HD7 as e-reader isn't limited to just books. You can subscribe to a panoply of magazines and newspapers through the Amazon Appstore and read to your heart's content. Of course, all photos, pictures, and other graphics are displayed in high definition brilliance.MEETING MY HIGH EXPECTATIONS:  Once my Fire HD7 passed that first test (literally, with flying colors!) it was time to see how it would meet my other expectations.Here's how it did:As a Movie player: Through Amazon Prime, I have access to thousands of free streaming movies and TV shows, most of which are streamed to my Fire HD7 in high definition video. I have watched several movies now and have not seen even a single instance of hesitation, stutter, or break in signal. This is due to the Fire HD7's  advanced wi-fi system that uses two antennas and two frequency bands to ensure perfect, glitch-free video and audio streaming.Video Display: The Fire HD7 comes with a true high definition display with a resolution of 1200 x 800 pixels and a pixel density of 216 pixels per inch. This renders all screen graphics clear, crisp, and brilliant. All six fonts of the Kindle ebook reader are as sharp as you'll find in the best "hard copy" books. High definition movies and TV shows come alive on screen. And game graphics are vibrant and smooth.Audio: The Fire HD7 uses Dolby Surround audio that's crisp, clear, and provides a nice balance between high, middle, and low frequencies. I was actually surprised by the high quality of the sound emanating from those tiny stereo speakers on the back of my device. I think the audio is one of the Fire HD7's strongest features.VERSATILITY, AND CONVENIENCE: One of my key expectations for my Kindle Fire HD7 is: how capable is it in a wide variety of settings? Can I take it anywhere and do everything I want with it?  So far, my answer is a qualified "yes."Connectivity:  Unlike its older Kindle Keyboard cousin, the Fire HD7 does not come equipped with 3G/4G cellular capability, but relies instead on its dual-band, dual-antenna wi-fi system for connectivity. This means I only have access to the Internet where wi-fi is available. (Fortunately, I have a smartphone that provides my Fire HD7 with a wi-fi "hot spot," which solves this problem.)  As long as I am in a place where I'm able to connect through wi-fi, I can take full advantage of every feature, including live video streaming, browsing the web, and synchronizing books, newspapers, and magazines through Amazon Whispernet/Whispersynch.Kindle Accessories, battery life: My Fire HD7 shipped in a pretty "bare-bones" configuration : only a mini-USB cable is provided with the device. All other accessories - cases, chargers, screen protectors, and the like - must be purchased separately. These are all available from Amazon, as well as a large number of independent merchants. Cases and covers come in a variety of colors and sizes; with or without built-in lights; and can be reasonably inexpensive or downright costly. I purchased a good solid leather cover that provides plenty of protection for my Fire HD7.Battery life for the Fire HD7 is nearly as good as advertised. With wi-fi turned on, and with me reading an average of 2 - 3 hours per day, I can make a full battery charge last for about 2 - 3 days.MY VERDICT: Over the past few weeks, I have become a constant and enthusiastic user of my new Kindle Fire HD 7" tablet/ebook reader. So far, this excellent device has met or surpassed all my high expectations. Because my Kindle Fire HD is so versatile and easy to use, I find that I can not only read more often and faster, I can aso watch movies, play games, and browse the web nearly anywhere I want. In short: my Kindle Fire HD 7 is my nearly perfect companion, anytime and anywhere!

Reviews.Title: Such an amazing 7" tablet, no complaints at all...
Reviews.Author: John Murphy
Reviews.Content: Just got my KFHD a few days ago and have not been able to put it down.  I knew going in that Google apps were not available, and honestly I don't think it is big deal to me at all. Being a wi-fi device, I dont need turn by turn direction...and already having an Android phone...i have google apps where it is actually relevant to myself and my needs.  As a Amazon Prime member since its beginning, I am a huge fan of Amazon as a whole and I again think they have delivered a great piece of hardware for the cost.  I still have not paid to remove the ads on my KFHD, because they don't bother me 1 bit, only see them on at the lock screen, so I see them for maybe 2 seconds..if this bothers you, pay $15.00 and be done with them.  Anyone who has complained about this...I either feel you do not have a KFHD and just go off what others like to complain about...or you just like to complain..period.I got this tablet to basically be something i can carry easily around the house or to a friends house and check FB, Twitter, Fantasy football, shop Amazon, browse the web...play a few games, maybe read a book or two, and I just love everything this device delivers.  Alot of people complain bout not being able to get certain apps, or have to pay for them...do a google search for how to add certain apps (w/o rooting) and you will be amazed at what you can find, and accomplish with a little effort...which by the way..once you get it to work, you feel like you accomplished something.(At least i did/do)  With minimal effort, I have side-loaded Instagram (not the Instafire HD from appstore, the actual Instagram), Dropbox, Angry birds Star Wars (w/o paying for the 2.99 HD version)..an app to access the front camera (if that is something you want)..added Dolphin as my main web browser..etc...minus Google Apps, there really isn't any app i am upset I cant get on my KFHD, or expected I could and now am disappointed when i couldnt.  There are many apps/sites where you can download .APK's and install them, just do a bit or searching and you will be happy you did.  Before I actually bought my KFHD, i had thought i would root it right away as I did with my phone..but i really don't see the need to do so, and probably wont do it.I knew what i wanted in a tablet going in...I basically looked at the Nexus 7, the Nook and the KFHD...besides being a Prime member already, and loving what people have said about the KFHD..Amazon being a great company is probably what was the final thing to really not even make me go with anything else.  In 7+years of shopping almost entirely from Amazon...I have had 1 shipping issue (which was the carriers fault) and even then Amazon sent me a replacement that same night, no questions asked.  It is great to still have a company that appreciates their customers and provide great products, prices and service.Again, couldn't be happier with my KFHD..and for all the comparisons about how its not an iPad...I consider this...how many people own an iPad and use it to go on Facebook, pintrest, Twitter and play angry birds? In that case, it can do what most people use an iPad for, but for a 3rd the cost...tablets are not laptop/PC replacements IMO and should not be looked at being so...with the exception of some people doing "serious" gaming on an iPad (GTA 3, a few other graphically intense games), i feel most people don't ever fully utilize all a tablet can offer..same with laptops...people do email, browse social sites..do some online shopping, play some games to pass the time...the KFHD does all this, and more for less cost.  Thanks Amazon for a great product!

Reviews.Title: Very Nice . . . Couple of Minor Complaints
Reviews.Author: bantcher
Reviews.Content: This is the first and only Kindle Fire HD I've purchased so far, after having bought 4 Kindle Fires before (one for me, one for my wife, one for a daughter, and one for my mother.  I've now given my Kindle Fire to another daughter.)  I've had the KFHD now for 2 weeks and love the device.  I use it mostly for reading, and some for buying products through Amazon, surfing the web and using some apps and games.  Overall, this is a great product for the price.  Looks great and handles great.  I like the external volume button and the camera.  The ads on the lock screen don't bother me at all.  The "others bought" carousel bothered me at first, but now I mostly ignore it, and I've actually used it a couple of times.  My complaints are fairly minor and are, in part, based on my experience with the regular Kindle Fire, which I never reviewed but I would have given 5 stars.  Before I go on to the minor complaints about the KFHD, one other feature of the KFHD I really like is the micro HDMI out port.  We use it to put things up on our big TV for the whole family to enjoy, including pictures, blogs and the Bible (through an app) that is then read to us by a distinguished sounding British reader.  Very fun and cool way to "read" scriptures together as a family.  (Btw, I bought a 15 ft. micro HDMI to HDMI cable through Amazon that I use to get stuff on the screen -- wanted it long so I could do this from my easy chair.)Minor complaints:  there was (and is) a college football scoreboard app that I used and really liked on my Kindle Fire that is not available for the KFHD.  I know there are other similar apps -- I'm using one but I don't like it as much.  It is frustrating because when I pull up on Amazon.com the app I used and liked on my Kindle Fire it shows that it is available for the KFs on my account but not the KFHD.  Same is true of an accuweather app I used on the KF but can't get on the KFHD. I'm using the weatherchannel app now on the KFHD, which is fine, but I was used to and liked accuweather better.  I assume these things will work themselves out over time as apps are modified or new ones created to run on the KFHD.  But I wonder why what I assume is a somewhat more advanced device can't be made to run the older apps that run on the "less advanced" device -- retro compatibility.Not having flash was a real disappointment, but I understand Adobe is not supporting it now for these androids.  I'm using the Dolphin browser as the solution for this problem, as others in their comments have said they are doing, but it was a bit of a hassle to get that loaded and I wonder why Amazon doesn't maybe ship the KFHDs with instructions -- or somehow more clearly provide instructions -- on how to download the Dolphin browser (and maybe other workaround browsers?) to be able to use flash.  Probably a legal restriction of some kind or a desire not to promote some other company with which Amazon doesn't have a relationship. Understandable, but doesn't help the customer experience much.Amazon's "acting" like the camera is only usable for Skype is also a little disappointing.  By that I don't mean they're doing anything to keep people from realizing there are apps that permit the camera to be used as a regular camera -- that would be impossible -- but, again, I wish they'd more actively let people know the camera can be used for more than just Skype-ing.  Again, I'm sure there are good reasons for that.  I haven't even used the camera to Skype yet, but have used it to take pictures and post pics on Instagram.Overall, very pleased with the KFHD and looking forward to more apps, including updates of older apps, to run on this very nice, enjoyable and affordable device.  If you haven't owned a Kindle Fire before and are thinking of getting the KFHD, do not hesitate -- it is well worth the $200.  If you have a KF already and are wondering about getting the KFHD, I'd say do it, but be aware that you may need to adjust expectations a little and do some workarounds to get some of the same features/apps you enjoy on the KF -- flash being the single biggest one in my opinion.9/29 Update:  there's now an accuweather app for the HD, and the yahoo sportacular app has the same type of college football score board I was missing from the regular fire. Other thing I still miss from the regular fire is the charging/charged light in the power button. I'm using a battery app, and I know the light wasn't exact, but I still miss it.

Reviews.Title: Don't Waste your money
Reviews.Author: Craig
Reviews.Content: If you want a tabet that let's you look at ads and shop Amazon then this might be for you.  Otherwise it is an overprice bookreader and something  to watch movies on that you can't even download for free with your prime membership.  You want to surf the web don't plan on doing much of that on this table no flash browser so it blocks you out of most websites.  Amazon has designed this strickly as a gadget for you to make purchases from them.  That would not be so bad if you could do other things that tablets let you do like surf the web.  Please do your research they want you to pay $15.00 to opt out of ads which brings this tablet up to $264.00 not including tax for basically a reader.  You may as well go with Apple if your going to be forced to do things their way.  Bought ths for my wife who is a big Amazon fan can could no wait for a Kindle with more memory even if Kindle was too cheap to add a memory card.  What a disapointment.  Then to make it ad based is ridiculous, and not give you full internet capabilities.  We can't even book a flight when sitting at the airport.  Another company just ripping off the public.

Reviews.Title: best in class and then some...
Reviews.Author: W. Ballard
Reviews.Content: I was sick and tired of my iPad gen 1.  At $700 new (less than three years ago), it was the top of the line 64 GB 3G when it came out.  Over the few years I've had it, it's become frustratingly unresponsive and excruciatingly slow.  Apps crashed constantly and it lacked flash, which made surfing the web a hit or miss ordeal.  I wanted to replace it, but I couldn't see shelling out $700 for a new iPad, and a repeat performance of significant performance degradation over time.  Plus I wanted something smaller, lighter, and leaner.  I'd found I mostly use my tablet for browsing the internet and for reading, with occasional other media use.  It's primarily an entertainment device.I researched numerous tablets, and it came down to the Nexus 7 and the Kindle Fire HD as the most suitable options.  I went to the local Best Buy to get some hands on.  They had the Kindle Fire HD, but not the Nexus 7, and I was seriously impressed with the Kindle's features and performance.  The value is incredible and I came away with a product to beat.The reviews I'd read actually favored the Nexus 7, which was supposed to have a more powerful processor and a better app store, among other things.  However, on Amazon, the user reviews were not as glowing.  To test drive the Nexus 7, I had to go to Sam's Club where they had one on display.  I had high expectations, but found the Nexus 7 less impressive than the Kindle.  The Nexus 7 was actually a bit jerky and less responsive, despite the better processor, especially when browsing the web.  After a few minutes of lackluster interaction, I'd made my decision.  I ordered the 32 GB Kindle HD from Amazon that night.Two days later, I received my new Kindle Fire HD.  Man, am I happy with this decision!  This device is fantastic, and a HUGE improvement over my POS iPad.  And I spent one-third the money I would have paid for a replacement iPad and half the amount I would have paid for the new iPad mini, which I also checked out at the local Apple store prior to purchasing the Kindle.  Love the features and performance.  Love the browser; demolishes Safari.  Love the app store; I was able to find and replace nearly every app I had on my iPad that I cared about.  Love the cloud and superb integration with Amazon's ecosystem.  Love the vibrant HD screen.  Love the reader.  On and on...I would have loved to try the larger Kindle before buying the 7 inch model just for perspective, but such is life.  This product is awesome!  I can't recommend the Kindle Fire HD enough.update 11/15/12I got a Kindle fire for my wife last year and wanted to compare the wifi between mine and hers, so I found a site that measures connection speed.  I have Cox cable internet and pay extra for faster service.  My wife's Kindle clocked in at around 10-15 mb/sec, depending on the location in the house.  My Kindle HD was around 20-25 mb/sec.  Much faster.After a couple weeks of use, I'm still thrilled about the purchase.

Reviews.Title: Isn't Technology Wonderful!!
Reviews.Author: Tribaldancer
Reviews.Content: A friend bought me my first kindle for a Christmas present and for the last two years,it has not left my purse! The one I have has a keyboard (the keys of which are now faded)I mostly only read and played games on it, but I don't know how I would live without it!I have been wanting to update for a while now, and so I read many of the reviews here, and finally made up my mind to purchase a Kindle Fire HD and I love it! I love the price too! It is just the right size to keep in my purse.  I bought it for entertainment purposes, and so far, I have not been disappointed. I'm not a 'techi' by any means, and I'm rather impatient, I want to be able to "plug and play" I am a busy doctoral student and so I'm not interested in having to read extentsive "How to" manuals before I can use something, so I usually invest in gadgets that are easy to use. I was up and running within the first hour of getting the device.I was happy to find that I could charge my Fire with my Smart Phone charger adaptor. The only issue I have is when I read a book, sometimes I can't get to the 'home' icon when I want to close the book, it seems that there is some kind of delay. I haven't noticed it on the games. So far I have only watched an episode of one of my favourite shows on Hulu, but it was awesome!All, in all I am thrilled with my purchase, it is big enough to watch a movie, but small enough to keep in my purse. I am looking forward to using it when I travel, wait in the doctors office, or horror of horros the DMV!  I will be travelling to Puerto Rico in a few weeks, and I have a six hour lay over in Atlanta, I don't think I am going to notice the time too much :), I will be able to retreat into the world of Kindle entertainment!  I would like to say thank you to everyone who took the time to write such extensive reviews, they really help people like me who have no idea about technical stuff, but just want to know their hard earned cash will be well spent :) You saved me an awful lot of time and money!

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Multimedia Device
Reviews.Author: Eric Westrope "KindleReader"
Reviews.Content: I bought the Kindle Fire HD 7" 16gig device for two main reasons, Kindle eBooks and Amazon Videos. I also went in to the purchase knowing full well that this is designed as a personal multimedia tablet and not a full feature computer tablet. And I am not disappointed.The internet WiFi speed was great. It took me less then a half hour to download all my purchased ebooks. Which is quite a few. Movie streaming was smooth and high quality. The picture was great. Plus the sound was WOW! From such a small device, the movie I was streaming had quality surround sound, and it was impressive, it actually sounded like it was coming from different points around me.Personally, for me, the Kindle Fire HD fits the needs I wanted it for, streaming movies and reading ebooks.I really like it, and would have given it 10 stars if I could have.I should note that I purchased mine at Best Buy after checking out the demo model that was on display.Update: Netflix is super sharp and streams great, and sounds great. Flixster, not so great, it is pixelated, not bad, but noticeable. So Flixster needs to update their app so it will stream HD video to the Kindle Fire HD.Update 10/2/2012:The whispersync for voice works great! You can be reading an ebook, leave off on a new page, pick it up on the audiobook where you left off, then go back into the ebook and pick up where you left off on the audiobook. You can even listen to the audiobook and read along with the ebook, as the audiobook reads, it will highlight the words in the ebook! (This is great for children by the way.) FYI, not all ebook and audiobooks are whispersync voice ready yet.Also the new KindleFire HD has text to speech.

Reviews.Title: The Pros and Cons ... but definitely a keeper
Reviews.Author: eBookreader
Reviews.Content: My first Kindle Fire was among the first shipped, and I ordered the KF HD the day it was released. My initial reaction when the HD arrived was disappointment. But after spending several days complaining to my wife about all that was wrong with the new KF HD, I began to discover things about it that made me very happy I hadn't sent it back. So here is my essential list of the Pros and Cons:Cons:1. No external indicator of when the unit is fully charged (so I downloaded a free app to monitor the status of the battery).2. The on/off switch is hard to locate by touch (so I ordered the $44 case that is seen in all the ads -- it turns the unit on when I open the cover and turns it off when I close it...very well designed and highly recommended).3. I didn't like the fact that my favorites were removed from the home page (but I came to appreciate the fact that I can now access my favorites from any location without returning to the home page).4. I didn't like the ads for suggested purchases (keyed to the first item in my carousel on the home page--the item most recently accessed), but I have found several suggestions to be of interest (although some have been inappropriate).5. It takes much longer to charge than the old KF.6. Times Roman, one of my favorite fonts, is no longer available in the book reader.7. The camera only faces the user so its only practical use is with Skype (but, at least it has one--and it has a mic, which has other uses).8. Finally, they took what I considered to be a very elegant virtual keyboard and dumbed it down to something reminiscent of one of my earlier cell phones (but this is only an esthetical flaw, as I see it, and I may be all alone in my opinion).Pros:1. All my books (including the Oxford Dictionary and my foreign language dictionaries) can now be indexed the first time I do a search, so future searches are almost instant. This means I can now search my reference books -- which I COULD NOT DO on the old KF (well, I could, but it would take forever and was simply not practical). This is of particular use for me since I use my Kindle largely for academic work.2. It appears that the logic for the search engine on the new KF HD has greatly improved: For the first time, of which I am aware, Kindle e-Books can be searched using the "*" wildcard character. For example "revi*" will find "revisit" or "revitalize" or "review" or any other word in the book that starts with those four letters. But the letters "revi" will not find anything, unless such a four-letter combination exists as a separate word or acronym. This provides a greater level of precision when searching a reference book, for example.3. I can use an inexpensive HDMI cable to connect my KF HD to my HD TV and read my books, surf the Net, or watch Amazon Prime movies for free while I am on my treadmill! This was the feature that convinced me to order the KF HD (since I spend an hour per day on the treadmill) and it works as advertised.4. Games are now separated from other apps by a Games tab and an Apps tab (this would be of more value to me if I hadn't given my old KF to my 9 year-old daughter who liked to download free games to play whenever I wasn't using the KF).5. It is lighter weight than the original KF.6. I can now have my Kindle e-books read to me (something my Kindle DX would also do). Since this feature turns the page for me (and I can set the rate at which the text is read), I can also turn the volume down and have the pages turned for me at the rate I normally read.Although I see fewer Pros than Cons (there are other Pros but not thing of particular interest or use to me), the Pros make this one clearly a keeper.

Reviews.Title: A step down from the original
Reviews.Author: Mark F. Fisher "Gatortrapper"
Reviews.Content: The new Kindle Fire HD is a step down from the original so I don't recommend it.BACKGROUND: I have two original Fires and have about 1000 hours plus of use on them. I bought the HD and have run it about 60 hours and had a conversation with Amazon about their new system.First, the HD doesn't run Flash based media so a large % of content is not available. The original did support it and I loved it. Electing the "mobile" option helps but is not a full solution as the non-functional level went from about 40-50% to 20-25%...Second, the HD has made browsing and moving from one tab to another more difficult in that getting to "Bookmarks" has an extra step and you can't go from the existing tab to a bookmark but have to open another tab first.Third, a lot of apps that ran on the original won't run on the HD. Bummer.Fourth, although the keyboard is better on the HD the loss of the spelling correction/suggestion function is a severe downgrade. Yes, I know, it's supposed to have it and it is "enabled" as a choice on mine, it just doesn't work.Fifth, the Silk browser doesn't interface with websites as well as the older version. Why? I haven't a clue but I can tell you that the interface with the original was superior. For example, it doesn't let you navigate within the website as swiftly or precisely as the older version so much time is expended on trying to coax it to go where you want and then wait longer for it to load. Indeed I am getting "timing out" type problems and situations where the site "hangs", something I rarely experienced with the original.A final negative is the loss of the easy, intuitive access to functions. The HD has more icons and buttons and like TV controls and phones more is often not better. When I had a problem and needed to talk to Amazon before I knew with a few key strokes I would hear the phone ring. Now I have to navigate through the whole Amazon website to get to the same spot that was previously on the device. A real downgrade in my view because if it's a gift and you don't have an Amazon account you may have trouble.On the plus side the email app is much better: easier to access and better presentation and setup is easy.So...I'm giving this to my son and retrieving my older Fire.

Reviews.Title: Improvements at the Cost of Functionality
Reviews.Author: Fanny's Daddy
Reviews.Content: On the plus side: the screen is gorgeous; the browser fast; the sound a 100% improvement on the original Fire.The negatives: the ads are horribly intrusive (I own three Kindles with the special offers and haven't unsubscribed from any of them); on the Fire they take over half the screen. And when I unsubscribed from them for the $15 charge, I still found ads on the bottom of the carousel that I was informed I was not able to remove (they are ads disguised as Recommendations Features); the touch screen is very erratic and unresponsive; and the interface has become very clunky and way too 'busy'.As much as I am a fan of Amazon and love the products, I can't help but think this is a big step backwards for them. This is a 'rushed' project if I ever saw one. I hope the 'lit' kindle isn't as disappointing. As for this, I'm sending it back.

Reviews.Title: I love the new Fire HD (**Update 9/19)
Reviews.Author: larryl
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying I own mostly android devices. I have a Motorola Xoom, the original Fire and an iPad (work related) as tablets. Out of everything I was surprised that for the past year I used the original Fire more than any device I had. I admit that I installed goLauncher on the original as I wasn't a fan of the carousel. This basically made it more of regular android tablet. So I basically fell in love with a 7" device. More portable and easier to handle. The thing the original Fire lacked that I wanted was a front-camera, microphone and hdmi out. So I was extremely pleased the new HD version had those things.I've had the new HD in my hands for a few hours and here are my initial reactions (some based purely on prior Kindle Fire experience)1) The screen is beautiful.2) Without a doubt the BEST speakers in any phone or tablet I have experienced. Extremely clear and loud sound.3) Finally finally a facebook app (though it may be in the app store for all now). I just stumbled across it in reading the description on amazon's site about facebook integration and it says in addition to the facebook app in the appstore. There are no reviews for it yet, so I can only assume it is new.4) Love the magazine double-click to text view. So clear and easy to read with color pics.5) The new favorites star is awesome.. To be able to access the star on any screen and get your favorites is wonderful.6) The app store is nicely laid out and much better to deal with than the prior version.7) The calendar app is fantastic. Finally we have a calendar and email with exchange.8) The ads - well they don't really bother me as most of it is catered to what I would like I suppose, but here is the thing that is aggravating. One of the ads was for free $5 mp3 credit, which I've accepted and added to my account, but it stays on my offers. I wish it would delete itself for something like that. **EDIT - well today the mp3 offer is no longer there. Not sure if the new day did that or they read my review and remove it ha ha.9) A lot more menu items at the top now including audiobooks, shop, games (not apps as that is different), photos and offers.10) Unfortunately the device is wider than the original fire so I can't use the cover I had for it and have to buy a new one.11) No wall charger, but you can use your old one or purchase one from amazon, or use your android phone charger.**EDIT 9/1512) One thing I do not like is the power button being next to the volume controls as I keep hitting the volume instead of the power. I did get the Marware case though that turns the screen on and off when open/closed and now I'm glad I chose that kind of case as I don't have to worry about the power button mostly. *EDIT 9/19 - returning the marware case and got a must cheaper Moko case. It has speaker cut outs, better viewing angles and can charge while closed. Only mentioning here, because the power button being flush with the device is a minus, but the moko case clamp is between the volume and power so its easier to find it. But again, the case closing will power it off automatically as well.**EDIT 9/1913) My email app has 3 accounts.. gmail, exchange and my personal. All 3 are set to check every hour, but my personal one checks every 10 to 20 minutes regardless of what I set. They put the notifications under "settings/applications" and the email is off by default, so that's how I know as I turned my on.I will update if I find anything else.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Tablet and the price is right
Reviews.Author: G. Berger
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace my first generation iPad and second generation Kindle. It was a tough choice between the Kindle Fire and Nexus 7, but in the end I felt that the areas where the Kindle out-performed the Nexus were the ones that mattered to me - better display, better speakers, twice the memory, better wireless. But it could have gone either way, the Nexus has its points.At any rate, this device is perfect for me. It's just the right size, small but not too small and nice and light.Likes: - Display is terrific - Sound is EXCELLENT - The speakers especially are much better than expected for a device this size. Sound through good headphones is amazing - VERY easy to transfer files to and from my PC. It shows up like any other drive. - Hooked into Amazon, I consider this a plus. - Size - Browser is pretty fast - Movies look great - Overall look and feel is excellent - Wireless is fast, much faster than my iPad. At least it seems that way, I have no hard numbers to back that up.Dislikes:- The volume and power buttons are too well integrated into the side of the tablet - they should have been raised a bit to make them easier to find and operate.- Charging port should have been on the short side, not the long side. I guess it had to be somewhere and they had to make a choice, but I don't agree with their choice.- Does not include a wall charger. It should, but on the other hand my X2 phone chargers work so this is not an issue for me. I have chargers all over the place.- Battery life is good but nothing like my iPad or kindle. The kindle of course has longer life - it's  a very simple and limited device. And the iPad has room for a larger battery I suppose. I can live with it, no problem, but it does require charging fairly often.- No GPS (Nexus has it). Not an issue for me, but something to note if you are looking at these two tablets.I'm totally neutral about the ads. They only appear on the lock screen so what's the big deal? I can't believe all the negative reviews based on the presence of ads. Don't these people read before they buy?

Reviews.Title: Great Product
Reviews.Author: TA
Reviews.Content: We are long-time Kindle fans. We really have enjoyed the original Kindle Fire. The new HD version is a very good upgrade. We are very pleased with the availability of a camera to use with Skype. Other reviewers have expressed concern that the camera is of limited use beyond Skype, but it meets our needs completely. The picture and sound are outstanding. We had absolutely no trouble with the wireless connection. It works like a charm, easy and fast. The new Kindle is more email friendly, particularly for Outlook users. We had to purchase an app to access Outlook with the original Fire. That was not necessary with the new model. It is surprising that a charger is not included, but as many others have noted, chargers for previous versions work fine. The ads that annoy some reviewers don't bother us. We don't care what's on the lock screen. Like some other reviewers, we struggle to find the power button at times, but that is a minor issue to us. We love to travel. The original Fire was a great machine for road trips. We could easily access movies and music. The new Fire's upgrades in sound and video make this experience even better. We also like the HDMI access.This is an excellent upgrade. It's a nice bonus that the price did not go up with this new generation.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD Review from Someone who Purchased a Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: Mr. Orange "Music Obsessed"
Reviews.Content: I love my Kindle Fire HD. I have an iPad (2nd Gen) as well, and one of the reason I got a Kindle Fire HD is for school. I didn't want to take my expensive iPad with me, so I got a Kindle Fire HD for basic tablet needs (email, movies, music, etc) and not for heavy android customization. I did research and purchased the Kindle Fire HD and have been overall pretty happy.Couple things to mention before we begin:1. THIS DEVICE DOES NOT HAVE FLASH NOT BECAUSE AMAZON CHOSE NOT TO INCLUDE FLASH, but because Adobe, maker of flash, discontinued flash support on ALL android devices. This is also the case with Nexus 7 - it does NOT include flash.2. The device does NOT include a charger head (Why?), though I'm not bugged by it, I do feel its a cheap shot. Why do I want to purchase something separate for something that SHOULD be included. I'm lucky to have charger heads that support USB, including my last Kindle, but still. Most computers also include a USB port for charging, but overall, I think this is a bit lazy.3. ADVERTISEMENT!!! I actually don't mind them. When I pre-ordered it, I knew it would come with "Ads" and I thought it was only on the lock screen, but upon using the device, i found "Customers Also Bought" section below the carousel, which is bit of an annoyance, but overall, I don't mind it. I actually got really good stuff with it. I got $5 free MP3 credit AND $5 free credit for the video store as an offer from Amazon. So it's not all so bad. Of course, like others, I can opt out by paying $15, but for now, I'm comfortable.4. Kindle Fire HD vs. Nexus 7 - I'm really sick of this. First, the Fire HD, should not be compared to the Nexus 7, that's like comparing tablets to the iPad. Each have their pros and cons, and have different clientele. I got a Kindle over a Nexus 7 because I made a lot of investments with Amazon (music, books, music, etc) and their overall customer service (read below). Nexus 7 is an impressive tablet, but so is the Kindle Fire HD is many ways.5. NO BACK CAMERA - which I don't mind. I rarely use my own iPad for pictures or video. Most people have a camera phone or an actual photo camera, so really, I don't see the big gripe about not including a back camera. It does have a front camera for skype. Nexus 7 also does NOT include a back camera. However, what's weird, is that both devices have camera/picture apps.Now here are some highlights:***Display / Screen***Not the OS, but the overall display is extremely impressive. It has really nice vibrant colors and watching videos have never looked so good for a 7" tablet. Reading books are also a joy, it doesn't strain the eyes so much like the last Kindle Fire or any of the electronic tablets. Reading books, though not ink, is smoother and comparable to the Kindle ebook readers (touchscreen, etc). Looking at pictures are also really nice and clear. I've played around with the iPad 2 and 3 and I can say, even though iPad's Retina Display is unbeatable, the Kindle Fire HD display is pretty darn close to comparable.***Sound***The Dolby Audio, to my surprise, is really impressive. I thought the "Dolby" thing was a business gimmick, but I was wrong. Without headphones, the audio is loud and clear. I had a couple "hisses" and "crackling" noises for a bit when the Fire HD first arrived, but has gone away since. The audio on movies and TVs is really clear. Watching Hunger Games, it really brings out the detail in in the sound. With music, it emphasizes crisp clear sound. it doesn't have much of a bass, but it has enough of a kick. With Headphones, it really comes out clear, however, I have nice headphones, so depending on other headphones, it may be different. With Apple earbuds, it sounds the same as if listening from a iPhone or iPad. Overall, the sound really is a high quality to this device. 5/5***Customer Service & Prime Membership benefits***Overall, I've been really impressed with Amazon's customer service. Whenever I've had a problem, they've been able to step up and solve the issue. Is it perfect? No. I love Apple's customer service, but they're not perfect either. They have great deals and lots to offer in their store. I buy a lot of MP3's because of the low price (Albums from $.99 to $3.99) Even P!nk's new album is $5! Great deals. Plus, with the Prime membership, it's an added bonus that neither Google or Apple have. With Prime, I have access to streaming free TV and Movies as well as two day shipping. Also, the lending library is great. I've read books I've always wanted to read certain books, and since they're free to read, I have no excuse.Here's the BAD PART.The OS is terrible. The carousel, no matter what, is the worst thing in the world. The favorites' folder, the Apps, Movie, Music, etc Folder (or menu) is like any regular android or apple tablet setup and really great, but the carousel? No. Silk is great, but using Safari on my iPad, iPhone and using Firefox / Browser on Android, Silk doesn't come par. It's faster and smoother since Fire 1, but it's still not quite their yet (hopefully an update will improve this).Like others, I've had trouble with sensitivity with the touch screen, as well as "phantom" lag. The keyboard is actually fine, but for example, when I'm on screen and I push the "web" section, it takes a bit to load up, so it feels like I didn't push it at all. It goes with purchasing apps or clicking on web links. Sometimes I don't feel like I'm pushing it right or if I'm pushing it at all.On the other hand, the processor is really fast and extremely smooth.Also from an iPad user, and being aware of Google Play, the app section is pretty limited. Sure, it has your basic apps, like Temple Run, Netflix, HBO GO, Skype, news apps, etc, but it doesn't come close to offer the multitude of apps for android. Actually, Amazon has a "bootloader" code in the new Kindle Fires (all devices) that prevents you from installing boot apps like Firefox browser or GO Launcher Ex (that transforms your layout all together). Amazon wants their devices to be stricly Amazon based (using silk instead of firefox, example). I think this is kind of sad, especially when Apple and Android offer 3rd party browser apps like Google Chrome (for iPad) or Dolphin. I was able to install Dropbox APK with no problems. So some 3rd party APK apps will work, but other won't (trial and error).Overall, for $199, the Fire HD is solid and impressive. A major step up from the last Kindle Fire, which seemed almost a prototype "dip your toes into the water" version. The Kindle Fire HD is officially a tablet and tons of media selections. But there is room for improvement. Using it, I have no regrets and actually LOVE using the Fire HD. I'm a happy customer and intend to KEEP my device.

Reviews.Title: Kindle - Worst Interface of any device anywhere ever
Reviews.Author: Zbigboy
Reviews.Content: I have used almost every type of PC, Mac, Linux, Apple IOS, Android, Ipad, digital camera, interface there is.  I am in a professional business with lots of turnover of computers, cell phones, digital cameras, etc.  The Kindle by far is the most confusing and ridiculous interface I have ever seen.  It is completely setup to sell you something from the get go.  It is an amazon purchase interface and that is all it is.  At every step of the way it tries to sell you apps, movies, or get you onto amazon.com.  I have 3 of these for my kids and my wife and I have been through all the setup, all the kindle help pages on Amazon and we find ourselves not even able to find apps we just purchased for our kids.  Get yourself an Ipad, which we have, or an Ipod, which we have.  Get yourself a Mac laptop (or device), get yourself a PC(or tablet PC), both of which we have, but stay away from the Kindle OS until you have a chance to try one or borrow one.  This is a complete investment in frustration and the confusing library / apps / store interface will drive you away from this device.We, seriously, are minutes away from boxing up all three of these and sending them back.  The wife and kids will be fine with the wife's Mac Laptop, my PC laptop, or the Ipad or Ipods.  We were much less frustrated before the Kindle Fire HD's and we will be a happier family once these are out of here.  I think the only thing is the kids will miss the constant Amazon credit card ads or Ford ads on startup.This is not even a 1 star device.  It is an Amazon.com sales gimmick that only works if you enter in all your amazon user names and passwords.  It also wants to take you further by forcing you to setup amazon 1 click.  It has no ability to discern who is using it - as it will show ads not meant for your kids and not care or be able to tell who it is catering ads for - adult or child.  It has no ability to restrict ads, you will get them in just picking it up to unlock it.  You will get them and there is no turning them off.  Think of this device as a customer invasion of privacy as well because all of your web browsing and all of your use of it and purchases are tracked by amazon.  Congratulations on purchasing an amazon kindle - your privacy has been further invaded by a corporation.  You are now being tracked and targeted.

Reviews.Title: Good tablet...for the price.
Reviews.Author: Thomas R. Herzog
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire HD is a nice improvement to it's predecessor but it still needs some work.Pros:* The screen is very sharp and crisp, not as nice as the iPad but for this price, it's pretty great.* The sound from the Dolby audio is amazing, however- having the volume up all the way is nice and loud but lower it just a little bit and the volume lowers a whole lot.* Added native email support, unseen from the original Kindle.* Syncs well with the cloud, however I haven't been able to STREAM from the cloud, if I want to watch or read something it downloads it.Cons:* The ads, $15 to remove something you paid a high amount for, even when "Special Offers" wasn't mention in the description as it is with other Kindles* The wifi isn't as great as they make it out to be, I can stay connected better than the original Kindle, but it's not "lag free"* The screen on off/power button isn't tactile at all and I have to look for it every time I want to turn it on or off* Getting out of a book is more work than it should be, it took me awhile to figure out I had to tap really fast with my index finger to bring up the menu* Going from page to page doesn't have that cool little page animation like it did in the keynote, it just slides. Not a big deal.* The carousel is more fluid than the original Kindle, but they should make another "theme" since some people, me included, find the overall UI quite clunky.* Not a whole lot of apps to chose from, and the apps in the store, not all of them are made for the Kindles size.* No wall charger, not a big deal-- I'll use one from my old Kindle.Amazon-- Nice tablet, but you really need to remove ads (for free) and give us access to the android market. Polish up your UI a bit too.Design: 4 Stars (Suffers because of non-tactile buttons and lack of rear camera)UI: 3 Stars (Could be much better)Audio Quality: 4.5 Stars (Fix volume changing so much)Screen Quality: 4 Stars (Not quite HD, and the aspect ratio isn't designed for watching movies)App Selection: 2 Stars (Obvious)Total: 3.5 Stars, I'll give it 4 stars for now, since it did just release.UPDATE:Downgraded to 3 stars.  Just falls way short of my expectations, I love Amazon and will continue to shop from them. I might just return this however though, and get the Nexus 7 or wait for the iPad Mini. It's just too clunky, and half of everything you see is trying to sell you on something else.  I wanted to turn the volume off on an app, and used the only tactile buttons this thing has (volume rockr) and it didn't work. Turns out most apps have their own volume controls. Some that don't even work, so the volume controls don't do anything really.  Might be returning this. Going to give it a couple days.

Reviews.Title: Soooo Disappointed .... New Buyers Beware
Reviews.Author: w
Reviews.Content: As of this week Amazon has redesigned the web browser on the Kindle Fire and it is a giant step backwards. I received my Kindle Fire on Monday and was elated with the improvements over the previous editions, particularly the new web browser.  The next day the web browser was gone and replaced with a return to uninspired form.  The convenience of internet access on the updated  starter page is gone, and is replaced with a tired, cumbersome, time consuming mess.  I received this product on Monday and immediately fell in love with it.  Two days later I am disappointed to the max and am wondering what are they going to "improve" next.

Reviews.Title: I Love My New Kindle
Reviews.Author: Lady Song
Reviews.Content: I own the older style keyboard Kindle and the new Kindle HD 7".  I also had the regular Kindle Fire before I upgraded to the new Fire HD.  My favorite feature is that they have added the automatic reader.  You press a button and you can have text to speech where the machine will read to you.  This was not on the original Fire and it was a feature I missed greatly.  I realize they offer audible books for a fee however the text to speech monitone read is free.  The graphics are also much sharper and I am really pleased with the extra memory.  If you do not own a reader or do not have an updated reader I would highly recommend this one.  It is fast and love the color graphics.  You also can get a lot of apps that are a lot of fun and many are free games.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for my needs
Reviews.Author: David G. Nelson
Reviews.Content: This tablet is perfect for, quick internet browsing, checking and writing emails, using facebook, playing timewaster games, watching Netflix, listening to music....Well pretty much everything that I want a computer or tablet for.  I've played around with my friend's Ipad and actually prefer this, especially for the cost.  The screen is bright and crisp, video and pictures look great.  Internet connection is better than my ipod around the house. I have not experienced many apps crashing (less than on my ipod).  I also like the advertisments that Amazon puts on the boot up screen.  They've sent some very awesome deals to me ($10 or less album for $3, free $1 credits for various purchases, a $10 credit for paying with discover, and on and on.). Looking forward to the kids profile so I can let them play with it more and limit their use without having to battle them about how long they have been on.  I would also like to see a more robust app selection however they do have most of the major ones that I'd want.  All around this is a terrific product that you should not hesitate to buy. Bravo Amazon!

Reviews.Title: "AWESOME"
Reviews.Author: Virginia Dyer
Reviews.Content: I've had a Kindle for years..... since I read a lot of books, I thought I was in 7th heaven when I got my Kindle,  Now, I know I'm in 7th heaven with my Kindle Fire HD...  What can I say:  I LOVE IT, I LOVE IT, I LOVE IT.I'm 67 years young, and the newest technologies just "Thrill" me..........

Reviews.Title: One Awesome Little Tablet!  Yay!!!!
Reviews.Author: Teresa Grubman "dmagick1"
Reviews.Content: I tried to decide for months...Kindle Fire...iPad...iPad mini...I am so glad I chose this HD Fire!The sound is like having a tiny theater right in your hand.  The colors are just like an HD TV.  All of my books I have ordered on my other Kindle loaded in from the cloud.  Browsing in clean and seamless on the internet.I enrolled in Prime with this and have found all kinds of cute Christmas cartoons I haven't seen in years and watched them right from my tablet.  The 7 inch fits in my purse and it goes everywhere with me.This is a very high quality tablet for the money.  It does everything iPad does.  You can use it as a day planner and load in your Google calender which makes it easy of you want to schedule your life on your computer/Google calender and have it transmit into the e-reader.Rent or buy movies in seconds and hook up to the TV and enjoy!I am going to cancel digital cable because I can get more choice with Prime and it works out to cost a little less each year.Some people don't like the adds and 'people who bought this book bought this one, too.'  I like this feature because I want to see what other cool stuff is out there.  I love online shopping and I don't mind adds.This e-reader/tablet comes with a nice UBS cord but no charger.  If you have other Kindles you can use their charger (I use the one from my DX) or you can by the 'fast' charger.  You will want to get a little booklet to protect it, and it is a good idea to get the screen protector--I wish I would have bought these items too.You will not be able to get many of the apps that Apple offers, like TMC, and some other favorites, but you can enjoy your Face Book and Angry Birds!This reader has a bright screen just like a computer.  It does not have the glare that iPad has, though, and you can also get a little screen for it if reading hurts your eyes.No free 3G?  If you have one of the other Kindle versions and you are traveling, just take it along and use the free 3G for book and article purchases.  When you are in the airport or a hot spot you can always download the book from the cloud into the Fire version.I have been delighted and I am extremely happy I bought this Fire instead of iPad mini.  I enjoy shopping Amazon and this device works better for me.  It would make a pleasant gift for someone as well.

Reviews.Title: Great except for . . .
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Password reset.  I placed a password to lock the kindle so the kids couldn't be on it without our permission.  However after entering the password wrong a few times the kindle asks if you want to reset.  So of course the kids press the reset button and wipe the kindle back to factory defaults like when we recieved it.  I can see a stolen kindle being reset and resold very very easily.  This needs to addressed before I rate this tablet a 5 star product.

Reviews.Title: Glad I didn't buy a IPad instead & am in love with Support
Reviews.Author: Stephanie Mastro
Reviews.Content: I had been thinking about buying an IPad, but had always wanted a Kindle so I bought the Kindle Fire HD 7".  I agree with all of the good things everyone else has said, so I won't go on and on.  I see by other reviews that there are a lot more things for me to expore in addition to e-mail and Angry Birds!  I am basically an anti-electronic device person, and my cell phone is an antique.  The Kindle does everything I want to do, and I can understand how to do it!  There have been a few hiccups along the way but easily fixed.  Any time I have had a problem, Amazon support has been more than helpful.  In fact, I think that is one of the things I like best.My most recent problem was that my hotmail pages weren't all loading onto the Kindle, although they were still appearing on my PC.  I was accessing the e-mail through msn.com on the web and not using the Amazon e-mail app.  Everything was working fine until about two days ago, when I couldn't hit the arrow at the bottom of the page and access the next page of e-mail, nor could I delete anything by checking the delete box.  I will probably never know why.I called Amazon Kindle Support and got Alex, who was the most incredible support person I have ever spoken to.  He actually listened to and understood what I was saying and used his brain in conjunction with whatever he was finding on his solution screens.  We couldn't solve the problem, even with me opening an account through the e-mail app (pages look much better using this app).  So, we parted company for a while while he checked with the higher-ups.  He called me the next morning with a solution given to him by the tech gurus.  While working our way to the solution, we stumbled onto another solution which worked and found that the guru's solution probably wouldn't have worked.  I am so amazed by the quality of Amazon's support people and apologize for not saying more about the Kindle.  Everyone else has really said all the good things.

Reviews.Title: Great value and versatile
Reviews.Author: J. M.
Reviews.Content: For only $200 you cannot go wrong considering the capabilities of this small tablet.
