One of the best things about this is the ability to simply drag and drop music, photos, book files and other data from your PC to the Kindle fire without needing any other software or file conversions. It plays most standard Mp4 and Quicktime camera files as they are.Memory is fixed at 16 gig, about 13 of which is usable for storage. Good but not great.In summary, for 200 bucks I don't think you can beat the performance of this tablet. At least not at this point in time.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: Rufino
Reviews.Content: Received my Kindle today. Set up was quick and simple, picked up my wireless router, registered in less than a minute. Open my books, documents, photos and music and everything was in Amazon Cloud waiting to be downloaded. Including all my Apps from my original Kindle Fire.This is my second Kindle, and I find it easier to set up and use. I don't know what other users are saying that this is difficult to use compared to the First. I tried reading a book and fonts are more clear and adjusting the fonts is simple and easy. Video and sound is far more better than the First.I use my Kindle for casual browsing and lot of reading, while riding the train to and from work, and during lunch break. I think it serves my purpose and anything I can't do with my Kindle, I use my home computer.By the way, I also have an iPad, which sits at home, cause it's too big to fit in my pocket.Update: KFHD WiFi signal is stronger than my lap top. Downloading and uploading is a breeze. Amazing for 199.00.

Reviews.Title: Love it as an e-reader!
Reviews.Author: wishkc
Reviews.Content: I received mine today. So far, I love it! I will be using it mostly as an e-reader, and I was concerned about that. I actually like it much better than my Touch as an e-reader. My two favorite things are the page turns (you can turn a page slowly) and the select a word feature. You get the definition and more options. Of those, the option I love (the Touch didn't have it) is to search the book for other instances of the word. If I don't remember who a character is, I just touch and hold their name, choose options, and search. Up come the instances of that word, with a short part of the context following. This can even be expanded. On the Touch, you get the definition, but nothing else.I don't think reading will give me eye strain.As far as the web surfing, it seems that the connection is actually faster than my computer.Of course, the screen look is fabulous and the touch sensitivity is just right (better than my Touch).The only nit-picking I can think of is: it's heavier than my Touch,it has to be charged more often, you can't put books into collections, and it is a little difficult to find the on/off button. I'm getting a Mo-Ko cover, so I hope that will make it more convenient.I'm glad I bought this instead of the Paperwhite.I'll try to watch this for a couple of days in case there are questions I can hopefully answer.

Reviews.Title: My kindle fire hd and kindle case!
Reviews.Author: katriena blackman
Reviews.Content: Ok, I am a electronic junkie..iPads, galaxy tabs and previous kindle fire owner. When I heard about the KF HD, I wanted it simply so I can watch Amazon Prime (thru the hdmi cord) on my TV, there was nothing wrong with my kindle fire. I thought I loved it....Until KFHD arrived! It is so thin! In my kindle fire case, it is just a tad bit thicker than my kindle 4 in it's case! The case fits glove. The sound is incredible; Better than my Galaxy tabs. The color and clarity of the pic is absolutely beautiful. No, I doesn't match my iPad in productivity. But i can't throw my iPad in my purse to go with my mom to her drs appointments, or plug it in to my Tv, in a hotel room. ...

Reviews.Title: TTS-Immersion Reading Revolutionary
Reviews.Author: Michael Wiles
Reviews.Content: Text To Speech and Immersion Reading Revolutionary especially when combined with 2x-3x listening modes.  Your brain can actually adapt to listening at those speeds.  I was able to get 2.5 books completed this weekend(10 hour trip listened to about 22 hours of audio) and 274 pages(100 read just while waiting for finacee to get hair done by stylist for wedding we were attending) of a thick computer book read in less than a week.  I can finally get through the books I've placed on my list but never had time to read.Furthermore, I found myself fully concentrating on the material and my mind wandering less so I was able to understand more.  This has a profound impact for all sorts of areas (such as students reviews of lectures, listening to any other material presented in an audio fashion that is not music or where visuals are not always needed (i.e. studying for professional license exams/certifications).I also have to say that the Kindle Fire HD 7 handles text and tables well even from a computer book (when screen is rotated sideways).The TTS and Immersion reading is the main reason why I purchased the Kindle Fire and what I'll be using the device primarily for.  It will cut the amount of time required immensely to absorb material.Are their enhancments that could be made sure, but they are mostly software in nature.  The only thing from a hardware perspective I'd like to see is support for large SD cards to augment the storage.

Reviews.Title: Five stars stands for "I love it," and guess what, I do, so...
Reviews.Author: Frank MacCormack
Reviews.Content: If you are a part of the Amazon ecosystem and want to take full advantage of all Amazon has to offer, this device is a no-brainer in my opinion. I had the first Fire to use as an e-reader that could also watch movies/serve as a couch or bed toy, and I really liked it for those purposes. It was a little clumsy and kinda slow, but hey, it did everything it was supposed to do. The HD takes everything up several notches: the screen is so much better, the sound is improved, it's faster, feels more solidly built, and has a slew of completely new software and hardware features like text-to-speech (which I use for driving, and works great) and bluetooth. I don't mind reading extensively on LCD screens so paying the extra money for a device that can do so much more than just display text is just fine by me, and thankfully, the Kindle Fire reading software has been upgraded with the X-Ray features, the aforementioned text-to-speech, real page numbers, and audiobook integration. The interface is a pleasure to use. The device is everything the first Fire should have been, and I'm very happy with the purchase.People have ragged on this thing for multiple reasons, all of which are moot for me. Ads? I barely see them, one of them has actually given me an offer I could use, and you can pay $15 to get rid of them if you hate them that much. The device can't do much more than consume media? I'm curious as to what other people are doing with their tablets, because I've never seen them do anything but, guess what, consume media. Maybe people have found productive ways to use them, but for me, I don't care about that, and this device is not aimed at that, so holding it accountable for something it tells you upfront is misguided. The one gripe I do have is that you can't get rid of the "Customers Also Bought" bar at the bottom of the screen. It's unattractive and I would rather have that space used for a taskbar or something, but hey, they want you to buy things, and that's how they're giving you this fine peice of hardware for 200 bucks. I'm sure the Nexus 7 is a great device too, but since I am not tied to the Google ecosystem in almost any way, I don't know why I would get it over this. Whatever works best for your needs, make that choice, but I'm firmly convinced that anyone who consumes Amazon content will be very happy with this device.

Reviews.Title: Not all apps are compatibility
Reviews.Author: Joe Cicero
Reviews.Content: Well just got the kindle HD 7 inch and I also have the original Kindle fire. To my surprise not all the apps I purchased for the original fire are compatible with the fire HD. I thought I read enough about the fire HD but I don't remember reading that anyplace. Amazon did offer to refund the money of the apps but I declined. The other problem ive seen so far. No Charging Light on the Fire HD.

Reviews.Title: Maybe Amazon overdid the hype? Did not beat the Nook HD+ for me.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "aboyle"
Reviews.Content: Wanted a great birthday gift (I usually pass on gifts for myself), and after watching the videos and reading the reviews I went hook, line, and sinker for the Kindle Fire HD, 32GB, NO special offers.....about $214 total with the recent sale (would normally be $244-ish). Add on the charger for $15....total outlay of $230 for the 7" Kindle Fire HD loaded up nicely. Out of the box it was a little heavier than I expected, and definitely got pretty warm/hot as it ran. Turned it on, it was.....nice. I have to say I found the overall look and display a little gloomy, so dark with the black background. I guess it's there for dramatic contrast; personal preference, it was a little heavy/dark to me. But overall it was.....nice.I think I would have been just fine if I hadn't also received a Nook HD+.  Whoa.  Top to bottom, it's a wow.  Now, that's an 8.9 inch screen, true, but I could have also gotten the 7" screen (16 GB is $149, for 7" or 9").  However, for $179 I got the 8.9" Nook HD+ with 32GB.  The display is incredible.  Better specs than either Kindle Fire HD, and it shows. I didn't notice an appreciable sound difference between the two, but I am NOT an audiophile.  What I am is a serious reader, and the Nook HD+ gave me the absolute best reading experience of any ereader or tablet I found. That page curl/turn animation....feels like you're flipping a page, not clicking a page.B&N; is getting out of the color tablet business, true, but they are keeping their other readers and will continue to sell ebooks.  And with the Nook HD+ being open to Google Play, I can get the Kindle app and read Kindle books on the nook as well. I had them open side by side and the Kindle reading experience was identical on both machines (though again, reading a B&N; book from the nook store....totally different, more organic, natural reading experience, in my opinion).My Kindle Fire HD 7" was costing me $230 (32GB, no ads, and the wall charger); had I decided to do for it and get a comparable Kindle Fire HD 8.9" the total would have been $330 (32GB, no ads, and the wall charger).  For $179 I got everything I was looking for on the Kindle Fire 8.9", plus I have access to Google play and am not so fenced in in terms of apps.  For that price, I'll add on the $50 extended warranty.....and maybe even go ahead and get myself a 7" Nook HD as well, so I've got something smaller to carry when that would be more convenient.I thought I would hands down prefer the Kindle Fire HD, turns out, it was a really great thing to experience them side by side, and think about what I really needed in an ereader/tablet, and what I didn't.I wish you all luck in deciding, and encourage you to consider all the options.  I am so glad I did.  :-)(And just to note....these really are "first world" problems, aren't they....how fortunate we are to have 2 such great choices available!)

Reviews.Title: Great Product at Good Price
Reviews.Author: GJC
Reviews.Content: Did a lot of research and shopping before purchasing the 7" Kindle Fire HD. I was strongly considering the Nexus 7 but after reading the many posted horror stories claiming quality issues and poor customer service I went with Amazon's product. I know from experience that Amazon can be trusted to back their products and will offer a full array of products and services to support them.I've have been enjoying my Kindle daily for the past three weeks, and it's gotten a real workout.  So far it is one of the best products that I have purchased.  It delivers all that is advertised and much more. I opted for the 32 gig model as it allows for a lot of HD video and music storage. It was well worth the $30 price difference.  My Kindle is used primarily as a reader but it is also used to play music, watch videos (on my HDTV), and web surfing. It performs extremely well in all of these areas. It is not used for game play so I cannot comments on its' performance regarding them.Pros: Clear and crisp display, Incredible sound for a small device, light weight and extremely portable.  Best of all it quickly and easily transfers e-books borrowed from libraries and friends.Every good quality that "TL" mentioned in his extensive product review of 9/17/12 still holds true.Recent software updates and new free apps address many of the concerns that were mentioned in older reviews such as;  "customer also bought" pop-up ads, software issues, and app problems.Some reviews refer to "side loading" apps; I don't think that's necessary.  Amazon now offers over 57,000 apps with about 28,000 being free. I checked out their list and was able to find every app I needed for free.Cons: Only one very minor complaint, I wish that the screen adjustments that are made available on a book's page as it is being read included a "brightness" control.  As it is configured now you must leave the book, and take six steps in order to adjust the brightness and get back to the book.  If the printed page's brightness is still not to your liking you must redo the entire procedure. I realize that the Kindle has an "automatic brightness" setting, but its' adjustments do not suit my needs.I purchased the " Digitals On Demand 14-Item Accessory Bundle for Amazon Kindle Fire HD 7" " for $40. A great price for all of the accessories that one will need. I am very pleased with the products supplied.  The case fits well and it automatically puts the Kindle into sleep mode when closed and awakens it when opened. All of the cables and chargers provided are of good quality and work properly. I have used the micro HDMI cable many times without any problems.  I consulted a few YouTube videos before applying the screen protector to learn the proper techniques. It was time well spent and allowed me to accomplish a perfect bubble-free application. There is A LOT of good information about Kindles on YouTube.  The included earphones were unusable, very "tinny" sound with no bass response at all. They went directly into the trash.Some have complained about the confusing placement of the micro ports. Put a small dab of "White Out" on the case where the USB port is located and a dab on the top of the USB cable when it's connected, problem solved.The Kindle Fire 7 HD is indeed a great product at a good price, I am extremely satisfied with my purchase.

Reviews.Title: So far I love it
Reviews.Author: Chris R. Hotz "Real reviews.  No fake 5-star"
Reviews.Content: I drove off with my last Kindle on the roof of my car.  By the time I realized it I went back, and it had been run over several times.  Held up pretty well actually...except for the part that it was dead.  I was going to buy a paperwhite, but decided on the Kindle Fire HD.  I love it so far, but it's only been a few days.  We have an iPad II as well, so I'm comparing the Kindle fire to the industry standard.Couple early observations:-The WiFi on the Kindle is faster.  Our iPad gets really slow from time to time.  I've heard it's an issue and have tried everything I find on the forums, but nothing works.-Kindle let me set up MS Exchange Mail in about 30 seconds.  iPad not as easy.-I get books from the Kindle lending library free, you can ONLY do that on a Kindle-Home page is a little over-engineered on the Kindle, but now that I'm used to it, I can get to stuff really quickly, and it's very intuitive.-Screen is very clear.  Amazingly clear.-The quality of the item is much higher than I expected; it's got some mass to it, and feels good in the handBottom line:  For the price difference, the Kindle wins HANDS DOWN.  At $200 it's almost disposable, while the iPad is still crazy high.  Love the iPad, but this device is truly amazing, especially if you like Amazon...which I do.I like Apple products, but I'm actually kind of burned out on their attitude; Apple and their enthusiasts still act like their products are beyond reproach.  Probably time to wake up.

Reviews.Title: I Love My Tablet
Reviews.Author: Ming
Reviews.Content: I bought my Kindle Fire HD at Best Buy three months ago, and at first I was a little hesitant. I've always considered tablets to be this hype thing, but now that I own one I can see why it's so good. I've heard a lot of negative things about the Kindle Fire/Kindle Fire HD but my experience with it has been positive. To me it seems that people either really like it, or really hate. I'll tell you why I really like it.Device Build 9/10:The device is really solidly built and it doesn't feel cheap. It's quite heavy so if you're looking to hold it with one hand be warned that it can be tiring. The rubber in the back really gives the Kindle Fire HD a good grip and to this day I have never dropped it before. I'm taking one point off because the power button and the exterior volume controls are a bit too close for my liking. Several times I ended up locking the device when I wanted to change the volume.Screen 10/10:I have no problems with the screen. Of course it can't compare with high end devices like the iPad, but for the price I think it's very good. And yes it is sunlight resistant, I can read it outside on a sunny day with no problems. As far as graphics are concerned, all my apps seems fine. The pocket edition of Minecraft on this device is beautiful. Video viewing is also good, but I'll get to that later.Battery Life 10/10:I know this is important to a lot of people. I've heard the battery life is horrible on the Fire but this is not true. I watched two two-hour long movies back to back and the battery only went down half. There is an amazing Battery app you download for free that you tell me how long you can watch videos or read with the battery you have. For me, the battery life is amazing.Wi-Fi 10/10:The dual band, dual antenna wi-fi of the Kindle Fire HD is excellent. Even at my college campus, where hundreds of others are using the network, I can stream movies from Amazon with no pauses. It's very fast and I don't see how you can go wrong with it.Reading 10/10:I think the Kindle Fire HD's reading features are perfect. I especially like the highlight function. If you're reading fiction then it might not be all that useful, but for a history major like me who reads nonfiction, the highlighting function saves me a lot of time when I need to take notes and stuff. The interface is smooth, and there is a dictionary integrated into the software. All you have to do is to highlight the word and the definitions will appear.Video 9/10:For some reason, HD video doesn't always work for me. I think that's because it's probably better to view it in standard with my internet connection. But when HD is activated, it's simply beautiful. I love watching videos on my Fire. My only real problem with the video interface is that there is no fast forward button. There is a 10 second rewind, but I don't know why there is no fast forward. Of course you can just drag the progress bar forward but if you're looking for a specific spot in the movie, then dragging it is a bit difficult.Audio 10/10:The audio for me is perfect. The Dolby Audio really makes the device shine. I really have nothing else to say about this.Shopping 10/10:It is so easy to shop with the Kindle Fire HD. The store layout is very neat with a lot of good offers. Who doesn't like cheap or free books?Web Browsing 8/10:Here is where the Kindle Fire HD lacks a little. Most of the times the Silk browser is fast, but it can be a bit sluggish and laggy at times. You can especially see this when you try to type something. The keyboard comes out a second or two later. There is also no built in Flash with the Silk browser. You need to download Dolphin browser and manually get Flash in there. Just pick up any Kindle Fire HD guide and it will tell you how. Watching videos on Youtube is also a bit disappointing. A lot of the videos can't be viewed because it's not supported, and you need to download a Youtube for it (see below). Overall, I would say the browser performs well and it adequately suits my needs. You just have to put up with some minor lag here and there, which is bearable.Apps 8/10:There are a lot of apps missing from the Amazon App Store. Also, I found out that a lot of free apps on iPhone or Android phones aren't available on the Fire, forcing you to go with the paid version. That said, I don't really use the Fire HD to play games so I don't have a lot of game apps on here. You can find most of the big name apps here, but don't expect a lot.Tips:Amazon Prime:If you don't have it already, get it. The lending library system is really, really good. You can borrow a free book every month. I've also compared Prime Instant Video with Netflix. Instant Video has just about all the movies and television series Netflix has. If you're into Korean dramas and Anime, you might be a bit disappointed with Instant Video's offerings compared to Netflix's. That said, there is a large number of popular Korean movies you can watch for free.Advertisements:I just want to put this in here because I see a lot of people complaining about the lock screen ads and the what other people bought ads. I honestly don't get what the big fuss is about. As another reviewer pointed out, how many people really stare at a lock screen? Also, I got some pretty good deals out of it. Opened up my lock screen one morning and saw an offer of $10 gift card with purchase made by Discover Card. Since I use Discover to make all my Amazon purchases, buying a book for $0.99 then getting a gift card is not a bad deal at all.ES File Explorer:This is a must have for the Kindle Fire HD. I see some people complaining that you can't take pictures with the front-facing camera. Not true. The ability to activate the camera is inside ES File Explorer. Also, if you downloaded videos and/or pdfs online and you can't find it, they're also inside ES File Explorer.TubeMate:I'm a bit hesitant to recommend this app because I have bad experiences with it. The Fire has no native Youtube app, and some Youtube videos can't be watched through the browser. A lot of guides recommend TubeMate, which not only allows you to watch videos but also download them. For me the app is extremely slow and it freezes a lot - to the point where I have to restart my device. Use with caution.The Negatives:Battery Percentage:I feel like Amazon should add the battery percentage to the battery bar. To view the percentage, you either have to download the Battery app from the store or go deep into the Settings menu where it's buried.Back Button Doesn't Work:When I'm in the store too long, the back button stops working. When I press back to go back to the main list, nothing happens. I can try fifty times and it still won't go back. The only way to fix this is to go back to the Home Screen and reenter the store.Can't Manually Change Time:I don't understand why the Fire doesn't allow me to manually change the time. For some reason, the clock is occasionally NINE MINUTES SLOW. Twice I was almost late to the work because the clock was wrong.Final Score: 94/100

Reviews.Title: Awesome!,
Reviews.Author: David Jones
Reviews.Content: First off I would like to say I am a huge apple fan and both my daughters wanted iPad minis for Christmas after waiting around on them forever to come out I started looking at other options. I do 99% of my shopping on amazon and always see the kindles advertised. I read a lot of the reviews and decided to give it a try. This thing does not disappoint. The graphics are incredible compared to my ipad2 and it is definitely faster. My daughters love the amazon library and we have both Netflix and now amazon instant video so we are never without something to watch. The value in this tablet alone is worth buying it over an iPad.

Reviews.Title: Here is what I have done with the Fire HD 32 after 3 days
Reviews.Author: Objective
Reviews.Content: Before I describe what I have done with the Fire HD 32 in 3 days, a little about my techie level.Retired, 65 plus, set up one desktop and two laptops on wifi using Century Link Prism router, including Epson Workforce 845 printer wireless.  Kindle DX owner 3 years.OK, here goes:After opening the box, I played with the Fire for a few minutes.  Very intuitive.  The battery level on the pull down "More":"Device" screen was around 35% so I decided to charge it using my 3-year old Kindle DX charger/cord.  That is when I discovered the old cord was defective because when I wiggled it, the "charging" indicator would go off and on - mostly off.  And my DX, after being plugged into that same cord for 4 days prior, was nearly dead.  So I plugged the USB cable that came with the HD into the charger and viola! - charging nirvana.During the first few minutes after turning on the Fire it took a minute or two to download updated software automatically.First, wifi setup.  It found my router immediately.  I punched my 7 digit code into the very responsive keyboard and within roughly 4 seconds I was connected.It took me less than 2 minutes to link both my gmail and yahoo mail accounts to the email program that came with the Fire.  Access to both sets of emails on one device is more than I discovered to do with my desktop - and it set itself up automatically and instantly.  All contacts that I had on yahoo also were visible and revisable on the Fire.Next was my calendar.  I already had my Outlook calender on my desktop linked to a Google calendar.  That combination worked flawlessly.  Connecting the Fire calendar app with my Google calendar took most of 15 seconds.All of my previously downloaded books and cloud music were immediately available on the Fire once I intuitively followed a simple step.The real fun part was downloading and experimenting with several "free", several $0.99, and a couple of $1.99 programs.  The ones I've downloaded so far and really appreciate are:*The Free Dictionary*Calculator Plus*Scanner Radio Pro (listen to public safety and public service radios around the nation/world)*Photo Editor Plus (I quickly learned it is possible to use the Fire as a decent low res camera.  This program isn't necessary, but helps clean up images you take with the Fire or download from other sources.*WiFi Analyzer (very cool real time graphs and wifi data)*Zillow (show details of real estate around the nation)*MapQuest (I wasn't sure Fire did maps and satellite images.  But this program works great.)*eWeatherHD - An excellent, impressive weather program for anywhere in the world.  Very detailed information.*Weather Live - Scroll to any selected City; beautiful interactive background indicating conditions; more basic data than eWeatherHD*TrackIt Deluxe (a hurricane/topical storm tracking program with great satellite images any time of year)*CIA World Factbook*Pandora*TuneIn Radio Pro (select from hundreds/thousands of worldwide radio stations from a variety of categories of programming.)*A variety of other specific, single purpose radio programming apps....and finally, so far, (I sprung for the 13 bucks) PrinterShare Premium to print web pages and notes I create (easy set up and reliable use).The Kindle Fire HD32 exceeded my expectations.  I expect to use this device for most of my laptop and desktop tasks except extended typing.By the way, I don't notice the ads.  And the "Customers also bought" suggestions are appreciated and useful.A solid 5 stars!

Reviews.Title: Best Gift Ever
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: My mom gave me the original first generation for Christmas in 2008. The Kindle Fire HD was for CChristmas this year.She couldn't wait, I ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT. I have told  all my friends about it and they say I should do your ads. I don't even go to the computer any more. My granddaughter wants one.

Reviews.Title: From a parent...
Reviews.Author: A007w
Reviews.Content: Background: My husband I have been iPhone users for awhile now. And I own a Nook ereader (just the black and white kind - so my kids wouldn't borrow it!)For Christmas, my oldest asked for a laptop. After doing some serious thinking and some serious research - I actually bought both of my children (5 and 10 years old) the Kindle Fire HDs. While they have not had the chance to play with them since they are for Christmas - I have played with them extensively (I had to get them all set up for Christmas!) However, I took my kids by a store and walked them by the Kindle Fire HD display. They both immediately went to it and had it figured out within minutes. I love that the learning curve is short and sweet on it!Here are some of my thoughts:The screen quality is amazing! Really, it's the best that I have seen out there. It's just "wow!"The sound is great. My first thought was that I wish it had a plug so my kids could plug in headphones. Then I thought, who am I kidding? They don't use headphones for their DS or any other media device, so why would they start now? So, no headphone ability isn't a big deal for me.Speaking about Nintendo DS, I have had a couple of friends who are parents ask me about getting their kids one. I have since started recommending the Kindle Fire over a Nintendo Ds for a variety of reasons. 1. Games for DS run $20-50 EACH. Apps for Kindle Fire are $0.99 - 2.99 each- a BIG difference! 2. DS games are little and easily lost (and they do lose them frequently!) apps stay where they are suppose to! 3. The obvious... DS plays games. Kindle Fire can do sooo much more.So back to my thoughts: I was nervous being an iPhone user that Amazon wouldn't have the selection of apps that my kids like to play. There was no need for me to worry. Every app that my children play on my phone was available for download to the KF HD.Even more impressive was the amount of books (free or reduced) available for download. Being an avid reader with a nook, I could never find a lot of free books for my nook. I'm sure they are out there, but I didn't have a lot of luck finding them. While downloading tons of free books to my kids kindles, I also downloaded the kindle app to my phone and have started myself quite a collection of books. All of them (for myself and kids) free or under $3.Parental controls: since my children will not be sharing their kindles, I chose not to use the Kindle Free Time that has lots of controls, time limits, and the ability to create profiles. Even without using it, I was able to restrict buying ability from each child's kindle. For my oldest, I left Web browser but was able to block it for the youngest.I love that both kindles are synced to my amazon account. I love that I can buy one app and they both can have it in their kindle. I also love that I can buy an app or book and not have it on the other one if I don't want it there.Next, we love family movie night. While we use Netflix (available for download on the KF HD) there are times that the movie we want to watch isn't on Netflix. We have, in the past, rented a movie from Amazon and used Playon to push it from our home computer to the tv. This isn't ideal as it often freezes or crashes. I LOVE that with the KF HD, you can download the movie to the kindle from Amazon, plug it into the TV, and watch it. While we haven't done this yet, it is a feature that I am very happy about. I look forward to our first family movie night using it!Another great feature: my kids can use it to Skype with their dad in Afghanistan! Awesome!Price: $200 for a kindle and $350 for a mini iPad. Now, keep in mind that after I bought "no ads", covers, screen protectors, and the protection plan for each KF HD, I spent over $300 each. But I would have done the same with the iPad mini and wouldn't have been able to get but one. Then the kids would have had to share which would have been a lot of bickering that I would have had to listen to.My end thought for parents: buy it! Forgo the Nintendo Ds, laptops, and iPod touches. The Kindle Fire Hd has advantages over them all. And the price is reasonable enough that you may find yourself asking for one for Christmas like I am!I will update with the kids thoughts after they get them for Christmas.

Reviews.Title: How did I ever get by without it?!
Reviews.Author: Rebecca Simpson
Reviews.Content: Ok, admittedly this is my first `tablet` so the only thing I can compare it to but, I do have a lot of experience with a variety of smart phones and even have a SmartTV-technology is definitely my friend. I`m just a late bloomer on a budget. I have to say though, I am thoroughly impressed with this machine!I mean, the sound is incredible. I watched a movie last night, with ear buds in, and I felt like I had been to the movies. Clear, rich stereo sound with absolutely no `popping` or distortion of any kind. The picture was clear and crisp from any angle-I kept moving it around to see if what Amazon stated about the screen was true and, it is. Even at 16G I have plenty of room for enough books, videos and apps to keep me busy for a good long time. My Kindle FireHD is now glued to my side. I can't stay away from it. How did I ever do without it? There's a ton of apps to choose from to make the machine truly yours plus enough books for little to no cost to keep me reading for years. Oh, and the battery lasts a good amount of time too. Major bonus there.So far I  haven't had any issues with the FireHD. I'm just enjoying the dickens out of it. And, although it's very user friendly out of the box, I will eventually get around to reading the manual to make sure I'm not missing anything.Like I said earlier, this is my first tablet so I don't have anything to compare it to but, I am definitely impressed and would recommend buying this to anyone willing to listen to me

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 7" Christmas Present
Reviews.Author: Mary Lou Frisbie
Reviews.Content: Because this a Christmas Present we haven't had the opportunity to use it yet. However, we were very disappointed when we opened everything and saw that we had a power cord but no power adapter.  I'm sure if i read more carefully this wouldn't have happened BUT I feel it should have come with a power adapter.  I bought a Kindle Fire last August from Staples and the power adapter was included.  Because of all the hustle of the Christmas Season I just feel it was unnecesssary irritation.

Reviews.Title: Very nice unit
Reviews.Author: Kaliarose
Reviews.Content: First of all, I read many of the negative reviews, especially the one-star, to get a feel for what the negativity was all about.  I decided that a lot of them were 1) petty complaints that didn't have much of a basis, as no one size fits everyone; 2) the reviewer had an agenda of some type, maybe from the competition?; 3) the reviewer sounded like a generally hateful person.I have two iPads.  This is the first Kindle I've worked on, and it's perfect for my needs -- tucking in purse or pocket when I leave home, reading books at night in bed, and watching occasional movies-- those things that can be more difficult with a full-size tablet.  The speakers are great, the screen sharp, it's easy to navigate, and I have all the apps I want.  (Those that aren't available through Amazon I side loaded, not a difficult procedure.) The price is very reasonable.  I saw no reason to get rid of the ads as they're not intrusive.The on/off button was about the only problem I had, as it's flat to the surface, so I just put a dab of soft glue on it.So for me, after doing a lot of research and knowing what my requirements were, this is a nice little tablet.

Reviews.Title: One of the finest tablets
