Reviews.Content: This tablet is indeed fine! it is fine because it is in HD. if you love to watch movies, go for tgis tablet, becauae this one features HD, and dolby digital sound. If you love to read, this is the tablet for you. Kindle also features games to pkay, like angry birds, fruit ninja, etc. i love this Kindle. i am glad i did not buy an Ipad!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: Great for International Travel
Reviews.Author: Satisfied Customer
Reviews.Content: I just purchased this before a trip to Europe.  It worked wonderfully in Europe  for books, Email and SKYPE.  I did not figure out how to access the Web until theend of the trip, but once I figured it out Web access was great also.  I highly recommend the Kindle Fire.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: WOW, I ordered it on November 21, 2012 and received it on the 25th. I ordered it to use for school. It sold for 199 and paid a total of 208.99. That included the plug in wall charger, shipping, and taxes. Can't beat that! Thanks Amazon!!

Reviews.Title: A few more thoughts from a geek user . . .
Reviews.Author: D. W. Koester "dwk"
Reviews.Content: I have had several Kindles, and have now had the Fire HD for several weeks. My main use for a Kindle is reading eBooks, both Mobibooks (Amazon delivered Kindle books and others) and text (.txt) files.  There are some great reviews out there already, so this is just a few more things you may need to know to decide if the new Fires are for you.  I'm kind of a medium duty techno-nerd and can get carried away at times, so skip anything thats greek to you, here goes;As a book reader:You will find that the screen is great to read on. Being illuminated really makes reading in dim lighting much easier on the eyes. The screen is sharp and clear,  and the glare is minimal (don't think you can have sharp + clear + zero glare in the same device). Any glare you do experience can be removed by a small adjustment of your wrist as you hold it,  you won't even have to think about it after awhile,  you'll do it automatically.The reader app itself is pretty good and has, of course, several fonts + background colors + sizes.  One advantage to eBooks is that *all* books are large print if you want them to be <chuckle>. Larger font sizes determine how easy the words are to read, but at the cost of having fewer words per page. I know that's obvious, but I pointed that out just so I could say this; I'm mildly miffed that there is a big jump in the displayed font size between size 7 and size 8, not sure why they did that. I think I would be happiest with a size of 7.5, but its not possible with this reader.  Mebbe future software releases will change this size selection process to something a little more adjustable.  I know, I know,  it's a tiny thing,  but I am used to a certain look from previous Kindles and just want what I'm used to, I'll get over it. It likely won't bother you at all.The dictionary app built into the Reader is stellar.  The old Kindles made you cursor all over the screen to look up a word. The fire HD has you touch and hold the word until a small window pops into existance,  then release it and up jumps a window with the brief lookup for you, including a link to the full definition if you want it. Wonderful. However, unless you are an alien with pinpoint fingers or something,  you will likely need a stylus to select the word you want, especially on the smaller font sizes.  See the accessories section below for more info about that.Another thought abut the reader:  It seems that this reader only wants to read Mobi/Kindle style ebooks,  the older Kindles read text (.txt) style files as well.  This Kindle considers text files + Word files + PDFs as documents and wants to keep them in the Documents folder and open them with the included office clone software. You can convert text + Word files to Mobi books but it will take software to accomplish, I am considering writing a short ebook on how-to for those of you who write stuff you would like to read or share for eReaders, mebbe a 99 cent special if Amazon will carry it,  depends on the response in the comments section, as I'm pretty lazy <grin>.  I should also mention that there is a 3rd party reader for android devices called Cool Reader that reads text and a few other filetypes,  but it is not on the Amazon Apps store and must be side loaded. If I write anything I'll talk about that too,  but google it now and you will be rewarded right away,  side loading is easy.  The main reason to sideload Cool Reader is to avoid having to convert your creations to Mobibooks,  but on the other hand, Mobibooks will let you use that great dictionary function that the Kindle reader has built in. It's always something isn't it?Getting books:Here is where Amazon really shines.  Goto the Amazon ebook store and select your favorite category (fantasy, non-fiction, science fiction, mysteries, childrens, whatever) and sort the results for "price low to high".  You will be able to get at least 10 to 20 free ebooks in each category each and every day,  not counting the short stories, I'm talking full length novels that normally cost money.  BE CAREFUL,  prices can change at any time and the sort isn't perfect,  there will be a few in the list of free books that cost a few dollars and you can accidently buy them if you are not careful about what you are clicking on. Still,  I have gotten over 150 free novels and accidently spent mebbe eight dollars in the past few weeks.  Keep them on Amazons cloud and download them when you are ready to read them to preserve memory.  Life is good, and cheap.Other Issues:The power switch issue:  this hasn't bothered me at all because I have a cover with a magnet in it that tells the Kindle when you have the cover closed and when you open it (see below in accessories).  I turned off the auto sleep function and use closing the cover to put it to sleep and opening it to wake it up.  The only reason I ever use the power switch is to shut the device down (you press and hold the power switch until a shutdown/cancel menu appears).  As a computer geek of long standing,  I think it's a good idea to do a complete shutdown now and then,  nothing like a cold iron restart to eliminate the small errors that creep into any computer that runs constantly, and yes, that includes sleep time.What Kindle still needs;  There is no speech-to-text function available for Kindle,  not that I could find or download,  and that limits the use of personal assistants like Speaktoit in the Amazon Appstore.  Note that I am meaning using the Kindle microphone to accept voice input and convert this audio into typing for an app. Think Siri for cellphones. That's kind of too bad, as it would be alot of fun and very useful,  and it's just a software addition,  not a costly hardware change.What not to worry about;  One thing I worried about before buying was whether to buy the 7" device or wait 2 months for the larger device to be released.  For reading books it's entirely a matter of personal taste,  but there is the technical issue of screen resolution for feeding all that free Amazon Prime stuff to your TV via the mini HDMI port.  The 7" fire is lower resolution. I decided to go with the 7 inch device as it is probably the best size for a portable eReader.  BUT, as it turns out, I found that a better solution for feeding my TV with Amazon Prime material is the Roku 2,  which is 1080p capable and eliminates tethering your Kindle to a TV set with an HDMI cable.  Think of Roku 2 as a really long bluetooth HDMI cable. I'm glad I didn't wait.Accessories:Not everyone needs a cover for their kindle,  and if you are giving one as a gift you might want to hold off on buying one as there are many styles of covers, with different advantages depending on what you want to do with it. I opted for the standard black Amazon cover Amazon Kindle Fire HD 7" Standing Leather Case, Onyx Black (will only fit Kindle Fire HD 7") and have been happy with it even tho it seems a bit pricey when you look at the web page picture.  BUT, it is an absolutely great fit,  the Kindle snaps into it and looks like a million bucks. The leather seems durable, and will protect the edges and corners from reasonable wear and tear. If I was still doing the road warrior thing I would buy one with more padding,  or add a memory foam sleeve to this cover.  If it never left the table by my favorite chair I wouldn't have a cover at all EXCEPT for the wakeup function some covers provide (eliminates the hard-to-find power switch issue, see above).For some things (like using the dictionary, see above) you will absolutely need a stylus (a touch screen pen).  The really cheap ones have a soft rubber bulb on the tip and work fine,  excepting that they are not very long and also tend to drag across the screen with a small amount of resistance.  Better ones have a smooth woven cover (over what I assume is the same rubber bulb) that allows them to glide very smoothly across the screen.  I got HHI Dual Purpose Capacitive Stylus Pen with Soft Nano Fabric Micro-Knit high sensitivity Technology Tip and Fine Ink Ballpoint Pen - Black (For Touch Screen tablet, Cellular Phone, The new iPad, iPad 2, iPhone 4/4s, iPod Touch, Kindle Fire and more) here at Amazon with a nice pen in it that I will never use but like having <grin>. One reviewer says the Pilot G2 Gel refills will fit,  and searching Amazon will yield a bunch of color choices.This pen and cover do well together,  I clip the pen on the outside of the cover spine and have yet to have it try and fall off.Hope all of the above helps,  I'm sure I will realize what I forgot as soon as I punch the Publish button,  but I did the best I could.  Enjoy the new Kindle!

Reviews.Title: Spectacular
Reviews.Author: AMK
Reviews.Content: What can I say--spectacular--and $130 cheaper than the Apple Mini.  I love the Kindle HD.  The screen is beautiful, the sound is great, and it plays Angy Birds.  What else do you need?  I bought it mainly for Angry Birds, Hulu, Amazon VOD, and Netflix--oh yea, and books as well.  Works great. Sometimes when I just want to curl up in bed, but yet I want to catch up on American Horror Story--now I can do it.  Also, I'm the network admin for my company, so I can use Teamviewer to troubleshoot any server problems--right from the same tablet.  Definitely one of the best purchases I ever made.

Reviews.Title: Kindle fire HD
Reviews.Author: SassySteph
Reviews.Content: This kindle fire HD is the best one yet. It ranks right up there wi the iPad and is better I think since I am such an avid amazon shopper. The integration is great and the so is powerful.

Reviews.Title: HOOKED!
Reviews.Author: J. Matuszak "peepers"
Reviews.Content: I am a "senior" and have to admit that I'm not all that tech savvy when it comes to electonics. Heck, my "smart phone" out smarted me! (turned it in for a Blackberry and love it) I can tell you that the Kindle is easy to set up and if you have a problem, the technical team is right there to walk you through any problems that you may have. (technical support is important to me) Downloading books, games or movies is easy. The colors are crisp and vibrant. Some people said that "ads" bothered them, but to be honest with you, I don't get any ads while I'm reading or playing a game. There's ads when you first turn on the Kindle, but just unlock it and go to a game you were playing or to the page you left when you were reading a book. It's not a problem at all. I easily downloaded my i-tunes from my computer, and if you want some of your photos switched to your kindle, that's easy too. For me, it's the perfect size and I'm enjoying this new fangled gadget! I take it with me to appointments and it always make time fly while you're waiting. There are a lot of free books you can download as well as games. I'm glad that I invested in this HD 7" Kindle. The battery lasts for quite a while, but then again, I'm not on it all day long. I just charge it with the UBS cable while I'm on my computer. I am going to look into that plug thing as it is supposed to charge it faster. (Expect to charge it the first time for about 12+ hours) Hope this will encourage older folks like me to give it a try. Trust me, you will be hooked. I bought a Marware cover for it at the same time I ordered the Kindle. (it allows you to set up the kindle so it's proped up) I bought the red one and love it! It's less expensive and works great!

Reviews.Title: My third kindle fire
Reviews.Author: cyberflea
Reviews.Content: Ive only had the kindle fire had for a few hours and I'm most impressed. I have an iPad and iPhone , so I know apple this will surpass the apple iPad in use ability. The sound is great and the eBay browser is very fast. I'm glad I did not buy the apple mini iPad this is a much better buy

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: spencer d. curtis
Reviews.Content: This is a great product at a great price. It's fast, easy to use and the best way to read a book; especially in the dark.Of course it is also a computer just like the Apple Ipad;.so you get your email, Facebook and all the other thousands of Android apps! We bought a Belkin cover which is also great and makes the Fire easier to use.

Reviews.Title: Great improvement over already wonderful Fire.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Combat journalist, media con...
Reviews.Content: I'm a longtime Kindle owner, starting with the Kindle 3, and then Kindle Fire.  I recently bought my wife a Kindle Fire HD for her birthday, and was blown away at the upgrade in quality from the Kindle Fire to the HD (and let me emphasize that I LOVE my old Kindle Fire) ... it's just in a different league.  The vaunted audio improvements are not just marketing hype; it was amazing the first time hearing "surround sound" coming from a 7-inch tablet.  And the picture quality is awesome.  Also side-by-side, the Wi-Fi performance is improved.  For Amazon Prime and Instant Video customers, it's been an issue before that if you own an HD video, you could still only see it in standard definition on the older device, even if you could get it on HD on your smart TV hookup.  You can now see the full HD on the Fire, enhanced by the new sound.  This also applies to HD content on Netflix and other services, of course.

Reviews.Title: FACEBOOK App sucks but love the Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: joel_2112
Reviews.Content: so far so good...love the longer battery time...wish amazon had better app's...we'll see if it improves..if not maybe i'll give the IPad Mini a shot

Reviews.Title: Great Product
Reviews.Author: Joan E. Bencomo "Joan"
Reviews.Content: This is a great product!  A computer in your purse but much lighter weight.  The screen size is perfect and the speed is great.  The folks at Amazon are very helpful--wonderful customer service!

Reviews.Title: Great for reading books aloud
Reviews.Author: Regina Blosser
Reviews.Content: This Kindle Fire HD works superbly as a reader. Its big memory stores many audiobooks and Kindle books, and never runs out of memory space like my older Kindles have. Those better speakers are able to overcome background noise better. The pad displays and controls volume better than my older Kindle models. The 'robovoice'-reader for Fire Kindle books pronounces better and seems to make fewer word and name pronunciation mistakes. If you want a Kindle solely for reading books, both audio and print, this Kindle Fire 7 HD will more than satisfy. It's definitely worth paying about 80 more dollars, even if you never intend to watch movies on it.

Reviews.Title: From an Avarage, Everyday consumer!
Reviews.Author: Famous Starz
Reviews.Content: This is actually the very 1st review I've ever made ever since I went on joining amazon. and just to justify my knowledge of these tablets, I am very Illiterate on all of them, On how they work or what their performances are (Ipads, Nexus7's, Kindles etc.) this is my 1st time owning my own tablet, which is a gift for myself on my bday.Ok so enough of the intro. Let me get to the point. I did said that this Kindle Fire HD is my very 1st tablet. and I just want to let the regular consumer know who are  tempted to buy this tablet, "Get it, It's totally Worth it!" with my little knowledge on how these things work, I find the Kindle HD surprisingly easy to use! and the Visual graphics are outstanding for a 7" tablet! the sounds are really awesome! I even thought about having to use my Beats Headphones as a second option just incase the "HD sound" stated wasn't really that "HD" but people, did my Studio Headphones(beats) never felt so Unneeded. the sound quality on this tablet is superb!.other apps:NETFLIX : totally easy to maneuver for easy movie browsing. and the streaming is really good. I'm really such a fan of Netflix so It's a necessity for my Tablet to stream it Clear(sound, pictures) and easy!.Plants vs. Zombies : Maaaann, playing this game on this tablet made it soo fun. the HD images of the game is really eye catching!Silk : although I prefer using Chrome as my web browser, Silk was actually pretty descent on loading my websites.and there are more APPS to see! alot of them are free such as some games, there's even an RPG game on this tablet O_______o! oh and its free o____________O!!So far I've been really impressed with what i've seen on this tablet. this is really worth the money. $199 for this is a totally reasonable price! specially if your in to streaming movies alot, or reading! and I do apologize for such a simple BASIC review. for I don't really have that much knowledge on these.but, for an average person like me, having this tablet added so much Fun on my "rest time" :) and I'm pretty sure you getting it will make you feel exactly the same way!Hope this helped a bit on your next Purchase!

Reviews.Title: DONT WASTE YOUR TIME WITH A SO CALLED REFURBISHED ONE
Reviews.Author: Bridget K. Long
Reviews.Content: I had a kindle fire that was having an issue charging. I love the kindle product just not the so called refurbished one's.The guy at tech support told me there was no repair option for my kindle and that i would have to buy another one. No big deal mine was over 2 years old. He then talked me into the certified refurbished one. I recieved it and it was awesome. Everything I was expecting it to be. Atleast for the first 2 days. Then the screen had lines going through it. I Iet it sit for 2 hours on the charger then went back to it to find the screen was normal. That lasted 20 minutes and then there were lines through the screen again to the point of where you could not make out what you were looking at. I contacted amazon and they rushed me another one out. Right out of the box had issues with the operating hardware. at least thats what they said when I contacted tech support. To which I asked "Souldn't that have been caught during the certified inspection part?" the reply was evasive and they said they would send me another one right out. I have opted out of thier so called "certified refurbished" exchange program where the only thing certified is that they will pay the shipping to get you another one until YOU find them a returned one that works. This was a stressfull experience!!!!

Reviews.Title: An Excellent Device -- Depending on Your Viewpoint
Reviews.Author: Matthew Coenen "Ah. Books."
Reviews.Content: Not sure writing a review for an item with over 2,100 current reviews will be beneficial, but why not, eh? I know that I read reviews and do my research prior to purchasing an item, so here goes...A DISCLAIMER: The review below, albeit brief, is written under the assumption that the Kindle Fire HD 7" is _not_ a true "tablet" computer. It's a media consumption device and, as such, will not be compared to the Nexus or iPad. That's like comparing Apples to Oranges. To me, that makes little sense.I'm an Amazon fan. I buy books from Amazon. I buy music from Amazon. Heck, I'm even starting to view videos from Amazon -- especially as their interface is constantly improving. I've even been a Prime member for years. That being said, the Kindle Fire HD was the perfect purchase for me, and I have yet to be disappointed.Figure out exactly what you WANT the Kindle Fire FOR before making a decision. Again, it's _not_ meant to be a workhorse for doing your spreadsheets and documents. It _is_ meant to be an insanely easy way to consume your media. Especially if it's from Amazon.PROS:(1) Resolution. Screen resolution is amazing.(2) Sound. Wow. While I typically use my Fire for reading and web surfing, the few videos/movies I've watched sound great -- even without headphones. Amazon did this right.(3) Interface. While I also listed this below, kind of, under #1, the interface is easy to use and figure out. Amazon did this on purpose, surely, as they want the Fire to be as intuituve as possible for a large range of users. From those who have never used a computer to those who are geeks like me.(4) Amazon content. As I mentioned above, the Kindle Fire is meant to be a content delivery and media consumption device. Amazon wants you to spend your money with them and, honestly, why not? Most people buying a Kindle in the first place are already Amazon customers. If not, they soon will be. Again, Amazon has an extremely large library in terms of books and movies.(5) Many see this as a CON, but I disagree: The Amazon App Store. While not as big as the Google Play store, apps on the Amazon store are guaranteed safe and all go through a "process" to be approved. I see this as a good thing, honestly. If you want other apps, you are free to "sideload" them (I've done that for many; it's easy and most work as intended. You just need to know where to go what to do).(6) Silk Browser. Again, listed in both categories. Why? The stock Silk browser works well. Honestly, it's not bad. But if you're use to a more robust feature set, you will want another option.(7) Family stuff/security. I don't have kids, and I don't share my Kindle with other people. If you do, though, the parental controls on the HD look to be rather neat.(8) Fast WiFi. Enough said. You won't be disappointed.(9) Other services supported. Like Netflix. Hulu+. Etc. While Amazon wants to be your main content provider, they aren't so stingly as to shut out other services.(10) Customer Service. Amazon is known for their amazing customer service. And when it comes to the Kindle, responses are still quick and reliable.CONS:(1) Amazon is becoming proprietary much like Apple. While this isn't strictly a con -- especailly from a business sense -- it's frustrating for those of us who know the Android platform can do so much more and do not want to "root" our Kindle.(2) Stock touchscreen keyboard is of the ancient "hunt/peck" variety. Amazon really does need to get on the "Swype-style" bandwagon here. Imagine how much more I'd use my Kindle if I didn't have to tap out reviews, e-mails, etc.(3) No 3G availablity with 7". Again, from a business standpoint, this makes sense. Should be an option, though. (WiFi, fortunately, is available at more places now than ever. Shouldn't be an issue for many. And you can always download movies/books prior to a trip. Especially if you get the 32GB memory.)(4) Ability to "organize" your books into collections. Wow. This is a basic need and is offered on the e-Ink Kindles. Somebody dropped the ball on this one!(5) Silk browser. No. Not so good. Not so bad, either. If you use the Internet a lot, you'll want something else.(6) No "wall charger." The Kindle comes with a USB charger. Period. If you want the wall charger, you pay $10 extra IF you get it when you buy your Kindle. I did NOT, so I'd have to shell out $20. (I did ask Amazon customer service if I could get it for the $10 price but never received a resopnse. This is the ONLY time I've never received an immediate reply from their customer service department. Probably because it was a silly question and wasn't worth answering. It was my fault, after all!).

Reviews.Title: Helpful info - Why I bought the KFHD
Reviews.Author: J Coops
Reviews.Content: For those of you considering buying the 7" Kindle Fire HD, here is some important information that I think will be helpful.  There are enough reviews talking about the hardware specs, so I won't cover that here.PRIME - the KFHD comes with one free month of prime membership.  If you aren't planning on using Amazon Prime after that one month, I would get a different tablet.  The direct link to streaming so many instant videos is one of the main reasons I got this tablet. (Price = $79/year + tax)ADS - the drama around the "Special Offers" was way overdone.  I ONLY see ads on my lock screen, which only shows when I first turn it on. In the first few weeks of owning my KFHD, I specifically remember receiving a free $5 credit for the amazon mp3 store, a free $5 credit for the amazon instant video store, and a deal to buy any album from the amazon mp3 store under $10 for $3.  Point being - I could have spent that money to remove the ads, but instead I now own 2 cd's and rented a movie I'd wanted to watch for a while.CHARGER - IF (big IF - you can use almost any wall-usb plug to charge the KFHD) you need a wall-USB charger, one option is to ORDER the following charger WITH the KFHD to get a $10 credit on the charger (full price $20) Amazon Kindle PowerFast for Accelerated Charging (not included with device, for use with the new Kindle Fire or Kindle Fire HD models).  Additional price to KFHD purchase = $10 (comes with a $3 Amazon mp3 credit).Personally, I bought an accessories bundle for $30 that came with all I will need - cases/chargers/screen protector/cables, etc.  DigitalsOnDemand ® 14-Item Accessory Bundle for Amazon Kindle Fire HD 7", Dolby Audio, Dual-Band Wi-Fi, 16 GB 32 GB (Does not fit Kindle Fire HD 8.9 and older model Kindle Fire)LAGGINESS - there is often a sense I have of the tablet moving slowly, whether it's when I'm selecting something from the carousel or browsing around the different stores (video, mp3, libraries, etc.), it tends to just hang.  Sometimes this makes me hit buttons I didn't want to because I can't tell if my first tap registered or not. The wifi works fast and content isn't affected, but the device itself does tend to just "hang" for a couple seconds.  Having previously owned a Droid and currently an iPhone, I'm not used to having to wait for things to open! How big of a problem is this - minimal, but minor frustrations affect different types of people in different ways! This is my basis for 4-stars vs. 5-stars.CONCLUSION - WHY I BOUGHT ITI decided to buy the KFHD for the video streaming, e-book reading, and overall experience that Amazon is known for.  The tech specs are more than up-to-par and the screen looks fantastic.  Sure, there are better tablets out there, but in my opinion this tablet is not meant to be compared directly with the iPad, its purpose is to provide a direct link to everything Amazon offers.  Since I bought the KFHD, I have definitely become more active in using Amazon for purchases than before, and have made my way through 2 seasons of a tv show I'd been wanting to watch (included with Prime membership).  Amazon's plan to offer the entire Amazon experience through a well-priced, well-made, user-friendly tablet worked for me.  If that's what you are looking for in a tablet, look no further.

Reviews.Title: Superb Tablet !
Reviews.Author: Dennis R. Mountain
Reviews.Content: I have owned my Kindle Fire HD 7" for 1 month and love it. Navigating through the various menu's is very easy. The screen resolution is amazing. It rivals the clarity of my flat screen TV in it's color depth and contrast. I have not yet tried any videos but have up loaded pictures and they are excellent. The Wi-Fi works without any problems with wide range. I have purchased a few games and they play flawlessly. Reading even in sunlight is very easy on the eyes. I recommend purchasing a stylus so as not to scratch the screen with your finger. I also purchased the Amazon hard case with stand as I carry mine in a fanny pack while biking. This provides excellent protection from bumps and scrapes. All=in-all an excellent buy.

Reviews.Title: Great user experience - Incredible value - it just works
Reviews.Author: Columbus-techie
Reviews.Content: The device continues to perform flawlessly.  Kudos to Amazon for a well executed platform.  "It just works" seems to be my resounding opinion.  Having other much more expensive tablet devices, i continue to be amazed at what they have accomplished at this price point. Undecided?  Visit your local electronics store and put one in your hands.Common Questions:How the streaming video?  Amazing - Screen is bright and clear.  HDMI output works greatHow are the speakers?  Clear and loud for the size.Is the wifi really that good?  YES!  i can see three times the number of networks  versus any other wifi device in my house, and it holds a much more reliable connection at the edges of coverage.  "It just works".Can you customize and configure all the settings?  Not to the extent you can with other devices.  Out of the box (non-rooted) this is likely not a good choice for the tinkering type.Why is the bezel around the screen so wide?  So you can hold onto it without interacting with the screen.  After using it for a month, i cannot imagine it NOT having this area.

Reviews.Title: I Am So Excited and IN LOVE with My Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: C. Papin "I LOVE Amazon!"
Reviews.Content: I ordered a Kindle Fire HD 7 for both me and my sister and I have to tell you it has been non-stop action since I pulled it out the box and charged it two weeks ago!Let's start out with...SCREENCrisp, clear PERFECT!!!!  The colors are rich and intense, vibrant (and it's so nice to read my books from a larger screen than my phone, watch movies that seem to "POP" out of the screen and play games with glorious color)Also I like the Lock Screen Ads that are there (not obtrusive) and they do seem to be geared towards what I like...I have gotten more new music and a few books and movies as a result (the ads don't bother me)SOUNDThe sound is awesome....very crisp and clearBUILDThis is the first device that my sister and I have owned, and I like it's sleek design and how cozy it feels in my hands.  I love the rubberized backing (helps with grip)BATTERY LIFEI'm impressed - I can actually watch 3 movies, play and hour and half worth of racing (Adrenaline 7) and listen to a couple of hours of music before I have to charge.  I put my devices through a workout.EXPERIENCEThere is nothing like Netflix and Huluplus+, nothing like listening to your favorite music from your Cloud or reading your favorite book, surfing and downloading the latest apps (I just wish Google Play was available for Kindle Fire but uhhhhhhh I have it on my phones ....stop being mean and play fair with each other you two!) I REALLY want Google Play on my Kindle Fire....So far the device has not "crashed" with all my activity - just makes the experience even better!(My only gripe with my Cloud - (this has nothing to do with the Kindle Fire) When I uploaded "explicit" content the upgrade replaced my "explicit" files with "edited" files - not good! (Xzibit and Ice Cube and DJ Quik do not sound good "bleeped") Also I am very ANAL about album covers - so when the wrong covers are added to an album that drives me BATTY! I can remove them from the Cloud, but the wrong covers still show up on my Kindle Fire and I hate that! This is why I LOVE my Google Play because I have COMPLETE control over everything from tracks to album covers...)OVERALL SATISFACTIONI'm in LOVE with my Kindle FireFor the price and the features, this is an extreme media device (and I LOVE MEDIA OVERLOAD);-)

Reviews.Title: Very nice device at a great price.
Reviews.Author: Chung
Reviews.Content: I am not such a tech person and the most I do with my tablet is skype, email, browse web, and watch movie. I find fire HD fits both my needs and budget. It is light, fast and the picture quality is just fantastic. I can't possibly ask for more with $199!

Reviews.Title: I love it
Reviews.Author: S. Robinson "Book Goddess"
Reviews.Content: I have had my fire hd since the release date and so far I love it. I am a previous owner of the original apple ipad (which I found to be too large). I also own the second generation kindle (which I still use today). I must say that this device has worked great for me so far. I work at home so I am able to watch free movies using my prime membership and the advertisements have even been great. I was able to get a $5 credit for music and a $5 credit for movies just by taking advantage of the advertisements that comes across as my screen saver. 3 thumbs up!!!

Reviews.Title: Very good product. Very happy.
Reviews.Author: Charles Hamman
Reviews.Content: Received it two day ago and it is very well built.Outstanding screen display and the ad's are not as horrible as other reviewers have complained about.The touch screen takes a bit of getting used to, and the learning curve on using it is not bad at at all.Using the built in browser on internet forums is good, no need for 3rd party apps to read or post on thatI have found. Great to keep up with mail and people, especially if you do not have a cell smartphone whenout and about. Beats lugging my laptop with me.The only downside other than being more clear about not having a charger included, is they could havesaid it was needed if you did not have anything that needed usb chargers at all. Or if you did that mostwall warts do not have the output to properly charge it.When reading one has to be careful about the touch screen because you can turn pages unintentionally veryeasily.The amazon apps that are available at this point is limited compared to Google's play store. But I hopethe selection of apps will improve in time. For example my local news station has an app that can notbe found anywhere other than at the play store.Seeing that this is a new product, and knowing amazons history of paying attention to users complaints.I am sure that the shortcomings of this tablet will be addressed in future firmware updates as they havedone so with their other kindles, excluding the kindle dx.

Reviews.Title: Much better than expected. Close to Nexus 7
Reviews.Author: Paul Lockwood "Paul Lockwood"
Reviews.Content: == Update @ Nov 25th 2012==Since the latest Nexus 7 Firmware update I recommend it over the Fire HD. Great multi-user support for one is really useful; Amazon's is very lame in comparison.The Nexus 7 is faster, has an unrestricted Android market but I find myself using the Kindle Fire HD more.The sound is _really_ good. The Fire HD is way better than the Nexus 7 for watching movies and reading books. No YouTube app but via the web is fine. As of Oct 2012 the Fire HD's web browser is not great; it has crashed on me + is somewhat clunky.In general I use the Nexus 7 on the go for FlipBoard/ rss reading + use the Fire HD at home for watching movies/ short videos in bed. Also it's handy to read books if my eInk Kindle is not to hand - page syncing across devices is handy.Great sound and easy access to 'free' Prime movies/ TV shows are where this device shines. X-Ray is great for checking who minor actors are.

Reviews.Title: Does What I Want it To
Reviews.Author: Old Fisherman "Jim"
Reviews.Content: This is the first tablet I've owned, don't even have a cell phone of any kind, so this whole technology was new to me. My main reason for buying the Kindle Fire HD was for an entertainment device. I have two trips to Europe coming up in the next six months and from my home in California those are 10-12 hour flights. And I don't sleep on a plane. And many times, too many times, the airline "entertainment" center built into the seat backs don't work or work poorly.My requirements for the Kindle Fire were pretty basic, I wanted to be able to watch movies and listen to music on a plane where Wi-fi is not available. I also wanted to be able to do some basic web-surfing and check my e-mail when Wi-fi is available. And, being a Kindle, I wanted to use it as a book reader. I'm happy to say it does everything I wanted it to. The graphics and the sound are both outstanding. The screen is a little small but not really that bad. I've watched one long movie on the device already and the screen size was not a problem for me.Anyway, I've had the device for about a week now. I've been able to load some of my own movies from DVD onto the Kindle, I've loaded some music, and I've purchased a few books. I've used it to check my web-based e-mail, and even bid on an eBay item (which I didn't win). I leave tomorrow for the east coast to visit some relatives and I've even been able to load some videos and photographs from last year's trip to Germany onto the Kindle Fire so I can show them to my relatives.The downsides? I guess the biggest one is the lack of any documentation on how to use the tablet. There is some built in documentation but I've found it lacking so there has been a lot of trial and error. However if you have any computer skills at all it should be easy for you to figure out. And I'm sure that people who have had Android phones or other tablets will pick it up immediately. So, all in all, I'm happy with my purchase and I'd recommend the Kindle Fire HD.

Reviews.Title: This is Great!
Reviews.Author: Jeremy
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire HD, it's quite the tablet, you know, for being made "not" as a competitor to the iPad 3. I'll just start off by saying that there are four types of Kindle Fires now; The Original fire, The Kindle Fire HD with a 7" screen, The Kindle Fire HD with a 8.9" Screen, and The Kindle Fire HD with a 8.9" screen and 4g LTE Wireless. I have the Fire HD with a 7" screen. It has exceeded any expectation for everything except apps. Now I did get my kindle for school and for my textbooks, and books in general, but having some fun at home is not bad thing. The Fire is on the Android App store (also known as Google Play) but it requires specially made apps because most apps are made for smaller screened Android Phones.  So you have to do some digging to find some good apps. Also, a lot of the good apps cost money, and well most of the apps cost money, but if you don't mind spending a few dollars here and there, you should be fine. Now apps like Skype, or Facebook, and most other social apps are made for the Kindle, so that was a sigh of relief. Besides the apps that can't be removed and are already on the kindle when you open it up, Skype is on there. So I was already messaging my friends within the first five minutes of booting it up. The Carousel, or the "Home Page" is decent, some people think that it's too sleek and does not work well, but I don't mind it. If you have Amazon prime and you want a tablet, Kindle is the way to go. I say this because with Prime, you can get free movies and free books. Not all movies and books are for free, but they have a pretty good selection of Movies and Books.  The book borrowing is basically a library, but you can only get one book per 2 weeks or so. This is good if you're not the fastest reader, but you enjoy reading. Now with the Fire HD, Amazon added better sound quality, a microphone, and a camera. In the Original Fire, the sound was just awful, or so I've read, so Amazon upgraded and added Dolby sound, which is amazing. The microphone is pretty good, I haven't used it all that much, but it's good from when I've used it. The camera, with the kindle, there is no camera app, you have to get one, usually free on the app store. Another down side is it only has one camera, and that's right next to the screen so it faces you, which prevents things like bar code scanning, forgetting your camera pictures, and it's probably my least favorite part. But all in all, if you don't mind less apps, or  some camera annoyances, the Kindle Fire HD is a great product.

Reviews.Title: Must Have for Amazon Junkies
Reviews.Author: strangerwithcandy
Reviews.Content: The ability to stream movies and music as well as play games, check your email, surf the web, or read a book is an absolutely great thing to have in the palm of your hands.As an original Kindle Fire owner, I was most excited about the HD display in this model and it doesn't disappoint!  Movie images, as well as the carousel icons and e-book reading app are crisp and the colors vibrant.  The sound is also great on this model, much better than the original or any other tablet I've heard for that matter.  It is loud and clear.  There is not much bass feedback, but what they were able to do with such small speakers is pretty incredible.  I usually use a decent pair of ear buds when I want to hear all of the bass so that pretty much negates that concern.I love that there is now volume buttons on the device itself which saves you from having to open the settings menu to adjust it.  However, the buttons themselves, along with the power button, sit pretty flush with the outside and are hard to find with touch alone.  I often find myself pushing on the speaker grooves along the perimeter, mistaking them for the buttons.The touch screen on the Fire HD is MUCH more responsive than the original and typing on the keyboard is not such a pain anymore.  I have not noticed much of a reduction on glare in high light sources which is mentioned in the descriptions.  If there is any, it is minimal.  Still not something you're going to reach for when heading to the beach.The model is significantly less bulky and lighter than the original but I still found it awkward to hold in one hand.  And if you are going to watch a lot of video then some kind of stand is a must.  And again, consider a decent pair of ear buds if bass is important to you or just so you don't annoy the person sitting next to you on the plane.All in all I think everything runs a lot smoother on the new Fire, but there are a few annoying force closes, mostly while using the e-book reader.  If you lock the screen while reading a book, when you go back the screen will quit responding until the reader force closes.  This is a bit absurd as this was the Kindle's original purpose and hopefully it is sorted on it in a future update.As far as apps go, I have noticed that some of the apps that ran on the original Fire won't run on the Fire HD.  I'm not sure if it's a resolution thing or what, but it was a little annoying to find out when I went to re-download them on my new device.  We do finally have a dedicated Facebook app, but still inexplicably, no YouTube app.  Netflix and Hulu Plus are both available as is Pandora.  But the Amazon app store is still lacking while compared to the Google Play store.  I really wish they would just open it up so we could shop the Play store.  I really can't imagine it eating away that much of Amazon's business.Also, for some unknown reason, the Kindle Fire does not ship with a charger.  It comes with an USB cord and can only be charged while connected to a computer.  This is not really mentioned in the product description.  You can use the original's charger if that's all you have but be prepared to let it charge for about 10 hours as the battery life of the HD model is considerably larger.  Otherwise, you can buy a rapid charger from Amazon for 10 dollars at the time of purchasing the Fire HD.  If you don't purchase it while purchasing the Kindle, the price goes up to 20.  I think this is kind of a cheap tactic on Amazon's part and they should just include the charger with the product.There have been concerns about he inclusion of offers on the lock screen and recommendations on the carousel.  I did not find these in the least bit intrusive.  In fact some of the offers on the lock screen are quite good.  Chances are, if you buy a Kindle, you are already a frequent Amazon shopper anyway.  And if they really bother you that much, there is a way to opt out of them for 15 dollars.  But I can't imagine wanting to.The Kindle Fire is a great buy if you are already a frequent Amazon buyer, Prime member, or just looking for a cheap tablet with a lot of bang of your buck.  Not an IPad killer by any means, but I love mine all the same!

Reviews.Title: The wait was worth it!
Reviews.Author: H. Sweany
Reviews.Content: I cannot say enough positive things about my Kindle Fire HD. The picture and sound is amazing. It is fast and seamless on the internet. The on-screen keyboard is easy to use and comfortable.I would also like to add, Amazon was great when my first order was lost in shipment. They are uber-attentive and concerned about making things right and getting the shipment corrected (a little overboard in some cases-but that is better than not).Love Amazon, always have and will remain a faithful customer.Now back to Dr. Who on my Kindle Fire HD.

Reviews.Title: Love this little booger!
Reviews.Author: A.J.
Reviews.Content: I ordered this for my son's 6th birthday and so far so good. My 4 year old loves the apps on this little booger. It keeps my kids extremely entertained. I personally like the parental controls and the fact that I can block them from ordering and viewing certain items. It's very self explanatory as well, very easy to use, and very addictive! This Kindle Fire HD is AWESOME for ALL ages!

Reviews.Title: Love my Kindle Fire HD!!
Reviews.Author: Kimberley
Reviews.Content: I have never owned a tablet, always two versions behind on anything I own, but after I saw the specifications on the Kindle Fire HD, I bought one. Let me tell you, I am not disappointed! I love it, I am a novice, and it is very easy to use. I still can't believe I thought about buying an IPAD over this. I really don't want a camera or video on my tablet because I own a camera and a camcorder. For $200, you cannot beat this. I am 46 years old and having a blast with my new toy!

Reviews.Title: Great product...great value!
Reviews.Author: buffalogal
Reviews.Content: My teenage daughter recently received an ipad for her high school graduation and I was planning on getting one for Christmas, until Amazon released the Kindle HD. I had delayed purchasing an ipad because I felt that spending $500 on a tablet that I would primarily use for reading the news, books, magazines, and browsing the internet, seemed like too much to spend. I'm already a huge Amazon shopper, used to have the original Kindle, and am a heavy user of the Kindle app on my iphone.  So purchasing the Kindle HD seemed like a no brainer and I am extremely happy with my choice. I ordered the power charger, case and screen protector when I placed my original order, so I didn't have any big issue with the lack of a charger being included with the unit. I had planned on paying the $15 to get rid of the ads, but once I got the unit, I realized they were not bothersome at all, and in fact, I have already taken advantage of a couple of the deals for discounts on books, music and videos, all things I currently buy regularly anyway. I love everything about my Kindle! The size is perfect! I originally was going to purchase the larger Kindle HD, but didn't want to wait. I'm glad I bought the 7". I like the size much better than my daughter's ipad. It fits easily into my fairly small purse to take with me on shopping trips or appointments, yet it's big enough to enjoy watching movies. The HD screen is amazing! I am a Prime Member and watch TV shows and movies from Amazon and Netflix and the sound/picture/size is perfect for me!  It's my favorite way to read the news.....and I love reading books, and especially magazines on the Kindle. The pictures and graphics look gorgeous! Apps are much more limited on the Kindle HD which I'm sure will improve with time, which might be a deal breaker for my teenagers, but not for me. They have every app I would be interested in, including my favorite basic games, cooking apps (Big Oven and AllRecipes), a notes app, news channels, SKYPE and Netflix.In any case, the unit has the perfect functionality at the perfect price point for me. $199 plus $10 for the power charger, given how much use I get out of this Kindle, is a great value! I have no need or desire to purchase an ipad now. I do not need the additional functionality, so the additional cost would be wasted money that I can spend on purchasing the books, music, magazines and videos I would use on either tablet. Admittedly, I was already a faithful Amazon marketplace customer, which makes this tablet even more attractive to me, but anyone purchasing a tablet needs to really decide what functionality they will truly need/use. If they are like me, and will use it primarily for entertainment and browsing the internet, the Kindle HD is an amazing value!

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD worth it
Reviews.Author: William L. Lipton Jr. "Bill Lipton"
Reviews.Content: Well, to see if a Tablet was worth it, I bought a discounted Pandigital (out of box, it handles PDF but not Mobi book formats).  Liked it enough to take advantage of the pre-order opportunity for Kindle fire HD.  I write, and currently have three books on Kindle (plus global outlets), so getting a Kindle made sense.First thing you'll notice is the packaging.  I also ordered the wall-charger and the custom case; everything came in one box.  Individually, the packaging is rugged and well designed -- with everything protected, but easily removed.  The kindle dropped into the custom leather case as snug as you could want.  Only problem -- no place for pens (if you don't use a pen, get the screen protector).  At every initial power on, First Screen shows "LOCKED" and padlock image ... just touchscreen slide it to left and you're good to go.What really sold me was the idea of being able to watch HULU & NetFlix while laying in bed, like I would read a book.  Like any computer, took some getting used to, and set-up of the type which reconfigured my nearly 70-year-old brain more than the Kindle Fire.  But, once I located the correct Mobile apps, I was blow-away.  As for the sound quality ... beats my BOSE Radio.I haven't gotten in to the Cloud Storage app yet, that will be played with later today; it will also be a while before I really play with the free month of PRIME access.  Obviously, there are a few more customizing issues, but I generally budget three of four days for setting up a new computer, so no big deal there.  The HELP screens are -- takes a bit of getting used to for pull-down windows to access Bluetooth, etc.  But the wireless connecting was virtually automatic.  Still trying to determine the value of being able to Bluetooth connect to laptop ... would be nice is I could data-transfer that way.  OH, you might want to get a HDMI adapter (though not sure what mini size Fire takes, I assumed a D).  Depending on amount of typing you do, a Bluetooth keyboard and headset might be a good addition.The image quality is fantastic: crisp, sharp, vibrant ... add your favorite superlative and it applies. I've only had it two days, so there is a lot more to learn.  Transferring data/files between laptop and Kindle is on the agenda.  The charger is "cute" and works with the supplied USB cable that also allows charging from computer/laptop USB port.Setting up Skype was initially a problem -- never try to do it on an unplanned incoming call -- but once I got it going I know the Kindle will free-up my computer.  I haven't figured out if I can take pictures with front camera; nor have figured out how to locate download locations (sorry, out time hands on & inside type from the breadboard days of computing, so need that 'look inside' bit).FIVE STAR ... no question about it. I'm sure there are 'negatives' and somebody will post them, but, so far, the only negative is my learning curve.  Once I find something the first time, I am discovering just how intuitive the layout really is.  As of now, the biggest problem is that the case has no place to store for a touch-pen ... they could have added a holder between Fire and lid -- something a standard touch-pen would clip in to and be locked in when lid is closed.  When lid closes, the Fire goes to sleep. For those who are concerned with unauthorized access, there are passwords & security & "parental control" settings available, but I don't use them. I would not hesitate to get one of these for my kids as a present.

Reviews.Title: Kindle HD 7"
Reviews.Author: Stump Jumper 42
Reviews.Content: Just got my new HD 7" and man what some great improvements they made from my orignial kindle fire. Love the new email app that comes with it. Key board is bigger for these fingers of mine and the HDMI for the TV is just what the doctor ordered. I down load movies to watch at work and watch on TV at home now with no buffering on my slow wireless internet. Its thinner and lighter and wider. Tested Skype with the wife and it works great. Just very happy with the up grades. I thought I was happy with the Kindle Fire and it is a good tablet but these upgrades make it even better. Way to go Amazon!

Reviews.Title: ITS SO FAST!
Reviews.Author: Dusty
Reviews.Content: First, the audio that this puts out without being connected to anything is very impressive, streaming any sort of video there is no problem with hearing whatever you are watching. In addition to the new audio the Wifi connection is incredible! I manage a restaurant that feels like it could probably double as a bomb shelter so the wifi can get pretty shotty in areas of the place. Normally at the bar area the wifi is almost impossible to use but with the Kindle it picks everything up and it works just great at work on a weak signal. The OS is sleek and easy use plenty of apps to choose from for all sorts of tasks, very happy with this.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire2--Best birthday gift ever!!
Reviews.Author: Felly
Reviews.Content: Thank you Amazon for giving my granddaughter "the best birthday gift ever" as she put it. It arrived exactly on her birthday 9/17. It is the perfect gift for her or anybody. It is on par with my ipad2. The problem is her older sister also want one for Xmas.  So I will definitely be buying another Kindle Fire2 on Christmas. Amazon is the best!

Reviews.Title: Compare FIRE HD to the KINDLE FIRE GEN 2
Reviews.Author: clickz4 "clickz4"

} } } Length:: 2:29 MinsUPDATE: I bought both a Fire HD and a Gen 2. (as a present to my mother in law) My initial reviews were written after playing with them for like 20 minutes. I merged both reviews into one to really compare the two products. I'll be answering questions in the comments all weekend. And see the video that compares the two and gives a mini tour of the kindle system.My Background: I've had 4 android phones, I've had multiple e-readers and my latest 'touch' device is the Le Pan II Android tablet. I've worked on several iPads but never been compelled to spend the extra money for one myself. Wife has a first generation Fire.============The new Kindle Fire and Fire HD are the second generation color kindle e-reader/media player/tablet devices. The original Fire received a lot of well earned 4 star reviews. It was a great product but at the end of the day, it was a first generation product. It was no iPad slayer. The Fire HD raises the bar and raises it quite a lot. Jeff Bezos said they set out to make the best tablet available period and -in some regards- they did that in spades. In other ways not so much. (more on this below in the closing thoughts)HARDWARE:BUILD QUALITY:- BOTH are top Notch. I didn't expect anything less from Amazon but they really are solid feeling.- FIRE HD lighter and while it is about the same thickness, the edges are rounded more like an iPad. sleeker look and more comfortable to hold.- FIRE GEN 2 is heavier and 'boxier' built to more fit existing covers I guess. It's heavier too.SIZING:The HD is just a bit taller but a decent bit wider than the Fire. --- NOTE pay attention to accessories because THEY ARE NOT THE SAME SIZE. The cover from my wife's Gen 1 Kindle will fit the Gen 2 kindle (sorta) but NOT THE HD.THE SCREEN:- FIRE HD SUMMED UP IN TWO WORDS Oh. My. The Le Pan, the iPads and the Gen 2 Fire all have great screens. The Fire HD takes them all out. I read somewhere there was polarizing a filter over the Fire HD screen. Polarizers reduce glare by only letting 'straight' light though not off angle bounced light. This makes an enormous difference to this display. The off angle viewing is probably the best I have seen in any flat screen. 6 stars.- FIRE GEN 2 Still a high quality screen. I'd same the same or better than any other high end tablet on the market.- NOTE A few people in the comments asked about the touch response. I don't have a problem with either. Both worked very well.THE WIFI.- FIRE HD I admit only the geeky probably care but the wifi rocks. I have this mimo router and one quick copy from my server and I was getting almost 30MB/s. To put that into perspective, that's about as fast and an external USB Hard drive can push data to your computer. (USB 3.0 will be faster but they are rare today) -- The other thing is that I have a long skinny house and when I'm in the back bath, the Le Pan drops off. (ahem not that I surf on the potty or anything, just when I test it, you know.) With the Fire HD I can surf in the back yard.- FIRE GEN 2 still got 20MB/sec. But consider this. At that speed you can fill the entire memory in 5 minutes. Seems good enough to me.THE SOUND:- FIRE HD ok I'm a bit of an audio snob. The sound is fantastic for being a tablet. Which is to say it's still only marginally acceptable. You can still buy a $15 pair of Koss KSC75 headphones and blow the speakers away BUT I will say this is the first device I would actually listen to music on. The rest I simply don't even bother. I suspect most people would call the sound excellent.- FIRE GEN 2 still have a very good sound. For the spoken word it would be very fine. For music it is lacking in my book.SPEED: Both are quick with the HD being quicker. The Le Pan II is no slouch but I think the HD edges it out. Since the Le Pan apparent died this morning it's hard to compare. :-(NOTE: IT DOES NOT COME WITH A WALL WORT CHARGER It comes with a micro USB cable that can be used with your existing USB wall worts. (ie your cell phone charger) You can buy a rapid charger for it or even plug it into your computer to charge. This is an odd choice from Amazon IMO.NEW FEATURES (as promised)EXCHANGE CALENDAR SYNC:BOTH - Exchange on the Fire (both) just rocks. I really like the calendar app. The contact manager can't keep up with the one on the iPad but it is sufficient. Ditto the email. But the setup was easy and it seemed fast. Love it.SKYPE:- FIRE HD Spent way too long video skyping today. It worked as well as skype ever works. (long time skype users will understand that) yes it was glitchy but less than other platforms so no complaints. The sound really made a difference here.- Fire GEN 2 I don't think Skype came in it. I'll update with a definitive later.HDMI- FIRE HD ONLY I promised someone in the comments to test this soon but I misplaced my HDMI cable. (drat) will find it this weekend and test. Watch this space.BLUETOOTH- FIRE HD ONLY worked very smoothly pairing with LG tone. (great product btw) I'll be using that for Skype in the future.FREETIME: BOTH This is a widely requested feature that allows multiple users (i.e. kids) to log in and have their own customized tablet experience. It also allows parents to limit the time kids spend on certain tasks, like watching movies, while giving them unlimited time to read. Parents have been asking for this forever. (Are you listening Apple?) Early reports on this are good but I'll have more on this in a few hours too.CLOSING THOUGHTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS:If you're new to Kindle make sure you understand what you are buying here. Kindles are made -and sold at a highly discounted price- to allow you to purchase media from Amazon. Don't think of this as an android tablet, because it really isn't. Yes Amazon uses the Android operating system but you'd never know they hide it so well. This device is made (basically) exclusively to read/watch/listen to media you buy from Amazon. In that regard this device is about as fantastic as they could make it. HOWEVER. The Kindle Fire (first generation) was notorious for not playing well with many Android apps. If you're a app monster or looking for something to replace your laptop to allow you do work on the road and occasionally consume media, you need to look at an Android tablet or an iPad. But don't let that discourage you:Via Amazon Prime, you get 25,000 streaming movies and T.V. shows you can watch 24/7 unlimited. We dropped Netflix because Prime Instant Video was so good. Amazon gives you a free month with the either Fire so you'll get to see the value before you buy. (it's a no brainer btw) There are also over a million free books available for the Kindle. I try to limit how many I buy/download but I have over 100 books on my previous Kindle that are waiting to be read, all but like 4 of them were free. Also if you own a Kindle and subscribe to Prime, you can borrow one book per month from the Paid section. And big name books too... all 7 Harry Potter books are up there. If you figure that is worth at least 10 bucks a month, you're getting $120 of content per year and Prime only costs (I think) $79. Or looked at another way, that's $240 in content in two years and the Fire HD is only $199.If you're new to e-readers, owning one might just change your life. I had probably read 8 book length books in the last decade. (I'm a periodical junkie.) I now read at least one book per week. I was a big reader before but I'm reading more than I ever have in my life. Many studies show that people are reading as much as 3X more when they get an e-reader. If you're a parent looking to inspire a love of reading in a child, STOP. DO NOT PASS GO, DO NOT COLLECT $200. Buy them an e-reader.SO THE BIG QUESTION, WHICH ONE DO I BUY?- If you're on a VERY tight budget the Fire Gen 2 is a great product at a great price point. Coupled with Prime, you have access to mountains of cheap content.HOWEVER. When you look at what you get for the small difference in cost, the Fire HD blows it away... You get a better screen, better sound, bluetooth, it's faster, thinner and lighter than the Fire. You also get double the memory, better wifi and over 2 hours more battery life. All for $40. I guess Amazon wants to make color Kindles as affordable as possible but I don't even know why they made the small one. I'm not sorry I bought it but all things considered, I would buy two big ones if I had it to do over.As I said above, I'll be updating this and taking questions in the comments all weekend.Hope this was helpful.

Reviews.Title: Great media device
Reviews.Author: K. Moulder "Bobmo5"
Reviews.Content: I bought my Fire HD 7 July 2013 for $159. That is the current special price that is available from Amazon and many other sources. If you think of this device as a media source then it exceeds expectations. Other reviewers have done a great job of extolling the great features of the Fire HD, my goal is to deal with negative issues raised by others. I own both a laptop and a desktop computers. I wasn't trying to acquire another full feature computer when I bought the Fire HD. Those people who complain about this device having computing limitations have unrealistic expectations. You don't get a full feature computer for $159. This device delivers great movies and eBooks. I bought a Fintie package for less then $13.00 (it included a magnetic cover, stylus, 12 volt charger, screen protector, and a cable). My cover turns on and off my Kindle (I don't use the built in switch). I control my volume level by using the on screen control (I never use the built in control). This eliminates two of complaints that others have voiced about the Kindle design. I downloaded about six apps to my Kindle (I am not trying to make it into an Ipad). I downloaded a free copy of Edward Jones Kindle manual. It is a great resource to read.I utilize my local library's "Borrow Kindle Books Program" which is tied to Amazon. This an amazing free source for eBooks. This program is available from over 11,000 public libraries. I own a Kindle 3, a Fire HD 7, and my wife a Kindle Fire. Each is a great device in it's class. Those who complain about the weight of this device have to realize that glass and the batteries make up most of this weight. If you reduce the battery weight you give up battery time.About the Amazon pricing of this device: I don't care about the wallpaper ads when I turn it on (I saved $15), I didn't need another USB charger (I have five including a 15 watt device), if you were buying your charger from Amazon why do you expect them to include another cable?, I like having control over how I bundle my purchases. Having redundant items included in my purchases forces me to waste my money. I think reviewers need to focus on a device's capabilities and not their expectations. Did the device deliver on the items promoted in the ad?Since I was not an early purchaser of my Fire HD hence the firmware updates may have contributed to the current status of an exceptional media device. Those who think the Nook is an alternative need to realize that Nook support is being discontinued.I have watched 10 free movies and read 15 books since I acquired my Kindle. I have satisfactorily used the Email, weather apps, sports updates, and borrowed books through my library program. I am not pleased that I cannot return eBooks through the Kindle (feature does not exist per Amazon support). I have to use my computer to return my eBooks. This needed feature may be addressed by Amazon in the future.

Reviews.Title: Just what She wanted!
Reviews.Author: fellas05
Reviews.Content: My wife debated for sometime whether she wanted an IPad or a Kindle. I told her that I believed she would enjoy the Kindle better since she loves to read books, watch movies and research. The ease of accessing all the things that she likes to do without the issues that the I-Tunes store presents is,what appeals to her. She can find as many free apps and all the books that she wants to read, and everyday there's suggested reading. She loves it, and it's not as big or heavy. I watch her drop it in her purse,and she's on the go! I would definitely recommend it for someone that wants many of the IPad features and quality at much less of the price.

Reviews.Title: Video downloads won't complete
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Only a few months old, and my Kindle HD's video download is kaput! I spent a couple hours on the phone with very nice techs who unfortunately couldn't solve the problem, even after the drastic process of de-registering the device. So, I'm on hold, waiting for help while they "look in to it." Boo-hoo. I really hope they can "fix" this so I can download some videos for an up-coming trip. I think I might have to stop by the Apple store on the way home from work this week. I've just had too much trouble with my Kindle Fire and HD.

Reviews.Title: Great product!  Good for a lot of uses!  So convenient!  Saves time and Money!
Reviews.Author: Bea Daniels "Bea"
Reviews.Content: I've wanted a Kindle for a long time but procrastinated because it is hard for me to understand and use new technology.  Fortunately, after reading the instructions a few times and experimenting, I can use the Kindle just fine and I am really enjoying it.  It took me about a week to get comfortable with it, but bear in mind that I have never used anything like it previously so I am a total novice when it comes to these things.When my granddaughter visits, the first thing she wants to do is read and play on the Kindle and it is very child-friendly.  I enjoy spending the time together with her on the Kindle.  It is a nice bonding experience.  I can get her to read on the Kindle, whereas, with books, she was more reluctant.  If you have a child who doesn't seem interested in reading, get a Kindle, it makes a big difference!It is really great to be able to download library books and free books instantly and there are a lot of books available for minimal cost as well.  I like instant gratification.  It has already saved me gas money and time going back and forth to the library!  Also, my hubby and I enjoy watching videos (youtube and other websites) from the comfort of our couch instead of having to sit at our desktop.

Reviews.Title: Great Device. Kindle Fire HD vs Kindle Touch
Reviews.Author: Adrian
Reviews.Content: With nearly 14,000 reviews, I'm pretty sure everyone knows the Kindle family is great to use, and great value for money. What I'd like to do is write a little comparing the 2 devices I have used- the Kindle Touch, and Kindle Fire HD.Around July last year, I bought a Kindle touch and my life was changed. I read a lot, and had literally boxes and boxes of books. Suddenly, finding storage space was not an issue, nor was waiting time for delivery. I saved time and money. Kindle touch became my new best friendBut with all good things come bad things. At the beginning of this year, the Touch developed vertical lines on the screen. Started with just one, but after 3 months, they became 1.5cm wide and I couldn't see the words. At the same time, I realised I needed something bigger than my mobile for doing some things like surfing the web and reading documents. In the end I decided to buy the Fire HD, despite the huge drop in battery time- one of the Touch's big pluses.So what have I noticed? I'm mostly happier with the Fire than Touch, but it's not all roses. - Weight: The Fire HD is really quite heavy compared to the touch, which meakes more cumbersome to carry and to put in your pocket. - Features: The Fire blows the Touch out of the water. Bright colour screen with great audio. Books can be listed by full colour covers, instead of just lists, as can all your videos, documents, music. - Connectivity: Related to Features, Fire HD loses to the version of Touch I had. Fire has only Wifi, while my Touch had Wifi and 3 G. This matters, because I don't have Wifi everywhere in my region, and when I travel I can only access Wifi from my hotel, if my hotel has Wifi. This means I can't surf the web, check emails or use many apps on the Fire except at home, where I have a wireless router set up. In contrast, I could use my Touch anywhere, and I mean anywhere. One time I was in the hills of Hong Kong and despite a very weak mobile phone signal, still managed to download a book via 3G. Now that's fantastic! - Useability: Once you have the stuff you want on the Fire, it is far and away better than the Touch. It is faster, more attractive, swishier. You can see the files when you plug it to your computer, flipping through pages in ebooks is instant, rather than 1-2 second pause with the Touch, and you can read ebooks in less than ideal light because it's a backlit screen, unlike the Touch. Of course the Touch doesn't play videos or music, so I won't compare those. - Fire limitations- The Fire HD screen seems to pick up dust more easily than the Touch, and light reflects off the screen much much more than the Touch. The Touch surface seems matt, and I never had to worry about light reflection before. - Battery life: The pure ebook readers have far longer battery life than the colour screen tablets. But even then the Fire is not too bad, especially when you compare to your mobile phones. It's not like I'm on the Fire 24/7. I find in normal use- a few minutes here, half an hour there, a battery might go 2.5 days before I need to charge it again. That's ok with me.So overall I'm really happy with the Fire HD. Glad I decided to buy the Fire, and not try to get an android tablet with the Kindle app, and also glad I didn't by a Touch replacement (white paper etc). If they could shave 100grams off the next version and include 3G(4G, whichever is latest) that would make it near perfect.Thanks for reading. I know I tend to get wordy!

Reviews.Title: Wow
Reviews.Author: Woodie
Reviews.Content: Wow, wow, wow. This thing blows me away. I've been using the Kindle eReader for about 3 years now and I really wanted color. This Kindle Fire outstrips all my expectations. The WiFi is blazing fast. The video is amazing. The movies are way cool. All my books are in color!! Zomg! I set the whole thing up in less than 10 minutes. I punched in my WiFi password and blam! I'm online. It sync'd with my Amazon account, all my books where there (in color), and my Amazon Prime Videos were all there too. Another few minutes and I'm browsing my email. The Silk webbrowser is amazing for such a small screen keyboard-less device. The user interface was a snap. I didn't even read any instructions. I have a new companion now. I don't know why I waited so long to get this. The price is so cheap now. And this thing is amazing. Now I love to read. So this makes much more sense to me than the tablets. All these other apps are icing on the cake. Email, Browser, Books, and Video. That is pretty much all I need in a tablet device.

Reviews.Title: Whoa!!!!!!
Reviews.Author: Pamela R. Jenkins "Southern Chick with Pointy...
Reviews.Content: I love this thing!!!  I had a Kindle black and white with keyboard that I really liked.  At the time my budget was limited and all I wanted was a dedicated reader.  I bought it about 2 years ago and have never regretted it.  This Christmas, 2012, I got some cash as a gift and, after much deliberation decided to buy a Kindle Fire HD.  Although I've only had it 2 months, all I can say is "Whoa!"  I love this thing!  Reading is a pleasure; no more clicking to turn pages, no more clicking to go to the file where my book is stored, no more clicking to organize my books.  I like the carousel type storage, and the touch screen moves easily.  The sound is amazing.  I listen to music on Pandora, news on the internet, movies, etc. and the sound is SO much bigger than the device.  Picture quality is great when watching movies and videos.  Games are great, lots of inexpensive or free apps.My husband had decided to buy a tablet instead of a KF HD, but after I'd had mine a week he had to have one, too.  He loves his as well.  If you can afford it, I would suggest the HD.  Although I have not compared it with the other KFs, I read that the sound quality alone was worth the purchase and I believe it.

Reviews.Title: 3 Months with My Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: William Verbjar
Reviews.Content: I received my 7" Kindle Fire HD 32GB on for Christmas 2012. It is my wife's and my first tablet. We did a lot of research before we made our choice. I personally was interested at the Ipad Mini, but the price ended that. I got to play with Kindle Fire HD at my mother in laws house, and quickly realized that this tablet has eveything I need/want.For my wife and I:  * All the webpages I visit on a regular basis are easily accessed, with a quick touch screen interface. Typing  on the touch keyboard is a breeze, especially swype...which I love.  * We easily uploaded the majority of our music to the cloud, and the  Fire HD's speakers  sound better than any other tablets. We listen to music quite a bit, so if you are doing some chores, its nice to take it with you.  * Movies and pictures look GREAT on the screen. Very bright and crisp.  * The battery life is very good.  * It has all the apps we need, and they all work great. Facebook is user friendly and responsive, as is Twitter. Our games we love to play ( Dice with Buddies, The Dark Knight Rises, ect) are there and play well and look good.  * Books and magazines look great and respond very well.  * The content on Amazon Prime is amazing. Especially for kids and book lovers. The free movie and television show list seems endless. Loved our free trial, and we will be subscribing soon  * Skype works great.For my kids:  * With the proper case, the Fire HD easily mounts to the back of the front seat of our cars. We do this for our long trips we have to take (3 hrs) to visit our family and friends. This is the main reason I went with the 32GB model. My kids enjoy watching a movie or two on the way.  * There are some great learning apps available. My son has gotten quite good at one app that has him identify animals and letters.  * We bought a HDMI cable off of Amazon to connect the Fire HD to our tv at home. I found it on Amazon's store on my Fire HD. Buying it was simple, and it works great. The kids love being able to watch their shows wherever they go.  There are a few things that I have found that I would have liked. The big one is a rear facing camera. This should have been a no brainer. If you have a front facing camera , why wouldn't you have a rear facing one? I understand the need to keep costs down...but this would have been nice. Not a deal breaker, because I have my cell phone's camera, but there are times with my 7 month old daughter that I would love to capture, and sometimes the Fire HD is all that's handy.  Another complaint is when I am exploring the Amazon music store. Whenever you are browsing a list of albums or songs and you click on one to hear a sample or see track listings, when you hit "back", it takes you all the way back to the top of the list. Now I have to scroll down again to see where i left off. This becomes annoying after about 3 times, especially when there is an album sale and there are 50+ albums to browse.  The power button is odd. There are no ridges on it. The volume buttons have ridges. I used to turn the tablet on its side and rotate it a time or two in order to find the power button. It blends right in with the side of the tablet. That being said, the case I bought helps identify where it is.  In closing, I would like to say that the Kindle Fire HD is a great tablet for entertainment and web browsing. I believe that is what it is meant for. I can't see myself doing any major business transactions on it. My family and I use it as a device to add a little fun and convenience into our lives. There is nothing better than find a great new recipe and taking the Fire HD over to the counter and using its case to make it stand. It sure beats walking back and forth to the laptop. Plus it takes up such little space. This is just one example of the great ways to use the Kindle Fire HD. Great job Amazon!

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: Paul wallimann
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Kindle for my daughter who reads alot.  She also likes its compact size and can carry it in her purse.  It hasgood sound and a nice picture when watching a movie considering it's only seven inches.  I would even buy another.

Reviews.Title: To everyone who  can't find the camera app
Reviews.Author: David
Reviews.Content: Where it says, shop, games, apps, etc.,  scroll right and you'll see photos. Click photos. Then you'll see a tiny camera button located in the right corner. Click it and now you can take photos.

Reviews.Title: I Love My Kindle Fire HD, best purchase I've made in computer, tablet, readers...
Reviews.Author: Steph
Reviews.Content: I love this tablet. I bought it to read books, but it is a lot more. I can facebook with my friends, email, text, play games, music, reading too. This Kindle is a surprising machine. All the free games and apps are endless. Free books and other reading material. My favorite thing to do is catch up with friends on Facebook at night when I'm in bed. I hold this light weight easy to see machine and message, text and share pictures and answer posts with one hand. Can't do that even with a laptop. I got stuck only once, froze up.
